Description: PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSING THE SUCCESS AND VULNERABILITY OF HAWAIIAN RARE PLANT INTRODUCTIONS TO INFORM FUTURE STABILIZATION EFFORTSPROJECT DATES: 8 15 2023 THROUGH 8 14 2025 AWARD PURPOSE: HAWAII IS KNOWN AS THE ENDANGERED SPECIES CAPITAL OF THE WORLD. DUE TO MORE THAN A CENTURY OF HABITAT DESTRUCTION, SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES, AND DECLINE OF POLLINATORS AND SEED DISPERSERS, HAWAII IS NOW HOME TO 400 ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES. HAWAII CONSERVATION MANAGERS HAVE SPENT THE LAST TWO DECADES PUTTING ENORMOUS EFFORT INTO TRYING TO REVERSE THIS SITUATION BY REINTRODUCING THOUSANDS OF RARE PLANTS INTO NEW SITES WITHIN PROTECTED FORESTS. TODAY HOWEVER, AS CLIMATE CHANGE SHIFTS PATTERNS OF TEMPERATURE, RAINFALL AND INTERACTIONS AMONG SPECIES, THE ABILITY OF REINTRODUCED POPULATIONS TO PERSIST OVER THE LONG-TERM IS UNKNOWN. SIMILARLY, MANAGERS DO NOT HAVE THE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO IDENTIFY WHICH SITES MIGHT BE MOST SUITABLE FOR FUTURE RARE PLANT REINTRODUCTIONS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE RARE PLANT MANAGERS WITH THIS INFORMATION THROUGH A COLLABORATION BETWEEN RESEARCHERS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AND THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, AND RESOURCE MANAGERS AT THE ARMY NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM OAHU (ANRPO) AND THE HAWAII PLANT PREVENTION EXTINCTION PROGRAM (PEPP). BY LEVERAGING TWO DECADES OF ANRPO AND PEPP CENSUS DATA FOR MORE THAN 300 POPULATIONS FOR 38 RARE PLANT TAXA, THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS AND SYNTHESIZE THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY ON REINTRODUCED RARE PLANT POPULATIONS AND BASED ON THIS, IDENTIFY STRATEGIES FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL SYNTHESIZE ANRPO AND PEPP DATASETS TO IDENTIFY THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY ON REINTRODUCED RARE PLANT POPULATIONS. USING DIFFERENT MODELING APPROACHES, THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY: DIRECT AND INDIRECT DRIVERS OF REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS  LONG-TERM PERSISTENCE OF 10 FOCAL SPECIES UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS  AND SPECIES TRAITS THAT PREDICT REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS OR FAILURE. THESE RESULTS WILL BE SHARED AND CROSS-VALIDATED WITH RARE PLANT EXPERTS ACROSS THE STATE, IN A SERIES OF WORKSHOPS ON FOUR ISLANDS. IN THE WORKSHOPS THE RECIPIENT ALSO WILL COMBINE MODEL RESULTS WITH FUTURE CLIMATE SUITABILITY MAPS TO IDENTIFY: THE GAP BETWEEN CURRENT AND RECOMMENDED REINTRODUCTION STRATEGIES  RARE PLANT TAXA UNLIKELY TO BE EFFECTIVELY CONSERVED IN SITU  AND OPPORTUNITIES TO PROVIDE SAFE HABITATS UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: SCIENCE PRODUCTS GENERATED WILL INCLUDE STRUCTURAL EQUATION MODELS THAT IDENTIFY DIRECT AND INDIRECT DRIVERS OF REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS FOR GROUPS OF SPECIES WITH SIMILAR LIFE HISTORY TRAITS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES  MATRIX MODELS FOR  10 FOCAL SPECIES AND ASSOCIATED PROJECTED RESPONSES TO CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BEST PRACTICES AND CLIMATIC CONDITIONS APPROPRIATE FOR FUTURE REINTRODUCTION OF THOSE SPECIES  SUMMARY OF TRAITS THAT PREDICT REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS IN BASED ON GLMMS AND CROSS-VALIDATED WITH ON-THE GROUND OBSERVATIONS  AND IDENTIFICATION OF  MANAGEMENT-DRIVEN FUTURE RESEARCH PRIORITIES. THESE WILL BE DESCRIBED IN THREE MANUSCRIPTS FOR PUBLICATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): RARE PLANT MANAGERS, AND CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS THE STATE OF HAWAII  UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AT MNOA STUDENTS  HAWAIIAN FORESTS  SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH COMMUNITY  THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: HOSTING THE SOUTHEAST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (SE CASC)PROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2028AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO HOST THE SOUTHEAST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (SE CASC). THE SE CASC CONSORTIUM CONSISTS OF ELEVEN INSTITUTIONS SPANNING SIX LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES, THREE HISTORICALLY BLACK MINORITY SERVING UNIVERSITIES, A NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED SCIENCE POLICY CENTER, AN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE CENTER, AND AN INTERTRIBAL ORGANIZATION REPRESENTING SOUTHERN EASTERN TRIBAL NATIONS. THIS CONSORTIUM OFFERS UNPARALLELED EXPERTISE IN COPRODUCING ACTIONABLE ADAPTATION SCIENCE ACROSS THE PHYSICAL, NATURAL, AND SOCIAL SCIENCES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE CONSORTIUM WILL ADDRESS THE SCIENCE PRIORITIES OF THE REGION THROUGH RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIS PROJECTS CO-PRODUCED WITH A DIVERSITY OF PARTNERS AND CONDUCT FORMAL EVALUATION OF PRODUCTS AND THEIR UTILITY. A GOVERNANCE COMMITTEE WILL LEAD SCIENCE, CAPACITY BUILDING, AND COMMUNICATION ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST AND CARIBBEAN FOOTPRINT. RECIPIENT STAFF WILL MEET WITH FEDERAL PARTNERS IN WEEKLY, MONTHLY, QUARTERLY, AND ANNUAL MEETINGS. REGIONAL DIALOGUE WILL BE FOSTERED THROUGH TWO REGIONAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE SYMPOSIA AND REGULAR PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS OF PARTNERS, INCLUDING THE HBCU CLIMATE CHANGE CONFERENCE. THE RECIPIENT WILL BUILD A ROBUST PORTFOLIO OF RESOURCES AND ACTIVITIES TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PARTNERS, GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND OTHER EARLY CAREER PROFESSIONAL RESEARCHERS, WITH TARGETED EFFORTS TO FOSTER ENGAGEMENT OF TRIBES, INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, AND OTHER COMMUNITIES HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED IN CLIMATE SCIENCE AND ADAPTATION. THE SE CASC COMMUNICATIONS STRATEGY WILL USE MULTIPLE FORMS OF MEDIA ENGAGEMENT TO REACH ACROSS MULTIPLE SECTORS OF END USERS AND ACROSS A DIVERSE FOOTPRINT. FINALLY, THE HOST UNIVERSITY WILL MANAGE THE LARGE AND COMPLEX FUNDING OF SUBAWARD PARTNERS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS FEDERAL-UNIVERSITY PARTNERSHIP, INCLUDING THE HOST (PRIME) AWARD AND DIRECTED PROJECT FUNDING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE RECIPIENT WILL: (1) DEVELOP A CONSORTIUM THAT REACHES ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST AND CARIBBEAN FOOTPRINT, AND FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS AMONG DECISION MAKERS, SCIENTISTS, AND MANAGERS  (2) CONDUCT CO-PRODUCED AND ACTIONABLE RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIS THROUGH PROJECTS THAT PROVIDE DECISION-FOCUSED, RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION MEETING REGIONAL SCIENCE PRIORITIES  (3) BUILD CAPACITY OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, GRADUATE RESEARCH STUDENTS, SCIENCE COMMUNICATIONS INTERNS AND OTHER YOUNG PROFESSIONALS IN HOW TO FRAME, UNDERSTAND, AND SUPPORT CLIMATE ADAPTATION DECISIONS, VIA RESEARCH ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS  (4) COMMUNICATE THE PRODUCTS CREATED FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION THROUGH DIVERSE MEDIA AND VENUES AND FOR MANY AUDIENCES  (5) ENGAGE TRIBES, INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, AND OTHER HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES IN CLIMATE RESEARCH, SYNTHESIS, AND CAPACITY BUILDING  (6) PROVIDE FISCAL MANAGEMENT OF AWARD FUNDING.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE RELEVANT FEDERAL AGENCIES, STATE AGENCIES, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, TRIBAL NATIONS AND INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, LOCAL COMMUNITIES INCLUDING HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESSES, RESEARCHERS AND EDUCATORS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: SUBRECIPIENTS WILL BE FULLY INTEGRATED INTO ALL CONSORTIUM ACTIVITIES INCLUDING LEADERSHIP, RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIS, CAPACITY BUILDING, AND COMMUNICATIONS. SUBAWARD PARTNERS INCLUDE: AUBURN UNIVERSITY, DUKE UNIVERSITY, SAVANNAH STATE UNIVERSITY, UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA, UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA, UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE, AND UNIVERSITY OF THE VIRGIN ISLANDS.

PROJECT TITLE: INFORMING LANDSCAPE-SCALE MANAGEMENT FOR RESILIENT PLANT COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE IDENTIFICATION OF CLIMATE-ADAPTED NATIVE SPECIESPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2026AWARD PURPOSE: THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF SPECIES IS EXPECTED TO SHIFT UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE AS SPECIES STRUGGLE TO ADAPT TO RAPIDLY CHANGING CONDITIONS. PLANT SPECIES ARE PARTICULARLY AT RISK BECAUSE THEY DISPERSE SLOWLY ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. TO FACILITATE PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT ARE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE CHANGE, CONSERVATION MANAGERS SEEK TO PLANT SPECIES ADAPTED TO FUTURE CLIMATIC CONDITIONS. HOWEVER, CONSERVATION MANAGERS RARELY HAVE INFORMATION ABOUT WHICH NATIVE SPECIES ARE BEST ADAPTED TO CLIMATE CHANGE WITHIN THEIR MANAGEMENT AREAS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THIS KNOWLEDGE GAP BY PROVIDING CONSERVATION MANAGERS WITH SITE-SPECIFIC LISTS OF CLIMATE-ADAPTED PLANT SPECIES. IT WILL SYNTHESIZE A NEW SPATIAL DATASET CONTAINING SPECIES COMPOSITION INFORMATION FROM THOUSANDS OF PLANT COMMUNITIES WITH THE LATEST SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELING ADVANCES TO IDENTIFY SETS OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES PREDICTED TO MAINTAIN THEIR ABUNDANCE UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE (SO CALLED, CLIMATE-SMART SPECIES). BY IDENTIFYING CLIMATESMART PLANT SPECIES LISTS, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A CRITICAL SCIENTIFIC FOUNDATION FOR HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PRACTICES THAT SUPPORT CLIMATE CHANGE RESILIENCE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL APPLY A STATE-OF-THE-ART JOINT SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODEL TO A MASSIVE REGIONAL PLANT COMMUNITY DATASET (14,000  PLOTS) TO ESTIMATE THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF REGIONAL PLANT SPECIES. THE FITTED MODEL WILL BE USED TO PREDICT THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF SPECIES WITHIN LOCAL PLANT COMMUNITIES IN THE NORTHEAST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER REGION UNDER TWO CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS TO IDENTIFY SETS OF CO-OCCURRING NATIVE PLANT SPECIES ABLE TO MAINTAIN THEIR POPULATION UNDER NOVEL CLIMATES. THESE CLIMATE-SMART PLANT LISTS WILL BE CONVEYED TO REGIONAL CONSERVATION MANAGERS THROUGH A PUBLICLY AVAILABLE WEB APPLICATION THAT ALLOWS USERS TO PROVIDE COORDINATES FOR MANAGEMENT SITES AND RETURNS SETS OF CLIMATE-SMART PLANT LISTS BASED ON MODEL PREDICTIONS. THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK WITH PROJECT PARTNERS TO ESTABLISH A REGIONAL WORKING GROUP OF CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS. IN COLLABORATION WITH THIS WORKING GROUP, THE RECIPIENT WILL DEFINE A SET OF CASE STUDY SITES TO TEST AND REFINE THE WEB APPLICATION MAXIMIZING ITS USABILITY AND CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT IMPACT. RESULTS AND TUTORIALS ON THE USE OF THE WEB APPLICATION WILL BE SHARED WITH REGIONAL PRACTITIONERS THROUGH WEBINARS AND WORKSHOPS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1) SPATIALLY EXPLICIT WEB APPLICATION ALLOWING USERS TO GENERATE CLIMATE-SMART PLANT SPECIES LISTS FOR THEIR SPECIFIC SITE UNDER WARMING SCENARIOS BASED ON JOINT SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODEL PREDICTIONS  2) GRIDDED MAPS OF INDIVIDUAL PLANT SPECIES RANGES ACROSS THE NORTHEAST REGION UNDER WARMING SCENARIOS  3) WEB APPLICATION TUTORIAL WEBINARS AND WORKSHOPS. WEB APPLICATION AND SPECIES MAPS WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ONLINE HOSTED ON A WEBPAGE. SCIENTIFIC OUTCOMES WILL BE SHARED IN PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS AND APPLIED ECOLOGY CONFERENCES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): REGIONAL PLANT CONSERVATION MANAGERS AND PROJECT PARTNERS AT FEDERAL, STATE, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS WORKING ON ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROJECTS. CLIMATE-SMART SPECIES LISTS GENERATED BY THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO SELECT SPECIES ADAPTED TO FUTURE CONDITIONS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: NORTHWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER HOSTPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2028AWARD PURPOSE: THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON (UW) PROPOSES TO CONTINUE HOSTING THE NORTHWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (NW CASC) IN CYCLE 2 TO BUILD UPON ITS SUCCESS HARNESSING THE NORTHWESTS EXTENSIVE EXPERTISE IN IDENTIFYING AND MANAGING CLIMATE RISKS TO SUPPORT NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS PURSUING CLIMATE ADAPTATION, WORKING IN CLOSE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) TO MAXIMIZE THE NW CASCS IMPACT IN PROMOTING REGIONAL RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   DELIVERABLES: THE NW CASC CONSORTIUM (UW AND SUBAWARD PARTNERS) WILL 1) SUPPORT RESEARCH ALIGNED WITH NW CASC AND DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR SECRETARIAL PRIORITIES WHILE 2) BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF NORTHWEST RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS TO CO-PRODUCE AND APPLY ACTIONABLE SCIENCE TO INFORM CLIMATE-ROBUST RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. NW CASC RESEARCH FELLOWSHIPS (UP TO 11 YEAR) WILL SUPPORT CONSORTIUM GRADUATE STUDENTS AND POSTDOCTORAL SCHOLARS TO COLLABORATE WITH MANAGERS TO CO-PRODUCE ACTIONABLE SCIENCE TO INFORM RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN A CHANGING CLIMATE. NW CASC FACULTY FELLOWSHIPS (5 YEAR) WILL SUPPORT CONSORTIUM FACULTY TO COLLABORATE WITH RESOURCE MANAGERS TO TRANSLATE RELEVANT RESEARCH INTO ACTIONABLE PRODUCTS AND PROVIDE RELATED CAPACITY BUILDING TO SUPPORT THEIR USE. ACTIONABLE SCIENCE DEEP DIVES (1 YEAR) WILL ENGAGE NORTHWEST RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS TO CO-PRODUCE KNOWLEDGE SYNTHESES AND IDENTIFY SCIENCE AND CAPACITY NEEDS TO ADDRESS EMERGING ADAPTATION CHALLENGES. THE CONSORTIUM WILL ADVANCE PARTICIPATION OF UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN SCIENCE BY SUPPORTING CLIMATE ADAPTATION INTERNSHIPS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE DORIS DUKE CONSERVATION SCHOLARS PROGRAM, AND ADAPTATION RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES FOR TRIBAL UNDERGRADUATES THROUGH THE NORTHWEST INDIAN COLLEGE (NWIC) RESEARCH EXPERIENCE FOR UNDERGRADUATES. THROUGH THESE AND ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING THE ACTIONABLE SCIENCE WEBINAR SERIES AND THE NORTHWEST CLIMATE CONFERENCE, THE CONSORTIUM WILL CONTINUE TO PROMOTE REGIONAL DIALOGUE AROUND DEVELOPING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE TO ADVANCE CLIMATE ADAPTATION. THE NW CASC COMMUNICATIONS PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THE CENTERS PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES.EXPECTED OUTCOMES   INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE RECIPIENT WILL REPORT ANNUALLY ON SCIENCE OUTCOMES, REGIONAL DIALOGUE, CAPACITY-BUILDING, AND COMMUNICATIONS ACCOMPLISHMENTS. AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE AGREEMENT, THE RECIPIENT WILL SUMMARIZE AND EVALUATE ACTIONABLE SCIENCE ACTIVITIES, SCIENTIFIC ACHIEVEMENTS, CAPACITY-BUILDING, AND COMMUNICATIONS HIGHLIGHTS. THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS AWARD INCLUDE THE COMMUNITIES THAT RELY ON THE CONTINUED RESILIENCE OF THE NORTHWESTS NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES  THE NORTHWEST RESOURCE MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS PARTICIPATING IN CONSORTIUM-FUNDED PROJECTS AND ACTIONABLE SCIENCE DEEP DIVES  RESOURCE MANAGERS BENEFITING FROM FACULTY INITIATIVES IN THE FACULTY FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM  THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC AND RESEARCH COMMUNITY AND AUDIENCES OF GRADUATE STUDENT AND POSTDOCTORAL SCHOLAR PARTICIPATION IN THE NW CASC RESEARCH FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM AS WELL AS THE UNDERGRADUATE ADAPTATION RESEARCH PRODUCED BY INTERNS AND RESEARCHERS PARTICIPATING IN THE NWIC RESEARCH EXPERIENCE FOR UNDERGRADUATES AND DORIS DUKE CONSERVATION SCHOLARS PROGRAM, RESPECTIVELY  THE GENERAL PUBLIC. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL SUBAWARD TO THE FOLLOWING 8 PARTNERS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT: AFFILIATED TRIBES OF NORTHWEST INDIANS, BOISE STATE UNIVERSITY, NORTHWEST INDIAN COLLEGE, OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY, PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY, UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA, WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY, AND WESTERN WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY.

PROJECT TITLE: CREATING THE NEXT GENERATION OF DOWNSCALED CLIMATE PROJECTIONS FOR THE SOUTH-CENTRAL UNITED STATESPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE:TO PROVIDE STATE-OF-THE-ART CLIMATE PROJECTIONS TO AID STAKEHOLDERS IN MINIMIZING CLIMATE IMPACTS AND BUILDING RESILIENCE RELATED TO WATER SCARCITY, WILDFIRE, AND OTHER CONCERNS IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (SC CASC) REGION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THIS PROJECT WILL USE TWO MAIN TASKS TO PRODUCE DOWNSCALED CLIMATE PROJECTIONS FOR THE REGION. TASK 1 WILL EVALUATE THE AVAILABLE GLOBAL CLIMATE MODELS FOR THEIR ABILITY TO REPRESENT HISTORICAL PRECIPITATION AND TEMPERATURE (BOTH AVERAGES AND EXTREMES) AND THE SPREAD OF FUTURE PROJECTIONS. THE EVALUATION IN TASK 1 WILL BE USED TO SELECT A SUBSET OF GLOBAL CLIMATE MODELS USED FOR STATISTICAL DOWNSCALING. TASK 2 WILL STATISTICALLY DOWNSCALE THE CHOSEN GLOBAL CLIMATE MODELS FROM TASK 1 USING MULTIPLE STATISTICAL DOWNSCALING TECHNIQUES, MULTIPLE SETS OF TRAINING DATA, AND MULTIPLE SHARED SOCIOECONOMIC PATHWAYS. THE RESULTING DOWNSCALED CLIMATE PROJECTIONS WILL BE EVALUATED FOR THEIR HISTORICAL SKILL OVER THE PERIOD 1986-2015. THE FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF DAILY HIGH TEMPERATURE, DAILY LOW TEMPERATURE, AND DAILY TOTAL PRECIPITATION WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, AND SSP5-8.5 FOR THE PERIOD 2016-2100.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:DATASETS CONTAINING DOWNSCALED CLIMATE PROJECTIONS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO STAKEHOLDERS ALONGSIDE NUMEROUS VISUALIZATIONS AND GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL MAKE USE OF GUIDANCE FROM SOUTH CENTRAL CASC STAKEHOLDERS TO DETERMINE OTHER GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS AND VISUALIZATIONS THAT WOULD BE USEFUL IN MEETING STAKEHOLDER NEEDS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):STAKEHOLDERS OF THE SOUTH CENTRAL CASC AND REGIONAL SCIENTISTS ENGAGED IN IMPACTS ASSESSMENTS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:N A

PROJECT TITLE: CLIMATE-MEDIATED SPECIES MOVEMENT: TOWARDS A NATIONAL SYNTHESISPROJECT DATES: 7 15 2023 THROUGH 7 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO ADVANCE SCIENTIFIC SYNTHESIS ON CLIMATE MEDIATED SPECIES MOVEMENT ACROSS THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (CASC) NETWORK-BY CONVENING A NETWORK OF EXPERTS AND EARLY CAREER RESEARCHERS IN THE FIELD OF CLIMATE-MEDIATED RANGE SHIFTS AND ADVANCING SKILLS NECESSARY FOR THAT RESEARCH. THIS WORK WILL ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW CLIMATE CHANGE IS AFFECTING SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE NATIONAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (NCASC) TO:-DETERMINE SPECIFIC TOPICS AND OVERARCHING RESEARCH QUESTIONS OF THE NATIONAL SYNTHESIS EFFORT-DESCRIBE THE INTENDED PRODUCTS-WORK CLOSELY WITH REGIONAL SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS TO DEFINE PROJECT COMPONENTS-SUPPORT RESEARCHERS NATIONAL-SCALE WORK-ADVISE ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF CRITICAL SKILLS NECESSARY TO UNDERTAKE THIS RESEARCH, INCLUDING BESTPRACTICES FOR CONDUCTING INTERDISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND TEAM SCIENCE IN AN ACTIONABLE SETTING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE RECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP AND SUBMIT AN INTERIM REPORT REFLECTING PROGRAM PROGRESS, MILESTONES ACHIEVED, AND DEVELOPMENT NOTES FROM VISITS TO THE REGIONAL CASCS IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY REGIONAL-SCALE RANGE SHIFT PRIORITIES, AND TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS AND SUBMIT A REPORT SYNTHESIZING THE  STATE OF THE SCIENCE  ON CLIMATE- MEDIATED SPECIES RANGE SHIFTS. THIS REPORT WILL BE PREPARED IN CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH NCASC AND BASED ON INPUT RECEIVED DURING REGIONAL CASC SITE VISITS AND DISCUSSIONS. THIS REPORT WILL OUTLINE THE MAJOR RESEARCH AREAS ASSOCIATED WITH CLIMATE-MEDIATED SPECIES RANGE SHIFTS, WHAT MAJOR FUTURE RESEARCH AVENUES MIGHT LOOK LIKE, AND WHAT THE PRIMARY MANAGEMENT APPLICATIONS OF THIS RESEARCH ARE EXPECTED TO BE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): WORK DONE IN THIS LARGER PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A BROADER, MULTI-PERSPECTIVE CONSIDERATION OF HOW HABITAT MODIFICATIONS CAN EITHER FACILITATE OR BLOCK CLIMATE-INDUCED SPECIES RANGE SHIFTS. DURING THE DEVELOPMENT OF FURTHER CASC RESEARCH, IT IS CRITICAL TO ENSURE THAT ANY WORK INTO URBAN BUILT ENVIRONMENT IS LINKED BACK TO THE CASC CORE RESEARCH AREAS (FISH, WILDLIFE, WATER, AND LAND). THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT THE PRIMARY CASC STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR, STATE, AND TRIBAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AS WELL AS THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYPROJECT TITLE: DEVELOPING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE PRIORITIES FOR CULTURAL RESOURCES THROUGH DELIBERATIVE FORUMS IN TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIESPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE:CLIMATE CHANGE THREATENS TO DAMAGE HISTORICAL SITES AND DISRUPT CULTURAL PRACTICES IN COMMUNITIES AROUND THE WORLD. CURRENTLY LITTLE GUIDANCE EXISTS FOR DECISION MAKERS INTERESTED IN PROTECTING THEM. BECAUSE COMMUNITIES VALUE AND INTERACT WITH CULTURAL RESOURCES IN DIFFERENT WAYS, EFFECTIVELY PLANNING FOR THEIR PROTECTION REQUIRES BROAD BASED PUBLIC PARTICIPATION. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PERFORM RESEARCH AND FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS ABOUT CLIMATE THREATS TO CULTURAL RESOURCES TO DETERMINE THE NEEDS OF MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES AROUND THE SOUTHERN US AND PLAN FOR THEIR PROTECTION. THROUGH RELATIONSHIP BUILDING, COMMUNITY OUTREACH, AND A LITERATURE REVIEW, THIS PROJECT WILL LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR PROVIDING INFORMATION ON AND CONDUCTING DELIBERATIVE PUBLIC FORUMS ON CLIMATE CHANGE AND CULTURAL RESOURCES IN TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES. THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES AROUND THE SOUTHERN US TO FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS ABOUT CLIMATE THREATS TO CULTURAL RESOURCES AND PLAN FOR THEIR PROTECTION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE RECIPIENT WILL FOCUS ON (1) BUILDING RELATIONSHIPS WITH RESEARCHERS AND PROFESSIONALS WORKING TO PROTECT CULTURAL RESOURCES FROM THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, (2) IDENTIFYING AND ENGAGING WITH TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES IN OKLAHOMA, ARKANSAS, AND SOUTH CAROLINA WHO MAY BE INTERESTED IN HOSTING DELIBERATIVE PUBLIC FORUMS ON THIS TOPIC, AND (3) REVIEWING CURRENT LITERATURE ON HOW CULTURAL RESOURCES HAVE BEEN DEFINED FOR THE PURPOSE OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING. THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO CREATE A WORKING DEFINITION OF CULTURAL RESOURCES FOR THE PURPOSES OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SCIENCE PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE A PUBLISHABLE LITERATURE REVIEW AND AN ARTICLE FOCUSED ON THE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND PLANNING PROCESS. IN ADDITION, THIS PLANNING PROJECT WILL LAY THE FOUNDATIONS FOR CONDUCTING DELIBERATIVE PUBLIC FORUMS IN TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES TO FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS ABOUT CLIMATE THREATS TO CULTURAL RESOURCES AND PLAN FOR THEIR PROTECTION. ADDITIONAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE IDENTIFICATION OF 3-5 TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES IN OKLAHOMA, ARKANSAS, AND SOUTH CAROLINA WHO MAY BE INTERESTED IN HOSTING DELIBERATIVE PUBLIC FORUMS ON THIS ISSUE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT SCHOLARS AND PRACTITIONERS WORKING TO PROTECT CULTURAL RESOURCES FROM THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, AS WELL AS TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES INTERESTED IN FUTURE COMMUNITY-BASED RESEARCH ON THIS TOPIC. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP DEVELOP A ROBUST NETWORK OF TRIBAL AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITY PARTNERS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN EXAMINING CULTURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:SUBAWARD PARTNERS WILL WORK WITH MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES IN ARKANSAS AND SOUTH CAROLINA. IN ARKANSAS THEY WILL CONNECT WITH MINORITY COMMUNITIES AROUND THE STATE, SUCH AS AFRICAN AMERICAN, HISPANIC, AND HMONG FARMERS. THE SOUTH CAROLINA TEAM WILL FOCUS ON TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL COASTAL COMMUNITIES, SUCH AS THE GULLAH GEECHEE, WHO ARE DESCENDANTS OF ENSLAVED AFRICANS. TEAM MEMBERS AND COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES WILL ALSO PARTICIPATE IN A TEAM GATHERING IN NORMAN, OK TO STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND THE RESEARCH TEAM AND COLLABORATIVELY DESIGN THE RESEARCH PROJECT. RESEARCH TEAM MEMBERS WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO THE LITERATURE REVIEW AND THE ARTICLE FOCUSED ON THE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND PLANNING PROCESS.

PROJECT TITLE: HOSTING ALASKAS CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2028AWARD PURPOSE:ALASKAS TEMPERATURES ARE WARMING AT FOUR TIMES THE RATE OF THE CONTIGUOUS US, IMPACTING ITS NATURAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC SYSTEMS THROUGH THE TIMING, FREQUENCY, AND SEVERITY OF WILDFIRES, FLOODING, COASTAL EROSION, PERMAFROST DEGRADATION, GLACIER MASS LOSS, AND CHANGING SNOWPACK, AMONG OTHER IMPACTS. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT ESTABLISHES THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA AS THE ACADEMIC HOST OF THE ALASKA CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER. THE CENTER PROVIDES SCIENCE EXPERTISE AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SUPPORT CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION BY DEVELOPING, FACILITATING, AND TRANSLATING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE. ACTIONABLE SCIENCE HELPS SOCIETAL PARTNERS AND DECISION MAKERS THROUGHOUT ALASKA MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT THE REGIONS LAND, PLANTS, ANIMALS, AND ULTIMATELY THE WELLBEING OF ITS RESIDENTS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE CENTER WILL: (1) ENGAGE EARLY- MID- AND LATE-CAREER SCIENTISTS IN RESEARCH, SCIENCE APPLICATION, AND COMMUNICATION ACTIVITIES TO INCREASE AND EXPAND RESEARCH SKILLS, (2) SUPPORT RESEARCHERS, RESOURCE MANAGERS, ADAPTATION PLANNERS, AND OTHERS GENERATING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE TO SUPPORT CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, (3) IMPROVE AND EXPAND  REGIONAL DIALOGUE VIA THREE NEW CLIMATE ADAPTATION COORDINATION POSITIONS COVERING SOUTHEAST, WESTERN, AND INTERIOR ALASKA, (4) SUPPORT A COMMUNITY OF LEARNING, SHARING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND OUTREACH FOR ALASKA TRIBES AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES AS THEY RESPOND AND ADAPT TO CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS, (5) BUILD CAPACITY IN  CLIMATE ADAPTATION SERVICES VIA PARTNER ENGAGEMENT STRATEGIES, GEOSPATIAL SCIENCE, REGIONAL CLIMATE MODELING, AND INTERFACE WITH THE STATE OF ALASKA ON CLIMATE AND CRYOSPHERE HAZARDS, AND (6) ENGAGE IN COMMUNICATION ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION ACTIVITIES IN ALASKA, INCLUDING PROVIDING THOUGHT LEADERSHIP, ACTIONABLE SCIENCE CASE STUDIES, RESEARCH INTERNSHIPS, A PODCAST AND RADIO SHOW, AND A CENTER RESEARCH STORYMAP.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE KEY OUTCOMES WILL BE: (1) ALASKA FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENTS ENGAGED IN ACTIONABLE SCIENCE, (2) HUMAN INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT AND FACILITATE THE CREATION OF ACTIONABLE SCIENCE, (3) ENHANCED REGIONAL PARTNERSHIPS AND DIALOGUE, (4) COUPLING THE LIVED EXPERIENCES OF ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLES WITH RELEVANT SCIENCE TO INFORM DECISION-MAKING, (5) EXPANDED SCIENCE CAPACITY, AND (6) ENGAGING SCIENCE COMMUNICATION THAT SUPPORTS DECISION MAKERS. THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLES WILL BE STAFF (BOTH ADMINISTRATIVE AND TECHNICAL) AND SCIENTISTS TO CARRY OUT THE ACTIVITIES PERFORMED AND THE OFFICE AND MEETING SPACE REQUIRED FOR CENTER STAFF, SCIENTISTS, AND VISITORS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):228 ALASKAN TRIBES, FEDERAL AND STATE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND THE COMMUNITIES AND RESIDENTS OF ALASKA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:NO SUBRECIPIENTS  UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA SYSTEM CAMPUSES ONLY.

PROJECT TITLE: A FRESH SET OF TOOLS: NEW INFORMATION FOR MANAGING FISHERIES DURING CHANGES IN RIVER DISCHARGEPROJECT DATES: 9 15 2023 THROUGH 9 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT INVESTIGATES THE FISHERIES RESPONSE TO BONNET CARR SPILLWAY (BCS) OPENINGS IN THE CONTEXT OF BOTH PHYSICAL (I.E., SALINITY, WATER TEMPERATURE) AND BIOLOGICAL (I.E., NUTRIENT AVAILABILITY, PHYTOPLANKTON GROWTH) PROCESSES. ITS CENTRAL MANAGEMENT QUESTION IS: HOW DOES THE TIMING AND MAGNITUDE OF FRESHWATER DISCHARGE FROM THE BCS AFFECT LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN FISHERIES BOTH DURING AND AFTER ITS OPERATION  THE BCS IS A WELL-KNOWN FLOOD CONTROL STRUCTURE THAT MOVES EXCESS WATER FROM THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER INTO LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN ESTUARY, THEREBY PREVENTING FLOODING TO THE CITY OF NEW ORLEANS. HOWEVER, THE LARGE INTRODUCTION OF FRESHWATER DURING BCS OPENINGS SEVERELY DISTURBS VALUABLE FISHERIES BY TRIGGERING ALGAL BLOOMS, REDUCING SALINITY, AND COOLING WATER TEMPERATURES BELOW SEASONAL NORMS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE CENTRAL MANAGEMENT QUESTION WILL BE ADDRESSED VIA THREE OBJECTIVES: (1) ESTIMATE THE FUTURE FREQUENCY OF BCS OPERATION USING GLOBAL CLIMATE MODEL PROJECTIONS  (2) DETERMINE THE HISTORICAL RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE TIMING, INTENSITY, AND DURATION OF BCS EVENTS AND SUBSEQUENT ALGAL BIOMASS  (3) ASSESS THE HISTORICAL RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PHYTOPLANKTON BIOMASS AND SUBSEQUENT COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES PRODUCTIVITY AS WELL AS THE RECOVERY PERIOD.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PROJECT RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL BE COMMUNICATED IN AT LEAST TWO JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS: ONE DETAILING THE FUTURE BCS PROJECTIONS AND THE SECOND FOCUSING ON POST-BCS PHYTOPLANKTON BIOMASS AND FISHERIES. AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROJECT, THE PROJECTS LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES (LDWF) REPRESENTATIVE WILL HELP ARRANGE AN END-OF-PROJECT BRIEFING AT LDWF HEADQUARTERS IN BATON ROUGE FOR PERSONNEL THAT ARE NOT INCLUDED ON THE STAKEHOLDER ADVISORY TEAM. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE EXECUTIVE SUMMARIES AND INFOGRAPHICS TO LDWF AND TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPW). THESE MATERIALS WILL ALSO BE SHARED WITH THE LOUISIANA SEA GRANT FOR DISTRIBUTION DURING THEIR MARINE EXTENSION ACTIVITIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE LDWF, THE LOUISIANA SEA GRANT, THE TPW, THE USGS, RESEARCH COMMUNITIES, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. IN PRE-PROPOSAL DISCUSSIONS, AGENCY REPRESENTATIVES INDEPENDENTLY REPORTED THAT BCS YEARS ARE POOR FISHING SEASONS WHILE POST-BCS YEARS ARE ANECDOTALLY STRONG SEASONS. HOWEVER, THERE IS NO SCIENCE-BASED RESEARCH TO SUPPORT THIS IDEA AND USE IT IN AN ACTIONABLE CONTEXT. QUANTITATIVE ANALYSES OF THESE EFFECTS WILL ALLOW LDWF TO BETTER SELECT OPEN AND CLOSE DATES FOR AFFECTED FISHERIES AS WELL AS APPLY FOR NOAA FEDERAL FISHERIES DISASTER DECLARATIONS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA WILL SUBAWARD TO LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE: MEGAFIRE RISK EVALUATION SYSTEM (MERES) FOR PROJECTING FUTURE MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY IN THE SOUTHERN GREAT PLAINSPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE: MEGAFIRES ARE OCCURRING AT AN UNPRECEDENTED FREQUENCY IN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS AND HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BECOME COMMON IN THE FUTURE. THIS INCREASING TREND COMES ALONG WITH THE CHANGING CLIMATE AND WOODY PLANT ENCROACHMENT INTO GRASSLANDS. HOWEVER, MEGAFIRE RISK EVALUATION TOOLS TO PREDICT FUTURE MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY AND QUANTIFY THE CONTRIBUTIONS FROM KEY FACTORS ARE LACKING. THIS LIMITATION IS RESTRICTING GOVERNMENT AGENCIES CAPACITY TO DESIGN FUEL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO REDUCE FUTURE MEGAFIRE RISKS AND MAKE LONG-TERM PREPAREDNESS DECISIONS FOR ADAPTING TO THE CHANGING FIRE REGIMES. FOR THIS PROJECT, THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP A MEGAFIRE RISK EVALUATION SYSTEM (MERES) TO MAKE FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY IN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS FROM 2024 TO 2100 AND TRANSFER THIS SYSTEM AND PRODUCTS TO STAKEHOLDERS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL COLLECT HISTORICAL MEGAFIRE RECORDS, WEATHER CONDITIONS, FUEL CHARACTERISTICS, AND TOPOGRAPHY DATA FROM VARIOUS SOURCES. THESE DATA WILL BE PROCESSED TO THE SAME SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL RESOLUTIONS FOR TRAINING AND VALIDATING RETROSPECTIVE MACHINE LEARNING MODELS (I.E., LOGISTIC REGRESSION, RANDOM FOREST, SUPPORT-VECTOR MACHINE, AND NAVE BAYES). NEXT, EVALUATION METRICS WILL BE USED TO QUANTIFY MODELS PERFORMANCE. THE MODEL WITH THE BEST PERFORMANCE WILL BE SELECTED TO DEVELOP THE GRIDDED MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY DATASET UNDER SIX CLIMATE AND FUEL SCENARIOS. RESOLUTIONS OF THE FUTURE MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY PRODUCTS ARE TENTATIVELY SET TO BE 10 KM AND 1 MONTH, WHICH WILL BE ADJUSTED ACCORDING TO STAKEHOLDERS NEEDS FOR DESIGNING LAND MANAGEMENT AND WILDFIRE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: (1) THE MACHINE LEARNING-BASED MERES FOR PREDICTING MEGAFIRE RISKS  (2) GRIDDED DATASETS AND MAPS OF MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY FROM 2024 TO 2100 IN CLIMATE CHANGE AND FUEL CHANGE SCENARIOS  (3) WEB-BASED PLATFORMS TO DISSEMINATE PROJECT RESULTS  (4) TWO PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE PROJECTED MEGAFIRE RISKS ARE CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND FUTURE TRENDS OF MEGAFIRE RISKS AND IDENTIFY AREAS WITH HIGH MEGAFIRE PROBABILITY. THIS KNOWLEDGE PROVIDES A SCIENTIFIC BASIS FOR GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS TO PRIORITIZE FUEL MANAGEMENT RESOURCES AND ADJUST LAND MANAGEMENT POLICIES TO REDUCE MEGAFIRE RISKS. ALSO, PROJECT OUTCOMES ARE EXPECTED TO GUIDE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS TO DESIGN PROACTIVE STRATEGIES TO REDUCE WILDFIRE IMPACTS ON HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY, PROTECT INFRASTRUCTURE AND WILDLIFE HABITATS, AND PROMOTE ADAPTIVE RESILIENCE TO THE SGP WILDFIRES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LANDOWNERS IN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS AND FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES RELEVANT TO FIRE PROTECTION AND SAFETY, FORESTRY, AGRICULTURE, WILDLIFE, AND INFRASTRUCTURE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE: UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACTS OF EXTREME EVENTS ON OUR NATIONAL PARKS: PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTUREPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE:THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE WITH THE CLIMATE CHANGE RESPONSE PROGRAM OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) TO DEVELOP A PLAN TO CO-PRODUCE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES AND EDUCATIONAL SERVICES ABOUT THE THREATS THAT DIFFERENT EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS HAVE ON NATIONAL PARKS. THE TEAM HAS TWO MAIN GOALS: (1) DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR A COLLABORATIVE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PROJECT TO INVESTIGATE THE IMPACTS OF EXTREME WEATHER (E.G., EXTREME PRECIPITATION, FIRES) IN A CHANGING CLIMATE ON THE U.S. NATIONAL PARKS AND 2) ANALYZE CAPACITY AND NEEDS FOR UNDERSTANDING CHANGES IN EXTREME WEATHER AND ITS SUBSEQUENT EFFECTS ON ITS NATIONAL PARKS AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE RECIPIENT WILL HOLD A 2-DAY WORKSHOP TO GATHER DATA ON CLIMATE CHANGE RISKS SPECIFIC TO INDIVIDUAL EXTREME WEATHER TYPES AND SO-CALLED COMPOUND EVENTS (I.E., ONE OR MORE EXTREME WEATHER TYPES), DETERMINE QUANTIFIABLE METRICS OF EXTREME WEATHER THAT ARE USEFUL FOR NATIONAL PARK SERVICE PARTNERS AND DERIVABLE FROM CLIMATE MODELS, AND IDENTIFY SPECIFIC PARK(S) AND PERSONNEL FOR AN INITIAL PROJECT. ALL DERIVED METRICS WILL BE COMPARED TO HISTORICAL TRENDS IN THE PARK(S) TO QUANTIFY CHANGES AND HELP DEFINE THE SCOPE OF A LARGER PROJECT IDEA. IN PREPARATION FOR THE MEETING, THE RECIPIENT WILL ORGANIZE PRELIMINARY ANALYSES ON POTENTIAL METRICS THAT WOULD BE USEFUL FOR THE NPS TO EXAMINE AS A FUNCTION OF TIME (E.G., THE NUMBER OF DAYS EXCEEDING A CERTAIN HIGH TEMPERATURE THRESHOLD, THE NUMBER OF EXTREME RAINFALL DAYS, DROUGHT DURATION AND SEVERITY, AND DAYS WITH FAVORABLE FIRE WEATHER ENVIRONMENTS), BUT FOCUSED ON THE DECADAL TIMESCALE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE DATA DERIVED FROM THE PLANNED WORKSHOP THAT CAN BE ANALYZED FOR THEMES RELATED TO CAPACITY, NEEDS, AND OPTIONS FOR CO-PRODUCTION OF KNOWLEDGE. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PILOT PROJECT TO ADDRESS EXTREME WEATHER AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE THE INFORMATION GAINED AT THIS WORKSHOP TO DEVELOP A SET OF FACTSHEETS ON PAST EXTREME WEATHER TRENDS, THEIR EXPECTED FUTURE CHANGES, AND THE HAZARDS AND THREATS THEY POSE FOR THE SPECIFIC PARK. THESE FACTSHEETS WILL BE DIVERSE AND WILL EDUCATE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE PARTNERS AND PARK VISITORS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND THE PUBLIC. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: OPERATIONALIZING THE RESIST-ACCEPT-DIRECT FRAMEWORK TO MANAGE WILDFIRES AND CARBON STORAGE IN THE CONTEXT OF ECOLOGICAL TRANSFORMATIONS IN THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEMPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE:THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE AREA IS AN ICONIC LANDSCAPE WITH NATIONAL PARKS, CHARISMATICSPECIES LIKE GRIZZLY BEARS AND ELK, AND OVER 11,500 MI. OF FOREST. WHILE FIRES ARE A NATURAL PART OFTHIS LANDSCAPE, CLIMATE CHANGE AND LAND MANAGEMENT LEGACIES ARE INCREASING THE FREQUENCY ANDSIZE OF SEVERE FIRES. CLIMATE CHANGE INTERACTS WITH THESE FIRES TO SHIFT CONIFER FORESTS TO NON-FORESTECOSYSTEMS (E.G., GRASSLANDS AND SAGEBRUSH). THESE TRANSFORMATIONS IMPACT SPECIES HABITAT ANDOTHER MANAGEMENT GOALS ON PUBLIC LANDS, INCLUDING CARBON STORAGE. RESOURCE MANAGERS IN THEGREATER YELLOWSTONE AREA RECOGNIZE THAT MANAGING FOR NATURAL ECOSYSTEMS MAY NOT BE POSSIBLEIN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND SEEK TOOLS TO ACCOUNT FOR CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED ECOSYSTEMCHANGES. THE RESIST- ACCEPT-DIRECT FRAMEWORK CAN HELP: UNDER THE RESIST- ACCEPT-DIRECTFRAMEWORK, MANAGERS CAN RESIST CHANGE TO MAINTAIN CURRENT ECOSYSTEMS, ACCEPT CLIMATE-DRIVENECOLOGICAL CHANGES, EVEN IF THAT MEANS LOSING SPECIES HABITAT OR ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, OR DIRECTECOSYSTEM CHANGES TO MAINTAIN OR GAIN KEY RESOURCES OR SERVICES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK WITH MANAGERS IN THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE AREA TO IMPLEMENT THE RESIST-ACCEPT-DIRECT FRAMEWORK AS A STRATEGY TO MANAGE WILDFIRES AND SUBSEQUENT ECOSYSTEM CHANGES.THEY WILL COLLABORATE WITH MANAGERS FROM EACH GREATER YELLOWSTONE AREA AGENCY TO IDENTIFY 1)SHARED AND DIFFERING MANAGEMENT GOALS, 2) MANAGEMENT OPTIONS THAT CAN RESIST, ACCEPT, OR DIRECTWILDFIRE-RELATED ECOSYSTEM CHANGES, AND 3) OPPORTUNITIES FOR AGENCIES TO COORDINATEIMPLEMENTATION OF THE RESIST- ACCEPT-DIRECT FRAMEWORK ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE TO ACHIEVE THEIRGOALS, SINCE FIRES SPAN MANAGEMENT BOUNDARIES. THROUGH SYNTHESIS OF THE SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE, REVIEW OF MANAGEMENT PLANS, AND SEMISTRUCTUREDINTERVIEWS WITH FIRE, VEGETATION, AND RESOURCE MANAGERS IN EACH MANAGEMENT UNIT IN THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE AREA, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY SHARED AND DIVERGING DESIRED FUTURE STATES IN RELATION TO CLIMATE CHANGE, ECOLOGICAL TRANSFORMATIONS, WILDFIRE, AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. THEY WILL FACILITATE A WORKSHOP FOR FURTHER DATA GATHERING, BRINGING TOGETHER MANAGERS FROM ACROSS THE REGION TO DISCUSS HOW THE RESIST-ACCEPT-DIRECT FRAMEWORK CAN ASSIST IN ACHIEVING LANDSCAPE-SCALE GOALS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL HELP MANAGERS IDENTIFY AND COORDINATE APPROACHES TO ACHIEVE THEIR CONSERVATION GOALS IN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE, ENSURING THE PRESERVATION OF KEY SPECIES, ECOSYSTEMS, AND RESOURCES IN THE NORTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER REGIONS PUBLIC LANDS. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE REPORTS, PRESENTATIONS, AND WEBINARS THAT SYNTHESIZE THE EXISTING SCIENCE, THE RANGE OF MANAGEMENT GOALS, AND POTENTIAL FOR RESIST-ACCEPT-DIRECT COORDINATION CONTRIBUTIONS TO DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR AND NATIONAL PARK SERVICE FOR MANAGING WILDFIRES ANDECOLOGICAL TRANSFORMATIONS  A SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATION  AND A CO-PRODUCED PROPOSAL FOR A DECISIONSUPPORT TOOL TO ASSIST RESOURCE MANAGERS IN IMPLEMENTING THE RESIST-ACCEPT-DIRECT FRAMEWORK.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):RESOURCE MANAGERS, SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: MANAGING ECOLOGICAL TRANSFORMATION TO ENHANCE CARBON STORAGE AND BIODIVERSITYPROJECT DATES: 7 1 2023 THROUGH 6 30 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THIS WORK WILL EXPLORE KEY MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES INCLUDING NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITY RESILIENCE AND MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES, WILDFIRE, AND ECOSYSTEM CHANGE, THROUGH A COLLABORATION BETWEEN RESEARCHERS, LAND MANAGERS AND OTHER PRACTITIONERS WITHIN THE NORTH CENTRAL REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE (NC RISCC) NETWORK. RESEARCH EFFORTS WILL PRODUCE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT WHICH MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ENHANCE CARBON STORAGE, A KEY ECOSYSTEM SERVICE THAT AGENCIES WANT TO INCLUDE IN MANAGEMENT PLANS AND STRATEGIES, YET LARGELY HAVE NOT YET DONE SO. THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY AREAS THAT HAVE UNDERGONE ECOSYSTEM TRANSFORMATION (I.E., MAJOR STRUCTURAL AND FUNCTIONAL CHANGES ACCOMPANYING THE TRANSITION FROM FOREST- OR SHRUB-DOMINATED AREAS TO GRASS-DOMINATED AREAS) AND QUANTIFY THE CHANGES IN CARBON STORAGE THAT HAVE ACCOMPANIED THESE TRANSFORMATIONS. STAKEHOLDERS AND RESEARCHERS WILL GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF WHAT ECOSYSTEM TRANSFORMATION IS, AS WELL AS THE CARBON CONSEQUENCES OF AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO ADDRESS ECOSYSTEM TRANSFORMATION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TO HELP NC STAKEHOLDERS BETTER INTEGRATE CARBON STORAGE ALONGSIDE OTHER MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES, THE RECIPIENT WILL USE AN INTEGRATED FRAMEWORK WITH REMOTE SENSING AND STAKEHOLDER INFORMATION ON TRANSFORMATION LOCATIONS TO IDENTIFY AREAS THAT HAVE EXPERIENCEDTRANSFORMATION OR ARE VULNERABLE TO FUTURE TRANSFORMATION ACROSS THE NC REGION AND WILL ALSO QUANTIFY THE CURRENT CARBON STORAGE AND CHANGES IN CARBON STORAGE ASSOCIATED WITH ECOSYSTEM TRANSFORMATIONS INVOLVING GRASS INVASION AND OR WILDFIRE WITH REMOTE SENSING AND MACHINE LEARNING APPROACHES. THIS WORK WILL BE GUIDED BY COLLABORATION WITH STAKEHOLDERS IN THE NC RISCC NETWORK THROUGH A SERIES OF THREE INTERACTIVE WORKSHOPS WHICH WILL FACILITATE INFORMATION EXCHANGE AMONG PRACTITIONERS, AS WELL AS INFORM THE PROJECTS ANALYSIS. IN THE CULMINATION OF THESE WORKSHOPS, THE RECIPIENT WILL COLLECTIVELY EXPLORE WHICH MANAGEMENT PRACTICES LEAD TO DESIRED CO-BENEFITS (E.G., HIGHER CARBON STORAGE, NATIVE PLANT BIODIVERSITY, AND ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE) OR ENTAIL TRADEOFFS AMONG MANAGEMENT GOALS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PRODUCTS FROM THIS WORK WILL INCLUDE WORKSHOP INFOGRAPHICS, WRITTEN SUMMARIES WITH MAPS FOR A MANAGEMENT AUDIENCE ON ECOSYSTEM TRANSFORMATION (CURRENT AND FUTURE) AND CARBON STORAGE, A WORKSHOP REPORT THAT WILL BE JOINTLY WRITTEN BY WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS, AND PUBLICATIONS IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THIS WORK CAN BE USED TO ADAPT MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT MAY BE AGENCY ORGANIZATION SPECIFIC INCLUDING CARBON STORAGE, NATIVE PLANT DIVERSITY, AND ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE, TO BETTER ALIGN ASPIRATIONS WITH ACTION. THIS RESEARCH AND STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT WORK IS CRITICAL TO ADDRESS THE INTERACTIONS OF CLIMATE CHANGE WITH BOTH INVASIVE GRASSES AND WILDFIRE, AS WELL AS IDENTIFY ADAPTATION STRATEGIES TO RESTORE CARBON IN FORESTS AND SHRUBLANDS ACROSS THE NC REGION AFTER THESE DISTURBANCES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: SYNTHESIZING RESPONSES AND VULNERABILITIES OF PRIORITY AQUATIC INVERTEBRATES TO PRECIPITATION EXTREMES ACROSS THE MIDWESTPROJECT DATES: 1 16 2024 THROUGH 1 15 2026AWARD PURPOSE:  THE MIDWEST UNITED STATES IS FACING WETTER WINTERS AND SPRINGS AND MORE VARIABLE SUMMER AND FALL PRECIPITATION. HEAVY FLOODING AND PROLONGED DROUGHTS ARE COSTLYTO AGRICULTURE, HOUSING, TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE, AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES ACROSS THEREGION. THESE EXTREMES HAVE ALSO STRESSED THE HEALTH OF FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS AND ORGANISMSIMPORTANT TO OUR REGIONAL ECONOMY AND QUALITY OF LIFE. FRESHWATER INVERTEBRATES LIKE MUSSELS,CRAYFISH, AND AQUATIC INSECTS ARE GENERALLY ON THE DECLINE AND ARE STRONG INDICATORS OF FRESHWATERHEALTH. LOSING THESE ANIMALS WOULD LIMIT BENEFITS SUCH AS WATER PURIFICATION, FOOD FOR WILDLIFE,AND AESTHETIC VALUES.HOW ARE FRESHWATER INVERTEBRATES RESPONDING, AND HOW WILL THEY RESPOND, TO INTENSIFYINGAND INCREASINGLY VARIABLE PRECIPITATION EXTREMES ACROSS THE MIDWEST  SOME OF THE ANSWER RESIDESWITH PEOPLE KNOWLEDGEABLE AND CONCERNED ABOUT THESE ANIMALS. OTHER INFORMATION IS CONTAINEDWITHIN BASIC DATA ON WHERE SPECIES OCCUR AND THE CHARACTERISTICS THEY POSSESS. THE GOAL OF THISPROJECT IS TO SYNTHESIZE THESE STRANDS OF INFORMATION INTO A MORE COHESIVE PICTURE OF FRESHWATERINVERTEBRATES AND CLIMATE AT THE EXTREMES. THIS IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING WILL HELP SCIENTISTS,MANAGERS, AND COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS ASSESS THE QUALITY OF FRESHWATER RESOURCES AND BETTERPROTECT THESE ANIMALS AND THEIR CRITICAL SERVICES TO NATURE AND PEOPLE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:1. UNDERSTAND RELEVANT KNOWLEDGE, EXPERIENCES, PERCEPTIONS, AND OPINIONS OF INVERTEBRATEEXPERTS AND NON-EXPERTS2. LINK SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS TO REGIONAL EXTREME PRECIPITATION (DROUGHT AND FLOODING) TRENDSAND PROJECTIONS3. ASSESS SPECIES VULNERABILITY TO CLIMATE EXTREMES USING TRAIT-BASED INFERENCES AND THECLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX4. IDENTIFY CANDIDATE BIOINDICATORS OF PRECIPITATION EXTREMES FOR FUTURE STUDY AND POTENTIALINTEGRATION WITH CLIMATE EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS AND FRESHWATER BIOMONITORING PROGRAMSDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1. CONSOLIDATED OCCURRENCE AND TRAIT DATASETS FOR REGIONAL PRIORITY SPECIES2. MAPS OF ESTIMATED SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS AND DIVERSITY PATTERNS UNDER RECENT AND FUTUREPRECIPITATION EXTREMES3. SPECIES-SPECIFIC VULNERABILITY SCORES AND CROSS-TAXON VULNERABILITY GUILDS4. UPDATED THREAT ASSESSMENT QUESTIONNAIRES AND RESULTS FROM FORMER AND NEW RESPONDENTS5. EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS (FACT SHEETS) FOR VOLUNTEER FRESHWATER BIOMONITORING PROGRAMS6. CANDIDATE BIOINDICATORS OF PRECIPITATION EXTREMESINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES, CLIMATE EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS, VOLUNTEER WATER MONITORING PROGRAMS, FRESHWATER INVERTEBRATE BIOLOGISTS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA-CHAMPAIGN TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE: HOW PRAIRIE RESTORATION OUTCOMES ARE IMPACTED BY INTERACTIONS BETWEEN WINTER CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE TIMING OF DISTURBANCEPROJECT DATES: 6 12 2023 THROUGH 6 11 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT WILL DETERMINE IF MANAGEMENT DECISIONS CAN IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE OF PRAIRIERESTORATIONS UNDER ONGOING WINTER CLIMATE CHANGE.THE PRAIRIE GRASSLANDS OF THE MIDWEST AND GREAT PLAINS PROVIDE IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR A WIDEVARIETY OF PLANTS AND ANIMALS, CLEAN DRINKING WATER TO PEOPLE, AND SPACE FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION.HOWEVER,  99  OF PRAIRIES HAVE BEEN LOST. LAND MANAGERS ARE INTERESTED IN RESTORING PRAIRIES THATARE RESILIENT TO A SHIFTING CLIMATE. HOWEVER, DESPITE THE DESIRE TO ADAPT TO CLIMATE CHANGE, THECLIMATE IS CHANGING FASTER THAN KNOWLEDGE TRANSFER OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES CAN OCCUR,RESULTING IN A CRITICAL RESEARCH NEED. IN THE MIDWEST AND THROUGHOUT MUCH OF NORTH AMERICA, THEEFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ARE MORE PRONOUNCED AND RAPID IN WINTER THAN IN OTHER SEASONS. WINTERSARE, ON AVERAGE, HAVING LESS SNOW, RESULTING IN A HIGHER RISK OF PLANT TISSUE DAMAGE BY FREEZING ASTHEIR BLANKET OF SNOW INSULATION IS ABSENT. THIS CHANGE IN SNOW PATTERNS INTERSECTS WITH HOW LANDMANAGERS USE THE MANAGEMENT TOOLS OF PRESCRIBED FIRE AND MOWING THAT HELP MAINTAIN THE OPENSTRUCTURE OF GRASSLANDS AND PRAIRIES, WHICH MAY AFFECT HOW RESILIENT RESTORED PRAIRIE GRASSLANDSARE TO CLIMATE CHANGE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:IN THIS PROJECT, RESEARCHERS AND LAND MANAGERS HAVE DEVELOPED AN EXPERIMENT THAT APPLIESDIFFERENT DISTURBANCE MANAGEMENT TOOLS (MOWING, PRESCRIBED FIRE) AT DIFFERENT TIMES (SPRING, FALL)ACROSS SIMULATED FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS (BY MODIFYING THE AMOUNT OF SNOW COVER IN WINTER).BY MEASURING WHICH TYPES OF PLANTS GO LOCALLY EXTINCT AND HOW THE REMAINING PLANT POPULATIONSGROW OR SHRINK, THE RESEARCHERS WILL BE ABLE TO DETERMINE BOTH WHEN AND WHICH TOOLS MANAGERSSHOULD USE TO ENSURE THAT RESTORED PRAIRIES ARE MORE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE CHANGE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PROJECT FINDINGS WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO LAND MANAGERS, PROVIDING CRITICAL GUIDANCE FOR BUILDINGRESILIENT PRAIRIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND PEOPLE. FINDINGS WILL ALSO BE PUBLISHED INSCIENTIFIC JOURNALS TO CONTRIBUTE FINDINGS TO A BROADER KNOWLEDGE BASE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):RESULTS WILL BENEFIT LAND OWNERS AND MANAGERS WHO ARE RESTORING PRAIRIE GRASSLANDS AND WANT THEM TO BE RESILIENT TO A SHIFTING CLIMATE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN MADISON TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE: THE NORTHWEST REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE (NW RISCC) NETWORK: INCORPORATING CLIMATE CHANGE SCIENCE INTO INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENTPROJECT DATES: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE:CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO AFFECT THE SPREAD, ESTABLISHMENT, AND MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES, LEADING TO FURTHER DISRUPTIONS IN ECOSYSTEMS ACROSS THE U.S. THE NORTHWEST REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES   CLIMATE CHANGE (NW RISCC) NETWORK AIMS TO REDUCE THE COMPOUNDING EFFECTS OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE BY SYNTHESIZING RELEVANT SCIENCE, SHARING THE NEEDS AND KNOWLEDGE OF MANAGERS, BUILDING STRONGER SCIENTIST-MANAGER COMMUNITIES, AND CONDUCTING HIGH PRIORITY RESEARCH.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:AS A BRIDGING INITIATIVE, THE NW RISCC NETWORK AIMS TO IMPROVE THE IDENTIFICATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE NEEDS OF NATURAL-RESOURCE MANAGERS AND FACILITATE ENGAGEMENT WITH RESEARCHERS IN THE REGION THROUGH SYMPOSIA, WEBINARS, AND TRANSLATING EXISTING RESEARCH INTO ACTIONABLE OUTCOMES. ORIGINAL RESEARCH WILL UTILIZE THE TRANSLATIONAL INVASION ECOLOGY (TIE) FRAMEWORK (MORELLI ET AL 2021), WHICH INVOLVES IDENTIFYING PROBLEMS THROUGH DISCUSSIONS WITH STAKEHOLDERS, CONDUCTING RESEARCH COOPERATIVELY, PRODUCING MANAGER-FOCUSED MATERIALS, AND EVALUATING AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OUTCOMES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE SYMPOSIA AND WEBINARS THAT WILL FACILITATE KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE AMONG RESEARCHERS AND PRACTITIONERS. WRITTEN MATERIALS WILL INCLUDE FACT SHEETS, RESEARCH SUMMARIES, AND ORIGINAL RESEARCH BASED ON PRACTITIONER NEEDS. THESE RESOURCES WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO THE NETWORK THROUGH A LIST-SERV AND MADE AVAILABLE ON A WEBSITE. THE NW RISCC NETWORK WILL ALSO ORGANIZE A TEAM OF ADVISORS THAT INCLUDES RESEARCHERS AND PRACTITIONERS FROM ACROSS THE REGION TO HELP GUIDE NETWORK GOALS AND OBJECTIVES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE INVASIVE SPECIES BIOLOGISTS, CLIMATE SCIENTISTS, NATURAL-RESOURCE MANAGERS, POLICYMAKERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS FROM THE BROADER PUBLIC. NETWORK MEMBERS ARE AFFILIATED WITH LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, TRIBES, AND ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:N A

PROJECT TITLE: ALASKAS CHANGING HABITATS: A MULTI-SYSTEM APPROACH FOR UNDERSTANDING CLIMATE IMPACTS IN HIGH LATITUDE REGIONSPROJECT DATES: 05 01 2023 THROUGH 4 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE:THIS PROJECT WILL USE COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN ALASKA CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (AK CASC) STAFF AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS (UAF), STUDENT RESEARCHERS, AND USGS SCIENTISTS TO COLLECT DATA AND SHARE INFORMATION ABOUT ALASKAS ECOSYSTEMS. THIS PROJECT IS IMPORTANT AND VALUABLE BECAUSE IT WILL INCREASE OUR HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF ECOSYSTEM CHANGE IN ALASKA, THEREBY ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS AND RIGHTSHOLDERS ACROSS THE REGION. AS A PART OF THIS RESEARCH THE TEAM WILL CO-DEVELOP PUBLIC-FACING PRODUCTS AIMED AT PROVIDING A MORE COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS FOR APPLICATIONS IN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, PLANNING, AND DECISION MAKING. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND ADAPTATION, AS WELL AS THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF ALASKAN COMMUNITIES THAT DEPEND ON THESE ECOSYSTEMS FOR THEIR LIVELIHOOD AND CULTURAL VALUE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND CHANGE ON MULTIPLE HIGH-LATITUDE ECOSYSTEMS SIMULTANEOUSLY AND, IN TURN, GENERATE RESEARCH PRODUCTS THAT WILL PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS, RIGHTSHOLDERS, MANAGERS, AND DECISION MAKERS WITH A MORE COMPLETE, HOLISTIC VIEW OF HABITAT CHANGE WITHIN THE REGION. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ENGAGE IN A JOINT UAF AND USGS PARTNERSHIP TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA RELATED TO ECOSYSTEM STATUS AND TRENDS ACROSS A VARIETY OF HABITAT TYPES RANGING FROM THE NEARSHORE MARINE TO ARCTIC TUNDRA, INCLUDING THE STUDY OF SEABIRD AND FORAGE FISH, CARIBOU BEHAVIOR, SONGBIRD NESTING, AND NEARSHORE MARINE ECOLOGY. USGS SCIENTISTS WILL TAKE THE LEAD IN SUPERVISING DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS ACTIVITIES, WHILE THE PROJECT TEAM AT THE AK CASC AT UAF WILL LEAD THE DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF PRODUCTS FROM THE RESEARCH. UAF WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR MOVING RESEARCH EFFORTS FROM THE ANALYSIS STAGE TO THE GENERATION OF THE DESIRED RESEARCH PRODUCTS. THIS ARRANGEMENT IS THE BEST OPTION FOR ADDRESSING THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT BECAUSE EXTENSIVE USGS EXPERTISE IN FIELD LABORATORY DATA COLLECTION WILL BE LEVERAGED AGAINST UAFS CAPACITY FOR DELIVERING ACTIONABLE AND ACCESSIBLE RESEARCH.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1. DATASETS WILL BE GENERATED RELATED TO ALASKA ECOSYSTEMS, INCLUDING SEABIRD AND FORAGE FISH, CARIBOU BEHAVIOR, SONGBIRDS, OR NEARSHORE MARINE ECOLOGY.2. AT LEAST TWO COMPLETED RESEARCH PRODUCTS THAT COMMUNICATE SCIENCE FOR A SOCIETAL PARTNER WILL BE COLLABORATIVELY DEVELOPED BASED ON EVIDENCE-BASED PRINCIPLES FOR SCIENTIFIC COMMUNICATION, SUCH AS SCIENCE SUMMARIES FOR DECISION-MAKERS, FEATURE-STYLE WRITTEN ARTICLES, DIGITAL PRODUCTS LIKE STORY MAPS, OR PRINT BROCHURES OR POSTERS.3. A FINAL PAPER OR REPORT WILL SUMMARIZE FINDINGS OF THIS EFFORT.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND ADAPTATION, AS WELL AS THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF ALASKAN COMMUNITIES THAT DEPEND ON THESE ECOSYSTEMS FOR THEIR LIVELIHOOD AND CULTURAL VALUE. STAKEHOLDERS, RIGHTSHOLDERS, MANAGERS, AND DECISION MAKERS WILL BENEFIT BECAUSE THEY WILL BE PROVIDED WITH A MORE HOLISTIC, MULTI-FACETED VIEW OF CLIMATE-DRIVEN PROCESSES ACROSS THE REGION THAT THEY HAVE REQUESTED. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: COASTAL INDIGENOUS FISHERIES ASSESSMENT (CIFA) USING ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND ECOLOGICAL PERSPECTIVESPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2026AWARD PURPOSE: TO INTEGRATE ARCHAEOLOGICAL DATA WITH MODERN HARVEST AND ECOLOGICAL DATA ON AQUATIC RESOURCE UTILIZATION IN THE PROJECT AREA ALONG THE WESTERN EDGE OF THE ATCHAFALAYA BASIN. WITH THAT DATA, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP MODELS FOR UNDERSTANDING CHANGING FISHERY AND WATER BODY CONDITIONS, DEVELOP AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL ACTIONABLE SCIENCE SOLUTIONS FOR IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF THE PROJECT ECOSYSTEM, AND REFINE AND PROPOSE SOLUTIONS TO ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION THROUGH ITERATIVE COLLABORATION WITH THE CHITIMACHA TRIBE OF LOUISIANA, WHOSE HOMELAND IS IN THE PROJECT AREA. FURTHERMORE, THE TEAM WILL DEVELOP TRANSDISCIPLINARY ARCHAEOLOGICAL, ECOLOGICAL, AND CLIMATIC RESEARCH WITH CHITIMACHA TRIBAL PARTNERS THAT CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP A DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORK FOR FISHERY RESTORATION IN THE PROJECT AREA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: AN ARCHAEOLOGY TEAM WILL EXCAVATE DATA AND ANALYZE ARCHIVAL MATERIALS WHICH INFORM THE STUDY OF ANCIENT FISHERIES AND ECOSYSTEMS. THE PALEO-AND MODERN CLIMATE TEAM WILL IDENTIFY THE LONG-TERM CLIMATIC RECORD FOR THE REGION. PARTNER AGENCIES  LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES (LDWF) AND (LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (LDEQ)  WILL ASSIST IN LEGACY DATASET PROCUREMENT AND ANALYSIS. A MODERN FISHERIES TEAM WILL COLLECT NEW SPECIES AND ECOLOGICAL DATA TO DETAIL EXISTING FISHERY HABITAT CONDITIONS. NETWORK MODELLING, DATA INTEGRATION, AND DECISION SUPPORT ANALYSIS WILL BE CONDUCTED.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PROJECT DATA AND FINDINGS WILL BE COLLECTED WITH CHITIMACHA PARTNERS AND ALL OUTPUTS WILL BE SHARED WITH TRIBAL COLLABORATORS. NETWORK MODELS LINKING ANCIENT AND MODERN FISHERY CONDITIONS AND DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORKS FOR IMPROVING FISHERY CONDITIONS WILL BE DESIGNED, ITERATED, AND DEVELOPED WITH THE CHITIMACHA TRIBE OF LOUISIANA  ALL OF THESE DATA, MODELS, AND INTERPRETATIONS WILL BE AVAILABLE TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS. PROJECT METHODS WILL BE PUBLISHED TO SHARE TOOLS FOR PRODUCTIVE INDIGENOUS COLLABORATION FOR COLLABORATIVE, ACTIONABLE SCIENCE. PROJECT DATA WILL BE PUBLISHED IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. PROJECT INTERPRETATIONS AND BROADER IMPACTS WILL BE PUBLISHED IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS AND POPULAR SCIENCE OUTLETS (WEB-BASED AND PRINT) AND PRESENTED AT CONFERENCES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): WHILE THE DATA, METHODS, MODELS, AND DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS WILL BE BROADLY APPLICABLE TO A VARIETY OF SCIENTIFIC PRACTITIONERS AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES LOOKING TO BUILD COLLABORATIONS, AND WHILE PROJECT FINDINGS AND INTERPRETATIONS WILL BE PUBLISHED ACROSS VARIOUS ACADEMIC AND SCIENTIFIC OUTLETS, SPECIFIC PROJECT FINDINGS WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT THE CHITIMACHA TRIBE OF LOUISIANA. THIS PROJECT WAS CO-DESIGNED WITH INPUT FROM TRIBAL MEMBERS AND WILL RESULT IN A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT WILL ASSIST THE TRIBE IN WORKING TOWARDS THE RESTORATION OF THEIR WATER BODIES, FISHERIES, AND ECOSYSTEMS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT. THE LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY (LSU) HAS THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL SUBAWARD PARTNER(S) WHO WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY (FSU). FSU WILL CO-LEAD ALL ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATIONS AND DATA ANALYSIS FROM BOTH COLLECTED AND ARCHIVED CULTURAL MATERIALS, AS WELL AS GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF ANALYTICAL PROCEDURES FOR STUDYING ECOSYSTEM CHANGE OVER THE LONG TERM AND FOR INTERPRETING RESULTS FROM FIELDWORK AND LAB WORK.

PROJECT TITLE: IMPROVING SIMULATED FOREST FUELS TREATMENT PLACEMENT TO INFORM MANAGEMENT FOR EFFICIENTLY MITIGATING HIGH-SEVERITY WILDFIRE RISKPROJECT DATES: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE: THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO OPERATIONALIZE A MODELING APPROACH FOR OPTIMIZING THE PLACEMENT OF FOREST TREATMENTS TO IMPROVE FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANNING.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COLLECT FIELD DATA IN THE SANTA FE FIRESHED, PART OF THE RIO GRANDE WATERSHED, TO AUGMENT US FOREST SERVICE DATA FOR EVALUATING THE PROJECTS RESEARCH MODEL. THE DATA WILL BE USED BY THE PROJECT TEAM TO RE-ESTIMATE INITIAL VEGETATION LAYERS FOR USE IN THE LANDIS-II FOREST LANDSCAPE DISTURBANCE AND SUCCESSION MODEL TO QUANTIFY THE UNCERTAINTY IN RESULTS DUE TO THE INITIAL VEGETATION LAYER. QUANTIFYING THIS SOURCE OF UNCERTAINTY IS KEY TO OPERATIONALIZING THE MODEL OUTPUT BECAUSE INCREASED ACCURACY IN THE INITIAL VEGETATION LAYER WILL ALLOW FOREST MANAGERS TO USE MODEL OUTPUT TO GUIDE TREATMENT IMPLEMENTATION AT THE STAND-SCALE. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE THE NEW FIELD DATA TO DETERMINE THE NUMBER OF PLOTS NECESSARY TO REDUCE UNCERTAINTY TO THE POINT THAT MODEL OUTPUT CAN SUPPORT PLANNING. DETERMINING THE MINIMUM NUMBER OF PLOTS NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE ACTIONABLE MODEL OUTPUT WILL HELP DECREASE FUELS TREATMENT PLANNING COSTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS RESEARCH WILL ALLOW THE PROJECT TEAM TO DETERMINE THE FIELD SAMPLING INTENSITY NECESSARY TO REDUCE MODEL UNCERTAINTY SUFFICIENTLY TO OPERATIONALIZE TREATMENT PLACEMENT MODEL AND HELP QUANTIFY THE REMAINING UNCERTAINTY THAT IS DUE TO THE INITIAL VEGETATION LAYER. AN OPEN-SCIENCE APPROACH WILL BE USED. LANDIS-II IS AN OPEN-SOURCE COMMUNITY DEVELOPED MODEL AND ALL DATA AND CODE USED TO ANALYZE THESE DATA WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ON DRYAD (DATA) AND ZENODO (CODE). THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO WRITE ONE MANUSCRIPT FOR A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): RESOURCE MANAGERS AND THE PUBLIC. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PARTNER WITH THE US FOREST SERVICE FOR THIS PROJECT AND COLLABORATE TO ENSURE THE MODELING APPROACH WILL BE SUFFICIENT TO SUPPORT PLANNING EFFORTS WITHIN THE SANTA FE FIRESHED AND THAT THE MODELING APPROACH, INCLUDING SAMPLING INTENSITY, CAN BE IMPLEMENTED IN OTHER WATERSHEDS IDENTIFIED FOR FUELS TREATMENT WORK.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE  EXPANDING LESSONS FROM DATA RICH INLAND FISHERIES TO DATA LIMITED SCENARIOS FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATIONPROJECT DATES  8 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE  INLAND FISHERIES HAVE REMARKABLE CULTURAL, ECONOMIC, AND SUBSISTENCE VALUE. HOWEVER, CLIMATE CHANGE BRINGS NEW STRESSES TO LAND LOCKED FISHERIES THAT RAISE IMPORTANT CHALLENGES FOR RESOURCE MANAGERS. ONE KEY CHALLENGE IN INLAND FISHERIES IS HOW TO BEST ASSESS AND MANAGE DATA LIMITED FISHERIES WHEN RESOURCES ARE FINITE, AND UNCERTAINTY IS PERVASIVE. TO ADDRESS THIS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE AGE STRUCTURED SIMULATION MODELS TO EXAMINE WHETHER INDICATORS OF FISH POPULATION STATUS COMMONLY MEASURED BY MANAGERS CAN SERVE AS A SHORT CUT TO MORE DATA  AND CAPACITY INTENSIVE APPROACHES. FURTHER, THEY WILL WORK AND COMMUNICATE DIRECTLY WITH STATE AND TRIBAL FISHERIES MANAGERS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CHALLENGES FACED WHEN MAKING DIFFICULT CONSERVATION DECISIONS GIVEN CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE FINDINGS WILL BE SHARED AND DISCUSSED WITH FISHERIES MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS IN THE UPPER MIDWEST IN A FORMAL SUMMARY WORKSHOP. THROUGH THE COMBINATION OF MODELING EXERCISES AND MANAGEMENT DISCUSSIONS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ESTABLISH WHETHER THERE ARE METRICS THAT CAN BE USED BY MANAGERS TO GIVE THE BEST INFORMATION ABOUT FISH POPULATION STATUS, CHANGE, AND RESILIENCE GIVEN CLIMATE CHANGE. ACCURATELY QUANTIFYING INLAND FISHERIES STATUS AND DYNAMICS IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTANDING HOW THESE SYSTEMS CONTRIBUTE TO LOCAL AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES AND HOW THIS MAY BE IMPACTED BY GLOBAL CHANGE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE AGE STRUCTURED SIMULATION MODELING AND MEETINGS WITH MANAGERS AND RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS TO DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF COMMONLY USED ASSESSMENT METHODS AND APPROACHES USED IN INLAND FISHERIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A GENERIC AGE STRUCTURED FISHERIES MODEL AND WILL CONDUCT SYNTHESIS CONVERSATIONS WITH MANAGERS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL HOLD A SUMMARY WORKSHOP WITH MANAGERS AND PARTNERS TO SHARE RESULTS AND DISCUSS THE IMPLICATIONS FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AT THE END OF THE PROJECT. FROM THIS WORK, MULTIPLE SCIENTIFIC PAPERS WILL BE PUBLISHED. PROJECT PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND STUDENT RESEARCHERS WILL GIVE TALKS AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES. PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS WILL BE AMPLIFIED BY PRESS RELEASES, MEDIA OUTREACH, MANAGEMENT BRIEFS, BLOG POSTS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH THE USGS CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER COMMUNICATIONS TEAM TO AMPLIFY OUTREACH EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  KEY MANAGEMENT AGENCY PARTNERS ON THIS PROJECT ARE THE GREAT LAKESINDIAN FISH AND WILDLIFE COMMISSION (GLIFWC), MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES(MN DNR), AND WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WDNR). THE PROPOSED WORK ISCLOSELY LINKED TO MANAGEMENT AND WILL REQUIRE FREQUENT INTERACTIONS WITH AGENCY RESEARCHERS ANDMANAGERS, AND THEY REPRESENT KEY BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK. THERE ARE ALSO MANYSTAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING INDIVIDUAL FISHERIES MANAGERS, FEDERAL SCIENTISTS, TRIBAL NATIONS, ANGLINGGROUPS, AND LAKE ASSOCIATIONS THAT WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS RESEARCH GIVEN THE BROAD EXTENT OFWALLEYE FISHERIES ACROSS THE UPPER MIDWEST.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  ADVANCING STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE CLIMATE ADAPTATION THROUGH STATE AGENCY AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (CASC) COORDINATIONPROJECT DATES  5 17 2023 THROUGH 5 16 2026AWARD PURPOSE  FISH AND WILDLIFE PROVIDE MANY IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM AND CULTURAL SERVICES THAT SUPPORT PEOPLE, COMMUNITIES, AND ECONOMIES ACROSS THE NATION. MANY OBSERVED CHANGES IN THE GLOBAL CLIMATE ARE ALREADY IMPACTING THE NATIONS VALUABLE NATURAL RESOURCES. THESE IMPACTS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE WITH CONTINUED CHANGES IN THE CLIMATE SYSTEM, PUTTING OUR NATIONS FISH AND WILDLIFE AT RISK. STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES ARE AT THE FOREFRONT OF ADDRESSING THESE RISKS BUT WOULD GREATLY BENEFIT FROM LEVERAGING THE EXPERTISE AND RESOURCES OF THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (AFWA) AND FEDERAL PARTNERS. THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY AND MEET SPECIFIC NEEDS OF THE NATIONS STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES AS THEY ADDRESS CLIMATE IMPACTS ON NATURAL RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TO IDENTIFY WHAT ADAPTATION STRATEGIES ARE WORKING BEST AND WHAT GAPS IN KNOWLEDGE STILL REMAIN. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL 1) PROMOTE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGY TO INCREASE CLIMATE ADAPTATION IN FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT  2) IDENTIFY BARRIERS TO CLIMATE ADAPTION IDENTIFIED BY STATES AND THE SCIENCE NEEDED TO OVERCOME THOSE BARRIERS  3) COORDINATE WITH NATIONAL AND REGIONAL CASCS TO IDENTIFY SCIENCE NEEDS AND SHARE AND IMPLEMENT CASC SCIENCE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  EXPAND AND PROMOTE THE NATIONAL FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANTS CLIMATE ADAPTATION NETWORK.  UPDATE THE NATIONAL FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGY AND PROMOTE AND TRACK ITS IMPLEMENTATION.  CONDUCT SURVEY WITH STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES TO UNDERSTAND THEIR PERSPECTIVES AND CAPACITY FOR ADAPTATION, SCIENCE NEEDS AND GAPS, AND ON THE GROUND ADAPTATION EFFORTS.  CONNECT STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES WITH REGIONAL CASCS AND HOLD WORKSHOPS TO SHARE CASC SCIENCE AND RESEARCH PRODUCTS AND IDENTIFY EXISTING BARRIERS AND SCIENCE NEEDS OF STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES DELIVERABLES 1. REVISED NATIONAL FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGY 2. EXPANDED NATIONAL FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT CLIMATE ADAPTATION NETWORK 3. WEBINAR SERIES HIGHLIGHTING RESEARCH, DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS, CASE STUDIES OF IMPLEMENTATION. 4. 2024 STATE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SURVEY REPORT 5. NINE WORKSHOPS, SYMPOSIA, MEETINGS WITH REGIONAL CASCS AND STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES.OUTCOMES  1. USGS CASCS WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO UNDERSTAND AND ADDRESS THE NEEDS, PRIORITIES, AND KNOWLEDGE GAPS THAT REMAIN FOR STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES TO ADAPT TO CLIMATE CHANGE. 2. STATE AGENCY RESOURCE MANAGERS WILL INCREASE THEIR EFFECTIVENESS IN MEETING THE CHALLENGES OF SAFEGUARDING THE NATIONS FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES IN A CHANGING CLIMATE. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A VARIETY OF MUCH NEEDED PRODUCTS AND RESULTS THAT WILL BE USEFUL FOR BOTH CASCS AS WELL AS STATE AGENCIES AND OTHER ORGANIZATIONS IMPLEMENTING CLIMATE ADAPTATION.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES, NATIONAL FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT CLIMATE ADAPTATION NETWORK, AFWA CLIMATE ADAPTATION COMMITTEE, DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR USGS CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE PUBLICSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS ROADMAPPROJECT DATES  4 1 2023 THROUGH 3 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE  NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS PROVIDE BENEFITS TO BOTH NATURE AND PEOPLE, SIMULTANEOUSLY ADDRESSING THE ISSUES OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND BIODIVERSITY LOSS. THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR (DOI) MANAGES LARGE AREAS OF NATURAL AND WORKING LANDS IN THE UNITED STATES. THERE ARE BENEFITS TO IMPLEMENTING A NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS APPROACH TO MEET GREENHOUSE GAS REDUCTION TARGETS, EQUITABLY BUILD ECOSYSTEM AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, AND DELIVER ADDITIONAL CO BENEFITS FOR ECOSYSTEMS AND PEOPLE. HOWEVER, THERE IS A LACK OF CONSISTENT INFORMATION ON TECHNICAL APPROACHES, EXPECTED BENEFITS, FUNDING MECHANISMS, AND LIKELY BARRIERS AND SOLUTIONS FOR IMPLEMENTING NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE A ROADMAP DOCUMENT TO PROVIDE THIS INFORMATION FOR A VARIETY OF NATURE BASED SOLUTION STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED AS RELEVANT TO DOI. THE ROADMAP WILL BE USED TO EDUCATE RESOURCE MANAGERS AND PROMOTE IMPLEMENTATION OF NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS TO HELP INCREASE CARBON STORAGE, IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, AND PROTECT FEDERAL AND PUBLIC ASSETS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE ROADMAP WILL IDENTIFY FOR EACH NATURE BASED SOLUTION STRATEGY  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH  THE POTENTIAL MAGNITUDE OF BENEFITS AND TARGETED OUTCOMES  APPLICATIONS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE THREATS (INCLUDING EXTREME HEAT, COASTAL AND INLAND FLOODING, WILDFIRE RISK, AND DROUGHT)  ANTICIPATED BARRIERS AND SOLUTIONS FOR FIELD PRACTITIONERS  FUNDING MECHANISMS AND INNOVATIVE PARTNERING OPPORTUNITIES  RESEARCH, TOOL, AND TRAINING NEEDS  AND DEMONSTRATION OPPORTUNITIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   THE PRIMARY PRODUCT FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE A PDF ROADMAP DOCUMENT WITH GUIDANCE FOR IMPLEMENTING NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS STRATEGIES PRIORITIZED BY DOI. THIS PROJECT WILL FACILITATE UPTAKE OF NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS BY CREATING A ROADMAP TO IMPLEMENTATION FOR PRIORITY NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS STRATEGIES RELEVANT TO THE DEPARTMENTS LAND MANAGEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE CLIMATE INFORMED MANAGEMENT OF DOI LANDS AND THE ABILITY OF THOSE LANDS TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO A VARIETY OF STAKEHOLDERS WHO DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THEM.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  FEDERAL AGENCIES INCLUDING DOI, RESOURCE MANAGERS, RESEARCH COMMUNITY, AND THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL SUBAWARD TO DUKE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE  INCORPORATION OF SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION AND INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGES INTO NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PLANS  STATUS AND CHALLENGESPROJECT DATES  8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2026AWARD PURPOSE SOURCES OF CLIMATE INFORMATION CAN BE GROUPED IN TWO MAJOR CATEGORIES, SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION AND INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGES (ITEK). HOWEVER, THERE HAS BEEN LITTLE RESEARCH ABOUT WHAT CLIMATE INFORMATION IS ACTUALLY INCLUDED IN FEDERAL AND STATE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PLANS, OR THE COMBINED CHALLENGES PLANNERS FACE IN INCORPORATING BOTH TYPES OF INFORMATION IN THESE PLANS. THIS IS PARTICULARLY TRUE FOR ITEK. THIS RESEARCH WILL STUDY THE PLANS THEMSELVES, USING CONTENT ANALYSIS METHODS, AND THE PLANNERS  PERCEPTIONS OF CHALLENGES, THROUGH A SURVEY AND CASE STUDIES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE RESEARCH WILL USE CONTENT ANALYSIS OF PLANS, SURVEYS WITH CLOSED  AND OPEN ENDED QUESTIONS DISTRIBUTED TO PLANNERS, AND CASE STUDIES WITH MULTIPLE INTERVIEWS AND ETHNOGRAPHIC METHODS (ADDITIONAL DOCUMENT REVIEW, FIELD VISITS, PARTICIPANT OBSERVATION WHERE FEASIBLE). THE MAIN ACTIVITIES WILL BE 1. ASSESS THE INCLUSION OF CLIMATE INFORMATION   SCIENTIFIC AND INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGES (ITEK)   IN FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCY NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PLANNING PROCESSES AND DOCUMENTS  COMPARE ACROSS PLANS AND INFORMATION TYPES  AND CREATE BASELINE DATA FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE EVALUATION.2. ANALYZE THE CHALLENGES THAT PLANNERS PERCEIVE IN INCORPORATING CLIMATE INFORMATION   SCIENTIFIC AND ITEK   INTO FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCY NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PLANNING PROCESSES AND DOCUMENTS  COMPARE CHALLENGES ACROSS PLANS AND INFORMATION TYPES  AND RECOMMEND APPROACHES TO INCREASING THE USE OF BOTH TYPES OF CLIMATE INFORMATION IN PLANS, AS ACTIONABLE SCIENCE THAT SUPPORTS MANAGEMENT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE RESEARCH WILL PRODUCE A FINAL ASSESSMENT REPORT OF THE INCLUSION OF SCIENTIFIC AND ITEK CLIMATE INFORMATION AND ANALYSIS OF CHALLENGES TO ITS INCORPORATION INTO FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCY NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE PLANNING PROCESSES AND DOCUMENTS. THE REPORT WILL ALSO OFFER RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WILL SUPPORT THE INCLUSION OF CLIMATE INFORMATION ACROSS FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AND DEPARTMENTS, CONVEYED IN REPORTS, PUBLICATIONS, AND PRESENTATIONS, TO ULTIMATELY IMPROVE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) THE RECOMMENDATION REPORT PRODUCED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ACTIONABLE SCIENCE EFFORTS ACROSS THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (CASC) NETWORK, USGS, AND OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AND DEPARTMENTS, AS WELL AS BENEFIT THE RESEARCH AND SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITIES, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  CROSS REGIONAL RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIS IN RIDGE TO REEF AND ICEFIELD TO OCEAN ENVIRONMENTSPROJECT DATES  3 1 2023 THROUGH 2 28 2025AWARD PURPOSE STEEP, MOUNTAINOUS WATERSHEDS, DRAMATIC CLIMATE GRADIENTS, AND TIGHT LINKS BETWEEN THE LAND AND SEA ARE COMMON FEATURES OF BOTH THE PACIFIC ISLANDS AND SOUTHEAST ALASKA. CLIMATE CHANGE IS SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTING THE TERRESTRIAL, FRESHWATER, AND COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS THAT COMMUNITIES IN THESE TWO REGIONS RELY UPON FOR FOOD, WATER, RECREATION, AND TOURISM. FOR EXAMPLE, CHANGING WEATHER PATTERNS ARE LEADING TO MORE FREQUENT AND SEVERE EXTREME EVENTS SUCH AS STORMS, ATMOSPHERIC RIVERS, DROUGHTS, AND HEAT WAVES. RESOURCE MANAGERS NEED BETTER INFORMATION ON VARIABILITY AND LONG TERM TRENDS IN DROUGHT (AS IT RELATES TO WATER SUPPLIES, POWER GENERATION, AND FRESHWATER FISH MANAGEMENT)  FLOODING (AS IT RELATES TO INFRASTRUCTURE DESIGN)  OCEAN CHEMISTRY (AS IT RELATES TO HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS, AQUACULTURE, AND FISHERIES)  AND LAND COVER CHANGE (AS IT RELATES TO RUNOFF OF SEDIMENTS AND POLLUTANTS). ISLANDED COMMUNITIES IN BOTH REGIONS ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO DISRUPTIONS IN ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, AND PEOPLE IN ALASKA AND HAWAII ALSO TEND TO HAVE DEEP CULTURAL CONNECTIONS TO THE LANDSCAPE. THE ALASKA AND PACIFIC ISLANDS CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS HAVE DEVELOPED A SUITE OF COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EFFORTS BASED ON THE SHARED CHALLENGES OF PRODUCING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE SUITED TO EACH REGION S SPECIFIC ENVIRONMENTAL AND CULTURAL CONDITIONS. THIS PROJECT ENTAILS FURTHER COLLABORATION TO ENGAGE WITH COMMUNITIES AND SCIENTISTS TO FORMALIZE A CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK FOR CROSS REGIONAL, COMPARATIVE RESEARCH IN THESE LANDSCAPES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THIS PROJECT S ENGAGEMENT STRATEGY WILL INCLUDE MULTIPLE RESEARCHER AND COMMUNITY PARTNER WORKSHOPS IN BOTH ALASKA AND HAWAII TO DISCUSS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT CONCEPTUALIZATION AND PRIORITIZE SCIENCE NEEDS RELATED TO CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ADDRESS THE SCARCITY OF GOOD ENVIRONMENTAL DATA IN THESE REGIONS AS COMPARED WITH THE CONTIGUOUS US, THE HIGH COST AND DIFFICULTY ASSOCIATED WITH ACCESSING THESE RUGGED LANDSCAPES FOR RESEARCH, AND THE LIMITED EFFORTS TO INCORPORATE LOCAL, CULTURAL PERSPECTIVES AND KNOWLEDGE INTO THE RESEARCH PROCESS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO EXAMINE HOW BEST TO COMMUNICATE AND TRANSLATE RESULTS AND DISSEMINATE DATA AND OTHER INFORMATION, AND USE THIS TO ITERATIVELY DESIGN SHARING PLATFORMS AND OTHER DISSEMINATION MEDIA. THE PI WILL WORK WITH THE LEADERSHIP OF BOTH CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS TO IMPLEMENT A STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THIS COLLABORATION, AND WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR WORKING WITH PROJECT INVESTIGATORS AND PARTNERS TO ESTABLISH COMMON FIELD AND LAB METHODS ACROSS THE TWO REGIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE AT LEAST TWO PEER REVIEWED DATA SYNTHESIS AND REVIEW ARTICLES, ALONG WITH DATA AND INFORMATION DISSEMINATION PLATFORMS CATERED TO PARTNER NEEDS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THE LEARNING NETWORKS AND SCIENCE PRODUCTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT PARTNER COMMUNITIES IN BOTH REGIONS AS RESEARCHERS, MANAGERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS CAN SHARE EXPERIENCES, DATA GATHERING METHODS, ECOSYSTEM MODELS, AND BEST PRACTICES FOR ENGAGEMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  SUPPORTING CULTURAL RESOURCES AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL REGIONPROJECT DATES  2 15 2023 THROUGH 2 14 2026AWARD PURPOSE IT IS CRITICAL THAT THE SOUTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (CASC) BE DIRECTLY ENGAGED IN RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WITH THE FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBES ACROSS THE SOUTH CENTRAL U.S.IN MARCH 2022, THE SOUTH CENTRAL CASC HOSTED A WORKSHOP THAT HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR RESEARCHERS AND OTHER PARTNERS TO ADDRESS RESEARCH AND SCIENCE NEEDS AROUND CULTURAL RESOURCES AND CLIMATE CHANGE. IN THIS PROJECT, THE RESEARCH PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI) AND SUSTAINABILITY SCIENCE MANAGER WILL BUILD UPON THE RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS DERIVED FROM THE RESEARCH SYMPOSIUM ON CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT PLANT SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE AND HELP DISCOVER THE RELEVANT INFORMATION NEEDS OF THE REGION S TRIBES RELATED TO THIS TOPIC. THIS WORK WILL ADVANCE THE SCOPING QUESTIONS IDENTIFIED BY THE MARCH 2022 WORKSHOP ON CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT PLANT SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THROUGH THIS PROPOSED PROJECT THE SUSTAINABILITY SCIENCE MANAGER OF THE SOUTH CENTRAL CASC WILL EMPLOY SOCIAL SCIENCE METHODS TO IDENTIFY THE CENTRAL NEEDS OF TRIBAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROFESSIONALS IN THE REGION. FROM THE INFORMATION GATHERED, NOVEL RESEARCH QUESTIONS AND NEW SYNTHESIS EFFORTS WILL BE EXPANDED UPON. THE PI WILL WORK TO ADDRESS THESE CULTURAL RESOURCE RESEARCH NEEDS BY FACILITATING COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN ADDITIONAL RESEARCHERS AND THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY. THE PI WILL ALSO HELP FACILITATE RELEVANT CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THE SOUTH CENTRAL CASC RESEARCH PRIORITIES AND TRIBAL PRIORITIES. RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT WILL ALIGN WITH THE WHITE HOUSE GUIDANCE ON INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE (ITEK) AND OPPORTUNITIES TO COLLABORATE WITH THE REGION S DOI AGENCIES AND TRIBES. THE PI FOR THIS PROJECT HAS AN EXTENDED NETWORK OF CONNECTIONS TO TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, ENHANCING THE TRUST RELATIONSHIP WITH TRIBES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE PI WILL COMMUNICATE CASC RESEARCH RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT AND OTHERS TO NATIVE NATIONS ACROSS THE REGION AND WORK ONE ON ONE WITH TRIBES TO DEVELOP CONCRETE RESEARCH STRATEGIES FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION. THESE EFFORTS WILL RESULT IN NEW CASE STUDIES THAT HIGHLIGHT SUCCESSFUL ADAPTATION PRACTICES FOR CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.AN ADDITIONAL DELIVERABLE FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE REPORTS THAT HIGHLIGHT THE IDENTIFIED CLIMATE INFORMATION NEEDS OF THE TRIBES ACROSS THE REGION. IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE, HOWEVER, THAT TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY MEANS THAT EACH TRIBE CHOOSES HOW TO ADAPT OR RESPOND TO CLIMATE EXTREMES, AND THEY ARE REQUESTING THE DATA, MODELS, AND LATEST SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH TO MAKE THOSE DECISIONS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT TRIBAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROFESSIONALS ACROSS THE REGION THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF BRIEF CASE STUDIES. IT WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE SOUTH CENTRAL CASC AS THEY OBTAIN A CLEARER PICTURE OF THE TRIBE S CLIMATE INFORMATION NEEDS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  DEVELOPING A NEXT GENERATION CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX IN SUPPORT OF CLIMATE INFORMED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENTPROJECT DATES  3 1 2023 THROUGH 2 29 2026AWARD PURPOSE  CLIMATE CHANGE IS IMPACTING OUR NATION S PLANTS AND ANIMALS IN NUMEROUS WAYS. THE PEOPLE CHARGED WITH MANAGING PUBLIC LANDS NEED TO KNOW WHICH SPECIES ARE THREATENED BY CLIMATE CHANGE AND HOW THEY ARE THREATENED SO THEY CAN TAKE COUNTERMEASURES TO PREVENT DECLINES. BIOLOGISTS AT STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES PARTICULARLY NEED ESTIMATES OF SPECIES  VULNERABILITY TO CLIMATE CHANGE TO BE ABLE TO PRIORITIZE THEIR CONSERVATION WORK. IN THE PAST, NATURESERVE S MICROSOFT EXCEL BASED CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX HAS PROVEN TO BE A USEFUL METHOD FOR STATE BIOLOGISTS TO PERFORM CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS. SINCE THAT INDEX WAS RELEASED IN 2015, THERE HAVE BEEN NUMEROUS ADVANCES IN BOTH OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW CLIMATE AFFECTS WILDLIFE AND TECHNOLOGY FOR DEVELOPING USER FRIENDLY TOOLS. IN THISPROJECT, RESEARCHERS AND SOFTWARE PROGRAMMERS AT NATURESERVE WILL WORK IN COLLABORATION WITH USGS SCIENTISTS AND STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCY PARTNERS TO PERFORM RESEARCH THAT WILL LEAD TO A REVISED, SCIENTIFICALLY ROBUST VERSION OF THE CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX. THIS NEW VERSION WILL BE WEB BASED, ALLOWING COLLABORATION AMONG SCIENTISTS AND USERS, AND WILL FEATURE THE LATEST SCIENTIFIC PROJECTIONS OF FUTURE CLIMATE ACROSS THE COUNTRY. IN ADDITION, IT WILL FEATURE NEW METRICS THAT ASSESS HOW SPECIES CAN ADAPT TO OR COPE WITH CLIMATE CHANGE. BY THE END OF THE PROJECT, NATURESERVE WILL POST THIS FREE ONLINE TOOL FOR STATE BIOLOGISTS AND OTHER SCIENTISTS. THIS NEW VERSION OF THE CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX (CCVI) IS ESPECIALLY TIMELY, AS IT WILL BE RELEASED IN TIME FOR STATE BIOLOGISTS TO USE IT FOR REVISIONS TO THEIR STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS, WHICH ARE FEDERALLY MANDATED CONSERVATION PLANS THAT ARE DUE IN 2025.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  UPDATE CLIMATE EXPOSURE METRICS UPDATE SENSITIVITY AND ADAPTIVE CAPACITY ATTRIBUTES MODERNIZE AND IMPROVE ACCESS BY MOVING TOOL TO ONLINE FORMAT COLLABORATE WITH STATE PARTNERS TO ITERATIVELY RESEARCH CCVI USABILITY PILOT AND TEST ADDITIONAL CLIMATE EXPOSURE VARIABLES RESEARCH AND TEST USE OF CLIMATE SCENARIOS TO GUIDE EXPOSURE METRICS CONDUCT SENSITIVITY ANALYSESDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  PHASE 1  (1) ONLINE CCVI TOOL WITH SPECIFIC LEVELS OF FUNCTIONALITY  (2) DOCUMENTATION, INCLUDING TUTORIAL AND SUGGESTED WORKFLOW  (3) AT LEAST ONE WEBINAR DEMONSTRATING THE TOOL TO TARGETED USERS. PHASE 2  (1) REVISED ONLINE CCVI TOOL WITH ADDITIONAL FUNCTIONALITY FOR CLIMATE VARIABLES AND SCENARIOS  (2) SUBMITTED MANUSCRIPT DESCRIBING RESULTS OF SENSITIVITY ANALYSES  (3) WHITE PAPER OUTLINING NEXT STEPS AND NEEDS FOR FUTURE CCVI IMPROVEMENTS. IN YEAR 3, DRAFT OF A LONG TERM HOSTING AND MAINTENANCE PLAN.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE SCIENTISTS, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, STATE AGENCIES THAT ARE TASKED WITH REVISING STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS, AND THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A
