PROJECT TITLE  THE ROLE FOREST STRUCTURE PLAYS IN REGULATING WATER AVAILABILITY AND IMPLICATIONS FOR NATURAL RESOURCES AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONPROJECT DATES  3 1 2023 THROUGH 2 28 2026AWARD PURPOSE  CHANGES IN FOREST COVER FROM DISTURBANCE IMPACT HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS INCLUDING THE POTENTIAL FOR INCREASED RUNOFF THAT CAN LEAD TO DANGEROUS FLOODING, EROSION, AND WATER QUALITY ISSUES THAT CAN BE COSTLY FOR SOCIETY. IN RESPONSE, MANY LAND MANAGERS ARE USING FOREST THINNING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING TO REDUCE DISTURBANCE IMPACTS, ESPECIALLY FROM HIGH SEVERITY WILDFIRE. IN CONTRAST TO THE WEALTH OF RESEARCH ON THE ADVANTAGES OF FOREST THINNING FOR REDUCING HIGH SEVERITY FIRES AND THEIR IMMEDIATE IMPACTS, MUCH LESS IS KNOWN ABOUT THE LONG TERM IMPACTS OF THIS CHANGE IN FOREST STRUCTURE ON HYDROLOGIC AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION. THIS INCLUDES A LIMITED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW FOREST STRUCTURE ALTERS SNOW ACCUMULATION AND PERSISTENCE, AND HOW SNOW DYNAMICS FEEDBACK TO INFLUENCE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION. QUANTIFYING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN FOREST STRUCTURAL HETEROGENEITY AND SNOWPACK DEVELOPMENT AND PERSISTENCE IS KEY FOR DETERMINING THE POTENTIAL FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT TO INFLUENCE FUTURE FOREST ECOSYSTEMS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED 1. MONITORING AND  MODELING PREVIOUSLY BURNED AND MANAGED FORESTS IN THE VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE  2. ESTABLISH MONITORING OF UNDISTURBED FOREST PLOTS IN BANDED PEAK RANCH  3. AT THE END OF PHASE I, THIN PLOTS IN BANDED PEAK RANCH BASED ON INFORMATION GAINED FROM OBSERVATIONS IN THE VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE PROPOSED WORK WILL PRODUCE FURTHER UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES TO REDUCE WILDFIRE RISK ON FOREST FUNCTION. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL UTILIZE ROBUST FIELD DATA COLLECTION TO PROVIDE EMPIRICAL UNDERSTANDING THAT WILL ALSO BE USED TO CALIBRATE VALIDATE A FOREST LANDSCAPE DISTURBANCE AND SUCCESSION MODEL TO PROJECT THE FUTURE IMPACTS OF MITIGATION PRESCRIPTIONS IN THE FACE OF A WARMING CLIMATE. THESE RESULTS WILL PRODUCE PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLES (AN ESTIMATED 3 IN TOTAL) AND CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS DIRECTED TOWARD THE FOREST MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY TO DISSEMINATE THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED AS WIDELY AS POSSIBLE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT PLANNING (E.G., DESIRED STAND STRUCTURE PRESCRIPTIONS, FIRE MANAGEMENT PLANS) TO INTEGRATE FUELS MANAGEMENT WHILE OPTIMIZING HYDROLOGIC AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS. FORESTED WATERSHED MANAGEMENT VIA THINNING AND PLANNED MANAGED BURNING WILL BE THE NORM FOR MANY DECADES (AND CENTURIES) TO COME, AND DEVELOPING AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE RESTORATION ACTION IMPACTS ON WATERSHED HYDROLOGY AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION WILL BE CRITICAL IN CREATING LONG TERM STRATEGIES TO COPE WITH CLIMATE WARMING AND POTENTIAL REDISTRIBUTION OF SEASONAL PRECIPITATION.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT. THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HAS THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL SUBAWARD PARTNERS  UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING.

PROJECT TITLE  CRAFTING ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS TO IMPLEMENT THE RAD FRAMEWORKPROJECT DATES  3 1 2023 THROUGH 2 28 2025AWARD PURPOSE  AS CLIMATE CHANGE PROGRESSES, PROFOUND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES ARE BECOMING A WIDESPREAD CONCERN. A NEW MANAGEMENT PARADIGM IS DEVELOPING TO ADDRESS THIS CONCERN WITH A FRAMEWORK THAT ENCOURAGES STRATEGIC DECISIONS TO RESIST, ACCEPT, OR DIRECT ECOLOGICAL TRAJECTORIES. EFFECTIVE USE OF THE RESIST ACCEPT DIRECT (RAD) FRAMEWORK REQUIRES THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY TO DESCRIBE THE RANGE OF PLAUSIBLE ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS MANAGERS MIGHT FACE, WHILE RECOGNIZING LIMITS TO OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT PRECISELY WHERE OR HOW SPECIFIC CLIMATIC CHANGES MAY UNFOLD OR HOW COMPLEX ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS WILL RESPOND   THE CLIMATIC FUTURE DOES NOT FULLY DETERMINE THE ECOLOGICAL ONE. RECENT ADVANCES HAVE IMPROVED DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF CLIMATE FUTURES (SUMMARIES OF CLIMATE CONDITIONS FOR EACH CLIMATE MODEL PROJECTION), BUT APPROACHES FOR CREATING AND WORKING WITH A RANGE OF ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS FOR EACH CLIMATE FUTURE DO NOT YET EXIST.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP POTENTIAL APPROACHES FOR CRAFTING ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS, I.E., STORYLINES DESIGNED TO CAPTURE THE RANGE OF PLAUSIBLE ECOLOGICAL RESPONSES TO CLIMATE CHANGE. IT WILL SYNTHESIZE AND COMPARE TYPICAL APPROACHES FOR ESTIMATING ECOLOGICAL RESPONSES TO CLIMATE CHANGE, CONSIDER EXTENSIONS THAT ALLOW FOR MULTIPLE ECOLOGICAL COMMUNITY OR BIOME TYPES UNDER EACH CLIMATIC SCENARIO, AND DEVELOP APPROACHES FOR  WINNOWING  A LARGE SET OF PLAUSIBLE ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS INTO A WORKABLE, REPRESENTATIVE SET.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  EXPECTED PRODUCTS INCLUDE PUBLICATIONS THAT DETAIL AN ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS WORKFLOW AND OUTLINES RECOMMENDED PRACTICES FOR ENSURING ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS ARE USEFUL IN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANNING AND DECISION MAKING, AND ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS FOR A TBD CASE STUDY IN THE NORTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER REGION. THE PROJECT TEAM MAY ALSO CREATE TRAINING MATERIALS FOR SCIENTISTS IN HOW TO DEVELOP ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS, WHICH IS ESSENTIAL TO OPERATIONALIZE THE RAD FRAMEWORK.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  RESOURCE MANAGERS, SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, AND THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE   CLIMATE SMART  FISHERIES AND AQUACULTURE TO SUPPORT RESILIENT AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS IN VIETNAMPROJECT DATES  1 15 2023 THROUGH 7 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE  HOME TO THE MEKONG RIVER DELTA, VIETNAM IS ONE OF THE MOST VULNERABLE COUNTRIES TO CLIMATE CHANGE. IF SEA LEVELS RISES BY 100 CENTIMETERS, NEARLY 40 PERCENT OF THE MEKONG RIVER DELTA WILL BE INUNDATED AND 10 PERCENT OF THE DELTA POPULATION WILL BE AFFECTED BY LAND LOSS AND REDUCTION IN CULTIVATION AREA FOR RICE. THE GOVERNMENT OF VIETNAM HAS INDICATED A MOVE AWAY FROM INTENSIVE RICE FARMING AND TOWARDS AQUACULTURE, WHICH COULD CAPITALIZE ON THE BRACKISH WATER AND SALINE INTRUSION PRESENT IN THE MEKONG DELTA. HOWEVER, NOT ALL AQUACULTURE PRACTICES ARE SUSTAINABLE. SOME PRACTICES CAN CONTRIBUTE TO GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSION WHILE OTHERS MAY PLAY THE ROLE IN SEQUESTERING CARBON. THERE IS AN IMMEDIATE NEED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW  CLIMATE SMART  FISHERIES AND AQUACULTURE CAN IMPROVE ADAPTIVE CAPACITY AND ENHANCE RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, ESPECIALLY IN VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES OF VIETNAM. THIS PROJECT BUILDS ON MANAGEMENT RELEVANT RESEARCH PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED IN A COMPLETED CLIMATE EMBASSY FELLOWSHIP COLLABORATION WITH THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE AND WILL SYNTHESIZE THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE ON 1) ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT FISH SPECIES THAT ARE AFFECTED BY CLIMATE CHANGE IN VIETNAM AND 2) AQUACULTURE TECHNOLOGIES THAT REDUCE ENERGY CONSUMPTION AND OPTIMIZE THE POTENTIAL FOR CARBON SEQUESTRATION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  A SYSTEMATIC LITERATURE REVIEW PROTOCOL IS APPLIED IN THIS PROJECT TO SEARCH, REVIEW, AND DESCRIBE AVAILABLE INFORMATION ON CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS ON INLAND FISH AND FISHERIES IN THE MEKONG DELTA, VIETNAM AND CLIMATE SMART SOLUTIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW  CLIMATE SMART  FISHERIES AND AQUACULTURE CAN IMPROVE ADAPTIVE CAPACITY AND ENHANCE RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. DEVELOP AN INFOGRAPHIC IN VIETNAMESE AND ENGLISH HIGHLIGHTING  CLIMATE SMART  FISHERIES AND AQUACULTURE PRACTICES. DEVELOP A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION DETAILING THE KNOWNS AND INFORMATION GAPS ON  CLIMATE SMART  FISHERIES AND AQUACULTURE PRACTICES WITH A FOCUS ON VIETNAM.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  RESOURCE MANAGERS, RESEARCHERS, INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND RELATIONS COMMUNITY, VIETNAMESE STAKEHOLDERS SUCH AS LOCAL FARMERS AND RESOURCES MANAGERS, AND THE MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  LEVERAGING A STATEWIDE DATABASE TO FOSTER BETTER COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION OF WATER TEMPERATURE MONITORING EFFORTS ACROSS ALASKAPROJECT DATES  1 1 2023   12 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE  THIS PROJECT WILL UTILIZE A NEW DATABASE FOR THE STATE OF ALASKA (AKTEMP) TO IMPROVE WATER TEMPERATURE DATA COLLECTION AND DISSEMINATION BY FACILITATING COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION BETWEEN PROJECT PARTNERS THROUGH AN IN PERSON WORKSHOP AND THE CREATION OF REGIONAL MONITORING NETWORKS IN INTERIOR ALASKA, ORGANIZING A STATEWIDE WATER TEMPERATURE WORKSHOP TO DEVELOP A NEW 10 YEAR ACTION PLAN, AND CREATING NEW DATA VISUALIZATION AND ANALYSIS TOOLS DESIGNED TO MAKE WATER TEMPERATURE DATASETS ACROSS THE STATE MORE ACCESSIBLE AND USEFUL FOR MODELING, RESEARCH, AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE FIRST PROJECT OBJECTIVE SEEKS TO INCREASE DATA COLLECTION CAPACITY AND ACTIVITY THROUGH A STREAM TEMPERATURE TRAINING WITH THE GOAL OF CREATING NEW REGIONAL MONITORING NETWORKS IN INTERIOR ALASKA. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO PARTICIPANTS REGARDING MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF FRESHWATER RESOURCES IN THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THE MONITORING NETWORK ORGANIZATIONAL FRAMEWORK USED IN SEVERAL EXISTING REGIONS WILL BE ADAPTED TO INTERIOR ALASKA BY CONDUCTING AN IN PERSON TRAINING AND ENCOURAGING DATA COLLECTORS TO ORGANIZE THEIR EFFORTS AS PART OF NEW REGIONAL NETWORKS. THE SECOND OBJECTIVE FOCUSES ON WATER TEMPERATURE RELATED RESEARCH, THROUGH A WATER TEMPERATURE WORKSHOP TO ENGAGE FRESHWATER SCIENTISTS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS ON PRIORITY MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH APPLICATIONS THAT CAN BE GENERATED FROM WATER TEMPERATURE DATA AGGREGATED IN THE AKTEMP DATABASE. ANOTHER WORKSHOP PRODUCT WILL BE A SET OF PRIORITY GOALS AND ACTIONS THAT CAN BE TAKEN TO MEET THOSE GOALS OVER THE NEXT 10 YEARS. FOR THE THIRD PROJECT OBJECTIVE, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP WEB BASED DATA VISUALIZATION AND DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS LINKED TO THE AKTEMP DATABASE. WHEN CO PRODUCED IN COLLABORATION WITH END USERS, DATA VISUALIZATION AND ANALYSIS TOOLS TIED TO A CENTRAL, CROWDSOURCED DATABASE CAN MAKE RAW DATA MORE ACCESSIBLE AND INCENTIVIZE DATA COLLECTORS TO CONTINUE CONTRIBUTING DATA, WHICH IMPROVES REGIONAL MODEL PERFORMANCE AND DECISION MAKING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE COOPERATION AND COORDINATION AMONG DATA COLLECTORS IN INTERIOR ALASKA AND SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS AT THE STATEWIDE LEVEL THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN THE WORKSHOP. ACTIONABLE SCIENCE OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE CREATION OF REGIONAL WATER TEMPERATURE MONITORING NETWORKS FOR INTERIOR ALASKA, AN UPDATED TEN YEAR WATER TEMPERATURE ACTION PLAN FOR ALASKA, AND DATA VISUALIZATION AND DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS BUILT UPON THE NEW STATEWIDE WATER TEMPERATURE DATABASE (ATKEMP) THAT CAN BE USED BY RESEARCHERS, MANAGERS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO SUPPORT MODELING, INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, AND MAKE MONITORING DATA MORE WIDELY ACCESSIBLE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT DATA COLLECTORS IN INTERIOR ALASKA, SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS AT THE STATEWIDE LEVEL, AND THE PUBLIC. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA WILL SUBAWARD TO COOK INLETKEEPER TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE PROJECT DATA COLLECTION AND GOALS BY LEADING THE STREAM TEMPERATURE OUTREACH TRAINING, HELPING COORDINATE AND FACILITATE THE WORKSHOP, AND WRITING A STATEWIDE WATER TEMPERATURE ACTION PLAN IN COLLABORATION WITH PROJECT TEAM MEMBERS. THEY WILL ALSO DEVELOP AND DESIGN TOOLS FOR THE AKTEMP DATABASE BASED ON STAKEHOLDER INPUT RECEIVED AT THE STREAM TEMPERATURE WORKSHOP.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYPROJECT TITLE  FUTURE OF THE COLORADO RIVER PHASE 2  INTEGRATED OPERATION OF THE POWELL GRAND CANYON MEAD SEGMENT FOR WATER SUPPLY, HYDROPOWER, AND RIVER ECOSYSTEMSPROJECT DATES  1 15 2023 THROUGH 1 14 2024AWARD PURPOSE BASIN WIDE WATER SUPPLY DECISIONS CONCERNING WHERE AND HOW MUCH CONSUMPTIVE WATER USE OCCURS UPSTREAM FROM LAKE POWELL OR DOWNSTREAM FROM LAKE MEAD WILL INEVITABLY AFFECT THE FLOW REGIME OF THE GRAND CANYON ECOSYSTEM. PRESENTLY, THE MUCH LARGER MAGNITUDE OF USES DOWNSTREAM FROM LAKE MEAD GUARANTEES THAT A RELATIVELY LARGE AMOUNT OF WATER FLOWS THROUGH THE GRAND CANYON ECOSYSTEM, BUT THAT SITUATION MIGHT NOT PERSIST AS WATER USERS CONSIDER REALLOCATING WATER USES THROUGHOUT THE BASIN TO SUSTAINABLY MANAGE THE REDUCED NATURAL STREAM FLOW OF THE 21ST CENTURY. DECISIONS CONCERNING RESERVOIR OPERATIONS AT LAKE MEAD AND LAKE POWELL WILL ALSO AFFECT THE GRAND CANYON ECOSYSTEM.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED, DELIVERABLES, AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THIS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE HOW MAJOR CHANGES IN LARGE SCALE CONSUMPTIVE WATER USE AND RESERVOIR OPERATIONS WILL IMPACT THE GRAND CANYON ECOSYSTEM. BECAUSE THERE ARE AN INFINITE NUMBER OF ALTERNATIVE STRATEGIES FOR ALLOCATING CONSUMPTIVE WATER USE AMONG THE SEVEN BASIN STATES AND MEXICO AND TO REOPERATE THE RESERVOIRS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INVERT THE CONSUMPTIVE USE RESERVOIR OPERATIONS ECOSYSTEM PROBLEM AND ASK,  HOW MIGHT DESIRED ECOSYSTEM OUTCOMES IN THE GRAND CANYON BE ACHIEVED BY CHANGES IN REGIONAL CONSUMPTIVE USE AND RESERVOIR OPERATIONS   IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY THE SENSITIVITY OF ECOSYSTEM OUTCOMES TO DIFFERENCES IN WATER MANAGEMENT POLICY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY TWO END MEMBER ECOSYSTEM GOALS FOR GRAND CANYON AND DETERMINE THE DIFFERENCES IN POLICY NEEDED TO ACHIEVE EITHER GOAL. ONE GOAL IS TO MAINTAIN THE EXISTING HIGH QUALITY NATIVE FISH COMMUNITY OF GRAND CANYON. THE OTHER POTENTIAL ECOSYSTEM GOAL IS TO RECREATE A RELATIVELY NATURAL RIVER FLOW REGIME WHERE ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT IS MORE FOCUSED ON REHABILITATION OF THE NATIVE GEOMORPHIC AND RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEM AND LESS FOCUSED ON NATIVE FISH. THE OVERALL RESEARCH GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENCOURAGE WIDE RANGING CONVERSATION AND DEBATE ABOUT HOW COLORADO RIVER MANAGEMENT COULD BE FUNDAMENTALLY IMPROVED UNDER CONDITIONS OF PERSISTENT WATERSHED ARIDIFICATION. MOST OF THE PROPOSED WORK WILL INVOLVE WATER RESOURCE MODELING USING THE COLORADO RIVER SIMULATION SYSTEM (CRSS) TO EXAMINE IMPACTS OF DIFFERENT WATER MANAGEMENT POLICY. RESEARCHERS WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF EXISTING MODELS THAT PREDICT RESERVOIR RELEASE TEMPERATURE, RIVER TEMPERATURE, AND FISH OUTCOMES, AND WILL UTILIZE OTHER MODELS TO PREDICT GEOMORPHIC AND RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEM OUTCOMES. THE RESEARCH PROPOSED HERE CONSIDERS FUTURE WATERSHED RUNOFF (I.E. SUPPLY) TO BE AN EXOGENOUS FACTOR WHICH WILL BE DETERMINED BY GLOBAL ATMOSPHERIC CARBON EMISSIONS, FUTURE CLIMATE CHANGE TRAJECTORIES, AND EMERGING UNDERSTANDING OF THE LINKAGES AMONG A WARMING ATMOSPHERE, PRECIPITATION, AND RUNOFF EFFICIENCY.THE RESEARCH WORKFLOW WILL BEGIN BY CONSIDERING EXISTING PATTERNS OF CONSUMPTIVE WATER USE AND WILL EXAMINE THE IMPLICATIONS OF DIFFERENT MAGNITUDES OF WATER USE REDUCTION IN THE UPPER AND LOWER BASIN THAT YIELD SUSTAINABLE WATER SUPPLIES. THE EXTERNAL FACTORS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ARE DEEPLY UNCERTAIN, AND THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP SCENARIOS WITH A WIDE RANGE OF WATERSHED HYDROLOGY AND WATER USE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) WATER AND RESOURCE MANAGERS, SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH COMMUNITIES, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYPROJECT TITLE  INFORMING DECISIONS TO RESIST, ACCEPT, OR DIRECT POST FIRE VEGETATION TRANSITIONSPROJECT DATES  12 15 2022 THROUGH 12 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE  CHANGING FIRE REGIMES AND WARMER, DRIER CONDITIONS ARE INCREASING THE LIKELIHOOD OF POST FIRE VEGETATION TRANSITIONS IN THE WESTERN US, FOR EXAMPLE, FROM FOREST TO GRASSLAND. AS RAPID ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES OCCUR, MANAGEMENT AIMED AT MAINTAINING HISTORICAL CONDITIONS WILL BECOME INCREASINGLY UNTENABLE, REQUIRING MANAGERS TO MAKE DECISIONS THAT STEWARD VEGETATION TOWARD DESIRED OR NOVEL CONDITIONS. THE RESIST ACCEPT DIRECT (RAD) FRAMEWORK PROVIDES GUIDANCE FOR MAKING THESE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BUT REQUIRES AN UNDERSTANDING OF POTENTIAL FUTURE CONDITIONS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY PLAUSIBLE FUTURE ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS OF VEGETATION CHANGE AND FIRE REGIMES AT MANAGEMENT RELEVANT SCALES TO HELP MANAGERS UNDERSTAND WHERE RESISTING, ACCEPTING, OR DIRECTING POST FIRE VEGETATION CHANGE MAY BE MOST SUCCESSFUL.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE RAD FRAMEWORK PROVIDES GUIDANCE FOR MAKING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN AN ERA OF RAPID ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE, BUT KEY SCIENCE GAPS CURRENTLY LIMIT APPLICATION OF THE RAD FRAMEWORK TO MANAGING POST FIRE ENVIRONMENTS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO ADDRESS THESE KEY NEEDS BY IDENTIFYING PLAUSIBLE FUTURE ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS OF VEGETATION CHANGE AND FIRE REGIMES AT MANAGEMENT RELEVANT SCALES, AND BY IDENTIFYING WHERE THE DIFFERENT RAD STRATEGIES MAY BE MOST SUCCESSFUL. UTILIZING A CAREFULLY DEVELOPED METHOD BASED ON CLIMATE ANALOGS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY THE POTENTIAL RANGE OF VARIABILITY IN CURRENT AND FUTURE BIOPHYSICAL CONDITIONS  COMPARISONS BETWEEN THESE RANGES WILL HIGHLIGHT AREAS MOST VULNERABLE TO VEGETATION TRANSITIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THIS PROJECT ENGAGES PARTNERS FROM MULTIPLE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES AND WILL INTEGRATE THEIR FEEDBACK THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT TO ENSURE THAT PRODUCTS ARE DIRECTLY APPLICABLE TO DECISION MAKING PROCESSES. THE MAIN PRODUCT OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE BASED ON A SUITE OF GENERATED SPATIAL DATASETS CONVEYING THE RANGE OF CURRENT AND FUTURE VARIABILITY FOR VEGETATION AND FIRE REGIMES FOR THE NORTHWEST AND NORTH CENTRAL REGIONS. THE FORMAT OF THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE ADAPTED BASED ON FEEDBACK FROM PARTNERS BUT COULD INCLUDE DATASETS AVAILABLE ON AN EXISTING WEBSITE, A STANDALONE WEB APPLICATION TO VISUALIZE THE DATA, AND OR WRITTEN BRIEFS FOR MANAGEMENT UNITS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDE PLANNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDS, ECOLOGISTS, AND SILVICULTURISTS WHO NEED TO INTEGRATE FUTURE BIOPHYSICAL CONDITIONS INTO PLANNING OR PRE  AND POST FIRE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE PARTNERS AND COOPERATORS FROM THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS), BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM), WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WA DNR), THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC), AND THE US FOREST SERVICE (USFS).SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT. THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA HAS THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL SUBAWARD PARTNER(S) WHO WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  CONSERVATION SCIENCE PARTNERS.

PROJECT TITLE  CO CREATING AN INTEGRATED CLIMATE IMPACT ASSESSMENT OF FIRST FOODS AND MEDICINE IN THE LITTLE ROCKY MOUNTAINS FOR THE AANIIIHNEN NAKODA NATIONSPROJECT DATES  12 1 2022 THROUGH 11 30 2025PROJECT PURPOSE AND BENEFICIARIES  AS CLIMATE CHANGE LOOMS LARGE, THE AANIIIHNEN AND NAKODA PEOPLE OF THE FORT BELKNAP INDIAN COMMUNITY (FBIC) ARE ACTING TO PLAN, PROTECT, AND ADAPT BY UNDERTAKING A CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACT ASSESSMENT IN THE LITTLE ROCKY MOUNTAINS. THIS RANGE IS HOME TO NUMEROUS FOOD AND MEDICINAL SPECIES OF CULTURAL IMPORTANCE. IT IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND HOW CLIMATE CHANGE HAS AFFECTED AND WILL AFFECT AVAILABILITY OF THESE SPECIES AND THE CULTURAL IMPLICATIONS FOR THE TRIBE. UNDERSTANDING THESE EFFECTS IS KEY TO ENHANCING FOOD SOVEREIGNTY AND CULTURAL RESILIENCY, IMPROVING TRIBAL HEALTH, AND MAINTAINING BIODIVERSITY. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE PRESENCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF SPECIES INCLUDING SUBALPINE FIR, JUNEBERRY, CHOKECHERRY, AND OTHERS, AND ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN DISCUSSIONS AROUND ACCESS AND COMMUNITY NEEDS. THE RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT TRIBAL PARTNERS IN THE LITTLE ROCKY MOUNTAINS WHILE ALSO PROVIDING AN EXAMPLE APPROACH FOR FUTURE RISK ASSESSMENTS OF FIRST FOOD RESOURCES.PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND DELIVERABLES  TO BUILD CULTURAL, COMMUNITY, AND ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, THIS PROJECT WILL UNDERTAKE A CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACT ASSESSMENT IN THE LITTLE ROCKY MOUNTAINS, AN AREA OF CULTURAL AND SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE TO THE AANIIIHNEN AND NAKODA TRIBES OF THE FORT BELKNAP INDIAN COMMUNITY (FBIC). THE LITTLE ROCKY MOUNTAINS ARE HOME TO FIRST FOODS AND MEDICINES AND CULTURAL SITES VITAL TO AANIIIHNEN AND NAKODA WAYS OF LIFE. FBIC S TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE (THPO) AND THE ENVIRONMENT DEPARTMENT (ED) IDENTIFIED PROTECTION OF PLANT MEDICINES AND FIRST FOODS AS AN ADAPTATION PRIORITY THROUGH ONGOING CLIMATE RESILIENCE PLANNING. FOR EXAMPLE, SUBALPINE FIR IS A HIGH ELEVATION SPECIES OF CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE TO THE AANIIIHNEN AND NAKODA PEOPLES. UNDERSTANDING CLIMATIC CONDITIONS WITHIN THE LITTLE ROCKIES IS ESSENTIAL FOR EXPLORING THE FEASIBILITY OF RESTORING SUBALPINE FIR AND ENSURING THAT OTHER IMPORTANT SPECIES OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE SUCH AS BEAR ROOT, JUNEBERRY, CHOKECHERRY, AND BUFFALOBERRY ARE SUSTAINED WITHIN THE RESERVATION BOUNDARIES.THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT PLANT SPECIES AND ASSESS CURRENT DISTRIBUTION THROUGH BOTH TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE AND WESTERN SCIENCE. THIS PHASE WILL BE CARRIED OUT BY THPO WITH SUPPORT FROM THE PRAIRIE ADAPTATION RESEARCH COLLABORATIVE (PARC). PHASE TWO WILL ASSESS CLIMATE RELATED ECOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL CHANGES FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF TRIBAL KNOWLEDGE HOLDERS. PHASE THREE WILL INCLUDE IDENTIFYING FUTURE CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACT SCENARIOS BASED ON PARC S CLIMATE MODELING AND ANALYSIS, EXPLORATION OF DIFFERENT SCENARIOS FOR THE COMMUNITY, AND IDENTIFICATION OF KEY ACTIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MITIGATING ECOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL IMPACTS. THIS PROJECT WILL COMBINE TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE AND WESTERN SCIENCE METHODS THAT CAN INFORM A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO CLIMATE CHANGE ASSESSMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN THE FBIC CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLAN. A ROBUST DATASET WILL INCLUDE THE QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE DATA REPRESENTING SPECIFIC MAPPED OUTPUTS ASSESSING ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS AND VULNERABILITIES.SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT. THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WILL EXECUTE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL SUBAWARDS  FORT BELKNAP TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE, CENTER FOR LARGE LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION, AND THE PRAIRIE ADAPTATION RESEARCH COLLABORATIVE.

PROJECT TITLE  BUILDING TRIBAL CAPACITY TO ADAPT AND RESPOND TO CLIMATE CHANGE IN SOUTHERN SOUTHEAST ALASKAPROJECT DATES  11 15 2022 THROUGH 11 14 2024AWARD PURPOSE  OVER THE PAST DECADE OCEAN ACIDIFICATION HAS BECOME A CRITICAL RESOURCE ISSUE FOR ALASKA, ESPECIALLY IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA, WHERE COMMUNITIES ARE HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON COMMERCIAL FISHING AND SUBSISTENCE WAYS OF LIFE. TWO AREAS OF CONCERN ARE THAT OCEAN ACIDIFICATION COULD CAUSE ECOSYSTEM-LEVEL SHIFTS AND REDUCE FOOD SECURITY. THIS PROJECT ENHANCES AND EXPANDS CAPACITY TO SUPPORT CLIMATE ADAPTATION EFFORTS LED BY TRIBAL PARTNERS AND IN ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES MORE BROADLY. ALASKA NATIVE-LED RESEARCH AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR RESEARCH LINKED TO ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES ARE SUPPORTED THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP AMONG THE KETCHIKAN INDIAN COMMUNITY, THE METLAKATLA INDIAN COMMUNITY, OCEANSALASKA AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE KETCHIKAN INDIAN COMMUNITY AND METLAKATLA INDIAN COMMUNITY WILL COMPLETE CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANS THAT INCLUDE LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS WHO WILL IDENTIFY KEY RESOURCES THAT ARE CURRENTLY BEING IMPACTED BY CLIMATE CHANGES OR THAT CAN BE ANTICIPATED THAT WILL SOON BE IMPACTED. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL HOST COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS AND ENGAGE YOUTH INTERNS WHO WILL INTERVIEW ELDERS AND TRIBAL COMMUNITY LEADERS TO IDENTIFY WHAT ISSUES COMMUNITY MEMBERS IDENTIFY TO BE ADDRESSED THROUGH RESILIENCE AND ADAPTATION PLANS. THESE PLANS WILL IDENTIFY PRACTICAL AND STRATEGIC STEPS THAT CAN BE TAKEN TO MITIGATE OR ADAPT TO THE CHANGING CIRCUMSTANCES.TRIBES WILL ESTABLISH A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE PROJECT S SUBAWARD, OCEANSALASKA, TO MONITOR OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND SAMPLE WATER AT KEY HARVESTING SITES TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL FUTURE SCENARIOS FOR OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND VULNERABILITY OF SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES TO LOW OCEAN ACIDIFICATION. THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS WILL SUPPORT TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, PROCESS SAMPLES, AND MEET WITH COMMUNITIES AND LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  ANTICIPATED PRODUCTS INCLUDE COMPLETION OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANS, DATA ON OCEAN ACIDIFICATION, INFORMATION ON VULNERABILITY OF CULTURAL AND SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO BUILD RESILIENCE AND CAPACITY TO DETECT CLIMATE IMPACTS AND CHANGES IN THESE RESOURCES OVER TIME.INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   THIS PROJECT PROVIDES SUPPORT AND BUILDS CAPACITY FOR ALASKA NATIVE-LED RESEARCH AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING. STAKEHOLDERS ARE DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT, STARTING AT THE PLANNING STAGES, AND SERVE AS RESEARCHERS AND PARTNERS ON THE PROJECT.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE OCEANSALASKA TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE EXECUTION OF THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT, AS DESCRIBED ABOVE.

PROJECT TITLE  PUTTING THE SAMPLING DESIGN TO WORK  ENHANCING MONITORING PROGRAMS FOR IMPROVED MANAGEMENT AND INFERENCE OF ECOLOGICAL RESPONSES TO CHANGES IN CLIMATEPROJECT DATES  10 1 2022 THROUGH 9 30 2025AWARD PURPOSE  STUDYING THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE ON IMPORTANT ECOLOGICAL RESPONSES IS A RECENT PRIORITY OF MONITORING PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT THE NORTHEAST  ESTABLISHED SAMPLING PROTOCOLS FOR DATA COLLECTION, WHETHER TO INFORM ESTIMATES OF ABUNDANCE OR OCCUPANCY, WERE DESIGNED TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF NON CLIMATE STRESSORS AND RELATED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  TRADITIONAL MODELING APPROACHES, SUCH AS GENERALIZED LINEAR MODELS, MAY NOT ACCURATELY IDENTIFY IMPORTANT RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN SPECIES AND CLIMATE NOR ELICIT USEFUL INFORMATION ON HOW THESE SPECIES WILL BE IMPACTED BY A CHANGING CLIMATE  MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BASED ON A MODEL NOT ACCOUNTING FOR SAMPLING BIAS COULD HAVE NEGATIVE, UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES ON SPECIES AND HABITAT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED AND  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP STATISTICAL METHODS TO ENHANCE AND OR MODIFY EXISTING MONITORING PROGRAMS  ABILITIES TO UNDERSTAND CLIMATE EFFECTS ON FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS  SPECIFICALLY, GIVEN EXISTING MONITORING PROGRAMS, OBJECTIVES ARE TO  1  DEVELOP STATISTICAL MODELS THAT QUANTIFY AND ACCOUNT FOR THE IMPACTS OF THE SAMPLING DESIGN IN UNDERSTANDING THE PROJECT TITLE  EXPLORING CHANGES IN RAIN ON SNOW EVENTS AND THEIR INFLUENCE ON FUTURE STREAMFLOWS, STREAM TEMPERATURES, AND MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES IN THE GREAT LAKES BASINPROJECT DATES  10 1 2022 THROUGH 9 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE RAIN ON SNOW EVENTS OCCUR WHEN WARM RAIN FALLS ON AN EXISTING SNOWPACK, CAUSING RAPID SNOWMELT THAT CAN LEAD TO DAMAGING FLOODS, REDUCED SPRING AND SUMMER STREAMFLOW, AND ALTERED STREAM TEMPERATURES  IT IS IMPERATIVE TO UNDERSTAND HOW RAIN ON SNOW EVENTS WILL AFFECT STREAMFLOW REGIMES, STREAM ECOSYSTEMS, LOCAL COMMUNITIES, AND THUS IMPORTANT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS UNDER ONGOING CHANGES IN CLIMATE  ECOLOGICALLY, THESE IMPACTS COULD CAUSE A LOSS OF RIVERINE BIODIVERSITY, DECREASES IN FISHERIES PRODUCTION, AND DEGRADATION OF HABITAT  SOCIALLY, THESE IMPACTS COULD CAUSE WATER SHORTAGES FOR COMMUNITIES, PRODUCE FLOODS, AND CREATE WATER QUALITY PROBLEMS  ECONOMICALLY, THESE IMPACTS CAN CAUSE REPERCUSSIONS FOR NAVIGATION AND COMMERCIAL TRANSPORTATION, HYDROELECTRIC POWER GENERATION, RECREATION, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, AND HARBORS AND MARINAS  NOWHERE IS UNDERSTANDING THE CONSEQUENCES OF CHANGING RAIN ON SNOW EVENTS MORE IMPORTANT THAN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN, WHERE RAIN ON SNOW MELT HAS BEEN INVOLVED WITH APPROXIMATELY ONE QUARTER OF THE MOST EXTREME SNOWMELT EVENTS FROM 1980 2009 ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL COMBINE OUTPUTS FROM AN ENSEMBLE OF CLIMATE MODELS THAT PROVIDE PROJECTIONS OF DAILY AIR TEMPERATURE AND PRECIPITAT ON TO THE END OF THE 21ST CENTURY WITH A HYDROLOGIC MODEL THAT WILL SIMULATE THE WATER CYCLE  STREAMFLOW, SOIL MOISTURE, SNOWMELT, RAIN ON SNOW EVENTS, ETC   AND STREAM TEMPERATURES THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE GREAT LAKES BASIN  THIS WILL ALLOW WATERSHEDS RIVERS TO BE TARGETED FOR FUTURE RESTORATION AND MITIGATION DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE IMPACTS TO RIVERS FROM CLIMATE CHANGE POSE RISKS FOR THE ECOSYSTEMS, COMMUNITIES, AND ECONOMIES THAT DEPEND ON THE RESOURCES PROVIDED BY THESE SYSTEMS, AND THUS MODEL OUTPUTS OF HISTORICAL FUTURE HYDROLOGICAL EXTREMES, STREAM TEMPERATURES, AND AQUATIC SPECIES HABITAT WILL BE SHARED WITH THE PUBLIC THROUGH AN EASILY ACCESSIBLE PROJECT WEBSITE  THE FORMAT OF RESULTS AND WEBSITE WILL BE DEVELOPED IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE PROJECT TEAM AND MEMBERS OF THE LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BANDS OF ODAWA INDIANS AS WELL AS OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO BE INCLUDED AS THE PROJECT PROGRESSES  THE MODELS AND THEIR DATA INPUTS WILL ALSO BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES  STAKEHOLDERS THAT ARE INTERESTED IN HYDROLOGY OR FISHERIES HABITAT WITHIN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN ARE THE MAIN BENEFICIARIES FOR THIS PROJECT  THE PROJECT TEAM EXPECTS THAT THE PROJECT RESULTS WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR PROTECTING THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, MANAGING FISHERIES DURING PERIODS OF HIGH STREAM TEMPERATURE OR LOW STREAMFLOW, AND CREATING HABITAT REFUGIA TO MEET MANAGEMENT GOALS IN FUTURE AQUATIC FLOW REGIMES  SPECIFIC STAKEHOLDERS FOR THIS WORK INCLUDE THE LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BANDS OF ODAWA INDIANS, BUT OTHER GROUPS FROM AROUND THE GREAT LAKES BASIN WILL BE INCLUDED AS THE PROJECT PROGRESSES, AND RESEARCH RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH THE PUBLIC SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE INDIANA UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT

PRODUCTS WILL IMPROVE LONG TERM OUTCOMES OF MANAGEMENT PROJECTS WHILE PREDICTING AND REDUCING CONFLICTS WITH OTHER MANAGEMENT GOALS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED CREATE MODELS OF BIRD HABITAT QUALITY PROJECT TITLE  FUTURE OF AQUATIC FLOWS IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL U S   TOWARDS A NATIONAL SYNTHESIS OF AQUATIC FLOW UNDER A CHANGING CLIMATEPROJECT DATES  10 1 2022   9 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE THE GREATER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN  MRB  IS THE LARGEST RIVER BASIN IN NORTH AMERICA AND THE FOURTH LARGEST BASIN WORLDWIDE  THE MRB ENCOMPASSES 24 TERRESTRIAL ECOSYSTEMS, PROVIDING HABITATS FOR 100 SPECIES OF MAMMALS, REPTILES, AND AMPHIBIANS, AND ITS FLOODPLAIN SUPPORTS FORTY PERCENT OF THE WATERFOWL AND WADING BIRDS IN NORTH AMERICA  ITS RIVERS TRANSPORT 40  OF THE NATION S TOTAL EXPORTS  DOZENS OF DIFFERENT CULTURES ARE SCATTERED ACROSS THE MRB WITH DIFFERENT POLICY STRUCTURES, WORLDVIEWS, AND ECONOMIC STRENGTHS  THE HETEROGENEITY IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIO CULTURAL SETTINGS ACROSS THE MRB POSES A CHALLENGE TO CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND ACTIONABLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS CLIMATE CHANGE HAS DISRUPTED THE AMOUNT, FREQUENCY, AND SEASONALITY OF PRECIPITATION EVENTS ACROSS THE GREATER MRB  THESE CHANGES AFFECT THE RIVERS AND STREAMS, ESPECIALLY WHEN COMBINED WITH OTHER STRESSORS SUCH AS LAND USE CHANGES, NUTRIENT RUNOFF, AND INCREASING DEMAND FOR WATER  REGIONAL PRECIPITATION EVENTS CAN HAVE REMOTE IMPACTS, RESULTING IN SUBSTANTIALLY DIFFERENT CONDITIONS  HENCE, THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION COMMUNITY NEEDS TO THINK ACROSS MULTIPLE SCALES, RANGING FROM LOCAL TO REGIONAL TO GLOBAL AND FROM SHORT  TO LONG TERM, TO IDENTIFY SOLUTIONS THAT WORK WITHIN AND ACROSS THE SOCIO ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS AFFECTED ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP A CONCEPTUAL MODEL OF THE GREATER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN SOCIO ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEM TO DOCUMENT, VISUALIZE, AND ANALYZE THE COMPLEX INTERLINKAGES AND RELATIONSHIPS WHICH NEED TO BE CONSIDERED FOR SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF HYDROLOGICAL RESOURCES AND AQUATIC FLOWS  THEY WILL CONNECT THE MODEL WITH AN INTEGRATIVE DATABASE SYNTHESIZING A MULTITUDE OF QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE DATASETS ACROSS SPATIAL TEMPORAL SCALES THAT WILL FORM THE BASIS OF MANY ANALYSES OF THE MRB SOCIO ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEM DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE   1  A LITERATURE REVIEW ON THE SPATIO TEMPORAL HETEROGENEITY OF SOCIO ENVIRONMENTAL CHALLENGES RELATED TO HYDROLOGICAL RESOURCES ACROSS THE MRB   2  A CONCEPTUAL MODEL DOCUMENTING AND VISUALIZING THE MRB SOCIO ENVIRONMENT SYSTEM AND THE INTERLINKAGES OF THE SYSTEM COMPONENTS ACROSS SPATIAL SCALES   3  AN INTEGRATIVE DATABASE FOR THE MRB SOCIO ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEM  AND  4  AN ESRI STORY MAP THAT SYNTHESIZES THE PROJECT RESULTS IN A VISUALLY APPEALING AND ACCESSIBLE MANNER INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES  STAKEHOLDERS FOR THIS PROJECT ARE PRIMARILY APPLIED SCIENTISTS IN CLIMATE BOUNDARY ORGANIZATIONS WHO HAVE BEEN WORKING IN PARTS OF THE MRB AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS IN THE MRB REGION INTERESTED IN SCALE ISSUES SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  FUTURE OF AQUATIC FLOWS  EXPLORING CHANGES IN THE FRESHWATER SALTWATER INTERFACE AND ITS IMPACTS TO AQUATIC SPECIESPROJECT DATES  10 1 2022 THROUGH 9 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS ARE HOME TO MANY SPECIES OF ECONOMIC, ECOLOGICAL, AND CULTURAL IMPORTANCE, AND MANY OF THESE SPECIES RELY ON REGULAR INPUTS OF FRESHWATER  AS THE CLIMATE WARMS AND PEOPLE CONTINUE TO LIVE IN DENSE POPULATIONS ALONG THE COASTS, THE REGULAR RHYTHMS OF FRESHWATER INPUTS TO THE COASTS ARE DISRUPTED, LEAVING COASTAL SPECIES VULNERABLE TO POPULATION DECLINES OR COLLAPSES  NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TASKED WITH PROTECTING COASTAL SPECIES IN A CHANGING CLIMATE DO NOT HAVE THE GUIDANCE NEEDED TO DEVELOP MITIGATION PLANS THAT PROTECT COASTAL SPECIES AGAINST SHIFTS IN FRESHWATER AVAILABILITY  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP SCIENCE PRODUCTS THAT CAN BE USED BY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR PROTECTING COASTAL SPECIES UNDER SHIFTING FRESHWATER AVAILABILITY PATTERNS  TO MEET THIS GOAL, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL COMPILE INFORMATION FROM PUBLISHED STUDIES TO PRODUCE REFERENCE TABLES THAT SUMMARIZE WHICH COASTAL SPECIES OF ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, AND OR CULTURAL IMPORTANCE ARE VULNERABLE TO SHIFTS IN FRESHWATER AVAILABILITY  THEY WILL ALSO ESTIMATE HOW FRESHWATER AVAILABILITY TO COASTAL SYSTEMS IS EXPECTED TO CHANGE UNDER FUTURE CLIMATE AND LAND USE CONDITIONS BY RUNNING MODEL SIMULATIONS FOR THE ENTIRE U S  THAT ACCOUNT FOR THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE AND LAND USE CHANGE ON RAINFALL AND RUNOFF PATTERNS  THESE MODEL SIMULATIONS WILL RESULT IN A MAP THAT ILLUSTRATES WHICH COASTAL SYSTEMS ARE MOST LIKELY TO EXPERIENCE CHANGES IN FRESHWATER INPUTS  LASTLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE THE TABLES AND MAPS PRODUCED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT TO DEVELOP A MANAGEMENT STRATEGY FOR A COASTAL SYSTEM THAT IS VULNERABLE TO CHANGES IN FRESHWATER  THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE MANAGEMENT STRATEGY FOR A SPECIFIC SYSTEM WILL SERVE AS AN ILLUSTRATIVE CASE STUDY THAT DEMONSTRATES HOW PRODUCTS CREATED FROM THE PROJECT CAN BE PUT INTO PRACTICE TO CREATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES DESIGNED TO PROTECT COASTAL SPECIES FROM THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO  1  PERFORM A META ANALYSIS SYNTHESIZING THE ESTUARINE AND MARINE SPECIES AND HABITATS KNOWN TO BE SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN FRESHWATER DISCHARGE MAGNITUDE AND TIMING, AND THE ASSOCIATED THRESHOLDS OR TIPPING POINTS THAT DEFINE THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FRESHWATER INPUTS AND SPECIES HABITATS   2  PREDICT CHANGES IN FRESHWATER DISCHARGE TO ESTUARIES ACROSS PROJECT TITLE  HOW DO SNOW AVALANCHES IMPACT LANDSCAPE CHARACTERISTICS AND MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA PROJECT DATES  10 1 2022   9 30 2025AWARD PURPOSE SNOWCOVER IN THE MOUNTAINS HAS A WIDE VARIETY OF IMPACTS ON THE LANDSCAPE AND ANIMAL POPULATIONS  IN PARTICULAR, SNOW AVALANCHES ALTER VEGETATION PATTERNS BY PREVENTING THE ESTABLISHMENT OF FOREST COVER IN AREAS WITH FREQUENT SNOW SLIDES  IN ADDITION, AVALANCHES POSE A THREAT TO ANIMALS SUCH AS MOUNTAIN GOATS THAT UTILIZE AVALANCHE HAZARDS ZONES AS HABITAT DURING WINTER MONTHS  THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE HOW SNOW AVALANCHES IMPACT MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS IN THE COAST RANGE OF SOUTHEAST ALASKA  MOUNTAIN GOATS ARE IMPORTANT FOR CULTURAL AND SUBSISTENCE USES AND ARE KNOWN TO BE INFLUENCED BY WINTER SEVERITY  OUR PROJECT WILL BE THE FIRST TO QUANTIFY HOW MOUNTAIN GOATS USE AVALANCHE TERRAIN AND HOW THE OCCURRENCE OF AVALANCHES IMPACTS MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS THROUGH DIRECT MORTALITY WHEN GOATS ARE BURIED IN SNOW SLIDES  THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP INFORM DECISIONS MADE BY WILDLIFE AGENCIES AND NATIVE ALASKAN COMMUNITIES WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND USE OF MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE PROJECT WILL EMPLOY TWO UNIQUE DATASETS  THE FIRST IS A LONG TERM  2005 2022  DATASET OF GPS DATA COLLECTED FROM 434 MOUNTAIN GOATS THAT WERE OUTFITTED WITH CONTINUOUSLY RECORDING GPS COLLARS  IN ADDITION TO GPS LOCATION INFORMATION, EVERY INSTANCE OF MORTALITY WAS INVESTIGATED WITHIN THE POPULATION OF GOATS OUTFITTED WITH COLLARS TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF DEATH  THE SECOND DATASET IS AN AVALANCHE HAZARD MAP THAT USES A PHYSICALLY BASED MODEL TO DELINEATE AREAS ON THE LANDSCAPE WHERE SNOW AVALANCHES CAN OCCUR DURING WINTER MONTHS  THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE THESE DATASETS TO INVESTIGATE THE AMOUNT OF TIME THAT MOUNTAIN GOATS SPEND IN AVALANCHE HAZARD TERRAIN DURING ALL MONTHS OF THE YEAR AND THE PROPORTION OF MOUNTAIN GOATS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA THAT ARE KILLED BY SNOW AVALANCHES AS OPPOSED TO OTHER CAUSES OF DEATH SUCH AS FALLS, PREDATION, MALNUTRITION DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN TWO PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS  ONE RELATED TO MOUNTAIN GOAT USE OF AVALANCHE TERRAIN AS HABITAT AND A SECOND RELATED TO THE ROLE THAT AVALANCHES PLAY IN THE DYNAMICS OF MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS  THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO CONVEY PROJECT FINDINGS TO THE PUBLIC AND INTERESTED PARTIES THROUGH PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS IN RELEVANT COMMUNITIES SUCH AS JUNEAU AND HAINES IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA  FINALLY, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PROVIDE A MANAGEMENT ORIENTED FINAL REPORT THAT SUMMARIZES HOW PROJECT FINDINGS ARE RELEVANT TO THE MANAGEMENT OF MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES  THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS AND MANAGERS AT THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME AS WELL AS SUBSISTENCE MOUNTAIN GOAT USERS IN ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES SUCH AS THE CHILKAT INDIAN VILLAGE AND THE SITKA TRIBE OF ALASKA  IN PARTICULAR, THE PROJECT FINDINGS WILL PROVIDE NOVEL INFORMATION ABOUT HOW WINTER SNOWFALL IMPACTS MOUNTAIN GOAT POPULATIONS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF SEASONAL CLIMATE AND EXTREME PRECIPITATION ON FLOOD HAZARD IN THE MIDWESTPROJECT DATES  9 21 2022 THROUGH 9 20 2024AWARD PURPOSE  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE HOW THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF CHANGES IN SEASONAL CLIMATE AND EXTREME PRECIPITATION EVENTS, AFFECT FLOOD CHARACTERISTICS  SUCH AS FLOOD FREQUENCY, INTENSITY, AND SEASONALITY  THAT ARE OF RELEVANCE TO STAKEHOLDER MANAGEMENT COMMUNITIES IN THE MIDWEST REGION ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THIS PROJECT INVOLVES THREE COMPONENTS  THE FIRST IS AN ANALYSIS OF HISTORICAL AND MODELED CLIMATIC CHANGES IN THE MIDWEST REGION TO IDENTIFY VARIATIONS AND CHANGES IN  A  SEASONAL CLIMATIC PARAMETERS SUCH AS TEMPERATURE, PRECIPITATION, SNOW, AND SOIL MOISTURE, AND  B  POTENTIAL CHANGES IN EXTREME RAINFALL EVENTS  NEXT, THESE CHANGES WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO A SUITE OF EXPERIMENTS USING A STATE OF THE ART HYDROLOGIC MODEL TO IDENTIFY HOW DIFFERENT CLIMATIC VARIATIONS AND CHANGE AFFECT FUTURE FLOOD CHARACTERISTICS  THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT THE EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH STAKEHOLDERS IN THE MIDWEST REGION TO DETERMINE RELEVANT OUTPUTS AND ANALYSES DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE RESULT OF THIS PROJECT WILL ADVANCE UNDERSTANDING OF FUTURE FLOOD CHARACTERISTICS ACROSS A VARIETY OF LANDSCAPES IN THE MIDWEST REGION, WITH A FOCUS ON DEVELOPING INFORMATION THAT IS RELEVANT FOR STAKEHOLDER MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES  THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A SCIENTIFIC PAPER DESCRIBING EXPECTED CLIMATIC CHANGES IN THE MIDWEST REGION, A SECOND SCIENTIFIC PAPER DESCRIBING HOW THOSE CHANGES AFFECT FLOOD CHARACTERISTICS, AND A  PLAIN LANGUAGE  SYNTHESIS DOCUMENT THAT DESCRIBES HOW RESULTS RELATE TO STAKEHOLDER MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES  RESULTS WILL BE SHARED AT CONFERENCES AND WITH EXISTING STAKEHOLDER NETWORKS SUCH AS THE MIDWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER, AND THE WISCONSIN INITIATIVE ON CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT A WIDE RANGE OF STAKEHOLDER GROUPS IN THE MIDWEST REGION, INCLUDING DEPARTMENTS OF NATURAL RESOURCES, KICKAPOO VALLEY RESERVE, HO CHUNK NATION CULTURAL RESOURCE DIVISION, PARTNERS IN THE WISCONSIN INITIATIVE ON CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN MADISON TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT

PROJECT TITLE  SHIFTING FROM EXTRACTIVE TO SELF DETERMINED  ENHANCING INDIGENOUS RESEARCH AND DATA GOVERNANCE IN SOUTHWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION INITIATIVESPROJECT DATES  9 1 2022   8 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE  INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE SYSTEMS, SUCH AS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, CONTAIN CLIMATE OBSERVATIONS AND ADAPTATION STRATEGIES REACHING BACK MILLENNIA  THESE INCLUDE METHODS FOR CARING FOR OUR NATURAL RESOURCES AND RELATIONS, SUCH AS THROUGH DROUGHT RESILIENT AGRICULTURE, SOIL, AND WATER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES  DESPITE A GROWING GLOBAL RECOGNITION AMONG RESEARCHERS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS OF THE VALUE OF INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGES AND PRACTICES FOR ENHANCING HUMAN CAPACITY TO ADAPT TO CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS, WE FACE HISTORIC INEQUITIES THAT HINDER CROSS CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE AND INNOVATION  THIS INCLUDES A TENDENCY TOWARDS EXTRACTIVE RESEARCH, ACCESSING INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGES WITHOUT REGARDING INDIGENOUS DECISION MAKING NEEDS, SOVEREIGNTY, OR RIGHTS FOR SELF DETERMINATION  THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ADDRESS THESE INEQUITIES AND SERVE SOCIETAL NEEDS BY PROVIDING PRACTICAL PATHWAYS FOR SHIFTING FROM EXTRACTIVE TO INDIGENOUS SELF DETERMINED RESEARCH, EFFECTIVELY REDUCING BARRIERS FOR TRIBAL GOVERNANCE AND KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION  THROUGH THIS ANALYSES, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH AN INDIGENOUS ADVISORY COUNCIL, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF CURRENT TRENDS IN POLICY AND PRACTICE APPLIED WITHIN TRIBALLY FOCUSED CLIMATE ADAPTATION INITIATIVES BOTH NATIONALLY AND IN THE SOUTHWEST AND HOST AN INTER TRIBAL KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE AND MAPPING WORKSHOP FOCUSED ON INDIGENOUS LED CLIMATE ADAPTATION SUCCESS STORIES ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  PROJECT ACTIVITIES CENTER ON THREE FUNDAMENTAL OBJECTIVES FOR SHIFTING FROM EXTRACTIVE TO SELF DETERMINED RESEARCH AND DATA GOVERNANCE  OBJ1  CONDUCT A NATIONAL  SCALE SYSTEMATIC REVIEW AND META ANALYSIS IDENTIFYING BASELINE DATA TO GUIDE PROJECT  OBJ2  DRAW ON INDIGENOUS RESEARCH AND GOVERNANCE FRAMEWORKS, AND KNOWLEDGE SHARING GUIDELINES FOR FEDERAL NON TRIBAL AND TRIBAL PARTNERSHIPS TO COMPLETE A REGIONAL, CROSS CASE ANALYSIS  OBJ3  HOST AN INTER TRIBAL KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE AND PARTICIPATORY MAPPING WORKSHOP WITH SOUTHWEST TRIBAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND DECISION MAKERS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  INTERACTIVE LEARNING MODULES, A DIGITAL STORYMAP, PUBLICATIONS, AND EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS GENERATED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE AS LEARNING RESOURCES TO ENHANCE CLIMATE ADAPTATION INITIATIVES THAT ENGAGE INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGES AND SERVE TO STRENGTHEN INTER TRIBAL AND TRIBAL NON TRIBAL PARTNERSHIPS INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE, 1  TRIBAL RIGHTS HOLDERS AND DECISION MAKERS  INCLUDING COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGE KEEPERS, TRIBAL LEADERSHIP, NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND DATA ADMINISTRATORS   2  RESEARCHERS AND SCIENCE ORGANIZATIONS WORKING WITH TRIBES AND OR ENGAGING INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGES AND PERSPECTIVES  3  POLICY MAKERS ADDRESSING TRIBAL RIGHTS SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT  THE COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY HAS THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL SUBAWARD PARTNER S  WHO WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROJECT COORDINATION GUIDED BY ONGOING ENGAGEMENT AND COLLABORATION WITH THE INDIGENOUS ADVISORY COUNCIL  THIS INCLUDES STAKEHOLDER AND RIGHTS HOLDER ENGAGED PROJECT DESIGN, ANALYSIS, AND CO CREATION AND SHARING OF PROJECT OUTPUTS  SUBRECIPIENTS WILL ALSO GUIDE PROJECT ENGAGEMENT WITH BROADER SCIENCE AND CLIMATE NETWORKS

PROJECT TITLE  CALIFORNIA REFORESTATION MANAGEMENT TOOLSHED  AN INTEGRATED WEB BASED DASHBOARD OF EXISTING RESOURCESPROJECT DATES  9 1 2022   8 31 2023AWARD PURPOSE  MILLIONS OF ACRES OF CALIFORNIA S EASING THE BURDEN FOR FOREST MANAGERS TO LOCATE, REVIEW, AND COMPARE DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS SUITED TO CLIMATE INFORMED REFORESTATION EFFORTS, THE TOOLSHED WILL SUPPORT THE RECOVERY AND INCREASED RESILIENCE OF CALIFORNIA S FORESTS SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT

PROJECT TITLE  TRAJECTORIES OF CHANGE  HOW CLIMATE, WILDFIRE, AND MANAGEMENT DRIVE SHRUBLAND ECOSYSTEM TRANSITIONSPROJECT DATES  9 1 2022 THROUGH 8 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE A CHANGE IN WILDFIRE REGIMES AND THE EXPANSION OF INVASIVE GRASSES ARE DEGRADING SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS, ALTERING WILDLIFE HABITATS, AND THREATENING PROPERTY AND HUMAN LIVELIHOODS  IN RESPONSE, LAND MANAGERS OFTEN TREAT LARGE AREAS OF LAND WITH FUEL REDUCTION OR POST FIRE SEEDING TREATMENTS TO TRY TO REDUCE THESE RISKS, BUT THE TRAJECTORIES OF ECOSYSTEM CHANGE FOLLOWING TREATMENT ARE INCONSISTENT ACROSS THE SAGEBRUSH STEPPE  IN SOME PLACES, TREATMENTS ARE SUCCESSFUL   INVASIVE GRASSES DECREASE AND NATIVE PLANTS RECOVER  IN OTHER PLACES, TREATMENTS HAVE NO EFFECT OR EVEN FACILITATE THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE GRASSES  UNDER SOME CLIMATE CONDITIONS, NATIVE GRASSES AND FORBS DO WELL FOLLOWING A FIRE WHILE SAGEBRUSH HAS DIFFICULTY ESTABLISHING  AS THE CLIMATE GETS WARMER AND DRIER, IT HAS BECOME URGENT TO DISENTANGLE THE DRIVERS OF INVASIVE ESTABLISHMENT AND SAGEBRUSH RECRUITMENT, SO THAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS CAN FOCUS ON THE MOST VULNERABLE AREAS AND THE TYPES OF TREATMENT THAT ARE LIKELY TO HAVE THE MOST SUCCESS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  SAGEBRUSH SHRUBLANDS ARE ONE OF THE MOST IMPERILED ECOSYSTEMS WITH FREQUENT LANDSCAPE SCALE SHIFTS TO ANNUAL OR PERENNIAL GRASSLANDS, OR TO WOODLANDS  SURPRISINGLY, WE KNOW LITTLE ABOUT THE EXTENT OF THESE CONVERSIONS AND THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF CLIMATE, DISTURBANCE, AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS INDIVIDUALLY OR IN CONCERT  THIS PROJECT WILL 1  IDENTIFY WHERE VEGETATION TRANSITIONS IN SAGEBRUSH STEPPE ARE OCCURRING, 2  DETERMINE THE RELATIVE ROLE OF CLIMATE, WILDFIRE, AND MANAGEMENT IN CAUSING THOSE TRANSITIONS, AND 3  PREDICT AREAS MOST AT RISK OF TRANSITIONS UNDER PROJECTED CLIMATES AND SUGGEST POSSIBLE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES BY CONDUCTING RESEARCH USING LARGE FIELD DATA SETS PAIRED WITH REMOTE SENSING AND CLIMATE RECORDS, AS WELL AS DEVELOPING STATE AND TRANSITION SIMULATION MODELS UNDER CURRENT AND FUTURE CLIMATE SCENARIOS INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   PROJECT RESULTS WILL HELP RESOURCE MANAGERS MAKE CLIMATE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT APPROPRIATE TREATMENTS IN CURRENT AND FUTURE CLIMATES  RESEARCH RESULTS WILL HELP LAND MANAGERS AND DECISION MAKERS PRIORITIZE THEIR EFFORTS FOR TODAY S CLIMATE, AS WELL AS DEVELOP ADAPTATION STRATEGIES TO FUTURE CLIMATE  UNDERSTANDING THE COMBINED IMPACTS OF CLIMATE, DISTURBANCE, AND MANAGEMENT ON SAGEBRUSH STEPPE ECOSYSTEMS WILL INCREASE OUR ABILITY TO ENSURE THE CONTINUATION OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVISIONS, SUCH AS WATER RESOURCES, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND HUMAN SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC WELL BEING DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  PROJECT RESULTS INCLUDE SCIENTIFIC PRESENTATIONS, RESEARCH DATA, PUBLICATIONS, WEBINARS, FIELD TOURS, AND FACT SHEETS SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL SUBAWARD TO THE OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT

RECOVERY MORE RESPONSIVE TO THE NEEDS OF TRIBES  WORKING WITH AN ADVISORY BOARD OF TRIBAL EXPERTS AND PARTNERS, THE STUDY WILL GATHER AND ANALYZE LOCAL KNOWLEDGE FROM TRIBAL MEMBERS AND LAND MANAGERS, POLICYMAKERS, AND DIALOGUE THROUGH AN INTER TRIBAL ROUNDTABLE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   THIS RESEARCH WILL HELP TRIBAL AND AGENCY LAND MANAGERS COMMUNICATE AND ADDRESS POST FIRE RECOVERY PRIORITIES PROJECT TITLE  WHAT MAKES CLIMATE SCIENCE PRODUCTS USEFUL  EXPLORING HOW STAKEHOLDERS USE, UNDERSTAND, AND FEEL ABOUT THEM PROJECT DATES  8 15 2022 THROUGH 8 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE  FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS MAY DRAMATICALLY IMPACT MANY OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES, CULTURAL RESOURCES, AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ON WHICH SOCIETY DEPENDS  TO ENSURE THE LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE RESOURCES, DECISION MAKERS IN MANY DOMAINS COMMONLY CONSIDER CLIMATE FORECASTS IN THEIR STRATEGIC PLANNING EFFORTS  IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL UNITED STATES, FOR EXAMPLE, FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS ARE ROUTINELY CONSIDERED IN PLANS FOR WATER SUSTAINABILITY, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, THE DESIGN OF NEW INFRASTRUCTURE, URBAN HEAT IMPACTS, AND DECISIONS TO FEDERALLY LIST A SPECIES AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED  SCIENTISTS HAVE DEVELOPED SOPHISTICATED PROJECTIONS OF FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS AND THEIR IMPACTS ON ECOSYSTEMS AND PEOPLE, BUT THESE MODELS ARE NOT ALWAYS ALIGNED WITH STAKEHOLDERS  NEEDS  AS A RESULT, THE MODELS MAY BE UNDERUTILIZED  THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE USEFULNESS OF EXISTING AND FUTURE CLIMATE DATA AND MODELS BY BETTER ALIGNING THEM WITH STAKEHOLDERS  NEEDS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CONDUCT FOCUSED, MULTI WEEK OBSERVATION OF DECISION MAKERS IN REGIONAL AGENCIES TO ASSESS HOW THEY CURRENTLY USE CLIMATE DATA AND MODELS, WHAT UNMET NEEDS THEY MAY IN STAKEHOLDERS  DECISIONS TO USE CLIMATE DATA  AND THE HEURISTICS  OR MENTAL SHORTCUTS  COMMONLY USED TO THINK AND COMMUNICATE ABOUT CLIMATE DATA THAT HAS HIGH SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, HIGH DIMENSIONALITY  E G , MANY FUTURE SCENARIOS , AND HIGH NUMERICAL COMPLEXITY  E G , A COMPLEX DISTRIBUTION OF FUTURE POSSIBILITIES   THESE EXPERIMENTAL AND OBSERVATIONAL RESULTS WILL BE USED TO INFORM THE DESIGN OF A WEB TOOL THAT WILL TAILOR THE PRESENTATION OF EXISTING CLIMATE DATA AND MODELS TO STAKEHOLDERS  NEEDS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE VALUE OF EXISTING AND FUTURE CLIMATE DATA AND MODELS THROUGH A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF THE WAYS IN WHICH STAKEHOLDERS  PERCEPTIONS, ATTITUDES, HEURISTICS, AND CULTURAL AND ORGANIZATIONAL CONTEXTS MOTIVATE THEIR WILLINGNESS TO INCORPORATE CLIMATE DATA AND MODELS INTO THEIR DECISIONS  IN PARTICULAR, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FIRST EVER QUANTIFICATION OF THE MENTAL HEURISTICS AND COGNITIVE PROCESSES THAT STAKEHOLDERS USE WHEN COMMUNICATING AND THINKING ABOUT CLIMATE DATA  PROJECT RESULTS WILL BE COMMUNICATED DIRECTLY TO STAKEHOLDERS VIA STAKEHOLDER WORKSHOPS AND A WEB TOOL  THE PROJECT TEAM ANTICIPATES THAT THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE AT LEAST SIX PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, INCLUDING ON THE CULTURAL AND ORGANIZATIONAL CONTEXTS OF DECISION MAKING, THE HEURISTICS THAT STAKEHOLDERS USE TO THINK AND COMMUNICATE ABOUT CLIMATE DATA, AND THE DESIGN OF THE WEB TOOL INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  ACROSS THE SOUTH CENTRAL REGION AND BEYOND, PROJECT RESULTS WILL INFORM NATIONAL RESOURCES MANAGERS AND ENHANCE THE LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF A RANGE OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES  E G , WATER, AGRICULTURE, ECOSYSTEMS, AND INFRASTRUCTURE  BY ENSURING THAT CLIMATE DATA AND MODELS CAN INFORM STRATEGIC PLANNING EFFORTS FOR THESE RESOURCES SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE  ASSESSING IMPACTS OF EAB AND ADAPTATION STRATEGIES ON HABITAT QUALITY FOR AT RISK WILDLIFE IN BLACK ASH FORESTSPROJECT DATES  9 1 2022   8 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE  BLACK ASH WETLANDS WREN  IN THESE WETLANDS, BLACK ASH TREES ARE A FOUNDATIONAL SPECIES, REGULATING ALL ASPECTS OF ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION, AND ARE ALSO A CULTURALLY IMPORTANT RESOURCE FOR NATIVE AMERICANS, SPECIFICALLY FOR ASSESS THE DIFFERENCES IN ADAPTIVE STRATEGIES, SUCH AS SMALL PATCH CUTTING AND CLEARCUTTING, WHICH ARE BEING APPLIED BROADLY IN THE REGION TO TRANSITION BLACK ASH WETLANDS TO OTHER SPECIES  FOR THIS ASH MORTALITY, AND ADAPTIVE AND REACTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND  2  IDENTIFY DIFFERENCES IN HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS  E G , FOOD AVAILABILITY, VEGETATION STRUCTURE, DEGREE OF PONDING  AMONG EMULATED EAB CAUSED ASH MORTALITY, AND ADAPTIVE AND REACTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  IN COLLABORATION WITH PROJECT PARTNERS, RESULTS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP SCIENCE BASED MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO MITIGATE IMPACTS OF EABCAUSED MORTALITY ON WILDLIFE  OVERALL, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING SITE LEVEL METRICS  I E , HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS  THAT SHOULD BE CONSIDERED FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT WITHIN BLACK ASH STANDS AND WILL HELP TO INFORM AND PRIORITIZE BLACK ASH WETLAND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS ACROSS THE REGION  INFORMATION GAINED FROM THE RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE A HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF EAB IMPACTS ON WILDLIFE HABITAT, QUANTIFY EFFICACY OF ADAPTATION STRATEGIES FOR SUSTAINING HABITAT, AND AID IN IDENTIFYING OPTIMAL FUTURE HABITAT CONDITIONS PROJECT TITLE  INTEGRATING ECONOMICS AND ECOLOGY TO INFORM CLIMATE READY AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT FOR VULNERABLE WILLAMETTE BASIN COMMUNITIESPROJECT DATES  8 15 2022 THROUGH 8 14 2023AWARD PURPOSE AND  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  THREATEN THE RIVER ECOSYSTEMS AND THE COMMUNITIES THAT DEPEND ON THEM, INCLUDING THE WILLAMETTE RIVER BASIN, HOME TO THE PROJECT TITLE  ASSESSING THE NEEDS AND ADAPTATION PRACTICES OF SMALL HOLDING AND MINORITY FARMERS FACING EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS IN LOUISIANAPROJECT DATES  1 15 2023 THROUGH 1 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE  EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS  SUCH AS FLOODS, ICE STORMS, TROPICAL CYCLONES, AND TORNADOES  ARE INCREASING IN FREQUENCY AND CONSEQUENCE THROUGHOUT THE US AND PARTICULARLY IN LOUISIANA  THESE NATURAL DISASTERS ARE ESPECIALLY DEVASTATING FOR FARMERS, WHOSE LIVELIHOODS DEPEND ON THE ENVIRONMENT  MOST CLIMATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION OUTREACH FOCUS ON LARGE SCALE FARMERS AND TEND TO REACH MAJORITY WHITE FARMERS, OFTEN NEGLECTING SMALL HOLDING AND AFRICAN AMERICAN FARMERS  WHILE THESE FARMERS MAKE UP LESS OF THE TOTAL AGRICULTURAL POPULATION AND ECONOMY, THEY ARE A CRITICAL PART OF THE AGRICULTURAL AND ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS AND A CRUCIAL COMPONENT IN BUILDING SUSTAINABLE RURAL COMMUNITIES IN LOUISIANA  FURTHERMORE, CLIMATE ADAPTATION SUPPORT OFTEN FAILS TO CONSIDER THE SOCIAL, STRUCTURAL, AND CULTURAL FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE SMALL HOLDING AND AFRICAN AMERICAN FARMERS  DECISION MAKING AND RESILIENCE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THIS RESEARCH USES ETHNOGRAPHIC METHODS TO FOREGROUND THE PERCEPTIONS, NEEDS, AND CURRENT ISSUES FACED BY AFRICAN AMERICAN FARMERS  BEGINNING WITH THE STAKEHOLDERS THEMSELVES, THIS RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON OBSERVATIONS OF EXTREME WEATHER, ECOLOGICAL FRAMEWORKS, AND EXISTING PRACTICES OF ADAPTATION  THIS RESEARCH WILL ALSO ASSESS THE OBSTACLES FACED TO RECEIVING EXTENSION SUPPORT AND CLIMATE INFORMATION  THE PROJECT TEAM, CONSISTING OF AN ANTHROPOLOGIST, A CLIMATOLOGIST, TWO EXTENSION AGENTS, AND A COMMUNITY BASED FARMER ORGANIZATION, WILL USE THE INFORMATION GATHERED FROM FARMERS TO ANALYZE AND REFINE EXISTING CLIMATE MODELS AND EXTENSION OUTREACH INFORMATION  THROUGH FOCUS GROUPS, FARMERS AND THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL WORK TOGETHER TO BUILD MORE CONTEXTUALLY APPLICABLE OUTREACH AND CLIMATE MATERIALS DESIGNED SPECIFICALLY TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS AND GOALS OF SMALL HOLDING AFRICAN AMERICAN FARMERS IN LOUISIANA DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE EXPECTED OUTPUTS FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE 1  A DECISION TOOL THAT WILL HELP FARMERS INDIVIDUALLY CUSTOMIZE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES TO THEIR FARMS AND USE EXISTING CLIMATE INFORMATION, 2  A WEBSITE SHOWCASING STORIES FROM FARMERS, CLIMATE INFORMATION, AND THE DECISION TOOL, 3  POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS, AND 4  ACADEMIC ARTICLES AND REPORTS INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  AS EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS CONTINUE TO IMPACT LOUISIANA, THIS RESEARCH WILL HELP CONNECT FARMERS TO CRITICAL RESOURCES FOR MAKING INFORMED DECISIONS WHICH WILL ENABLE THEM TO MAINTAIN BOTH THE ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL WELL BEING OF THEIR FARMS AND LANDS  THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL PRIORITIZE THE CULTURAL AND CONTEXTUAL PERSPECTIVES OF AFRICAN AMERICAN FARMERS TO BUILD CLIMATE RESILIENCE AMONG MARGINALIZED POPULATIONS IN LOUISIANA SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA WILL SUBAWARD TO THE LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY AND AAND M COLLEGE TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT  THE LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY HAS THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL SUBAWARD PARTNERS WHO WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  LSU AGCENTER  LSU AG  AND  MISSISSIPPI ASSOCIATION OF COOPERATIVES  MAC   LSU AG AND MAC WILL BOTH BE PROVIDING ASSISTANCE WITH FOCUS GROUPS, INTERVIEWS, AND STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT

PROJECT TITLE  INCORPORATING CLIMATE, DISEASE, AND INVASIVE SPECIES INTO THE CONSERVATION OF A FIRST FOOD, KLAMATH REDBAND TROUTPROJECT DATES  8 15 2022 THROUGH 8 14 2025AWARD PURPOSE  CLIMATE CHANGE HAS THE POTENTIAL TO MAGNIFY EXISTING PROBLEMS IN CONSERVATION, SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES AND DISEASE  THIS THREAT IS PARTICULARLY SEVERE IN THE KLAMATH BASIN, WHERE THE FISH PARASITE CERATONOVA SHASTA HAS MADE NATIONAL HEADLINES FOR KILLING SALMON, AND INVASIVE TROUT HAVE EXTIRPATED POPULATIONS OF NATIVE TROUT  ONGOING COLLABORATION WITH THE KLAMATH TRIBES HAS REVEALED A POTENTIAL SILVER LINING ASSOCIATED WITH DISEASE AND CLIMATE CHANGE  UNDER MILD ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, C  SHASTA APPEARS TO KILL INVASIVE TROUT BUT NOT NATIVE TROUT AND SALMON  HOWEVER, IF TEMPERATURES GET WARM ENOUGH, C  SHASTA CAN KILL NATIVE FISH TOO, GENERATING DEVASTATING FISH KILLS  THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY THE RANGE OF OPTIMAL TEMPERATURES WHERE C  SHASTA BENEFITS NATIVE FISH BY SERVING AS THE  ENEMY OF THEIR ENEMY   THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CONSERVATION PLANS WITH MAPS OF INVASIVE TROUT AND C  SHASTA AND FORECAST WHERE THEIR INTERACTIONS WILL CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR MANAGERS, BOTH NOW AND IN A WARMER FUTURE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE PROJECT TEAM WILL  1  MAP THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF REDBAND TROUT, INVASIVE TROUT, AND C  SHASTA IN THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN  THIS WILL HAVE IMMEDIATE UTILITY FOR RISK ASSESSMENT AND WILL CLOSE FUNDAMENTAL KNOWLEDGE GAPS FOR ONGOING CONSERVATION  NEXT, THEY WILL  2  RELATE THE PREVALENCE OF C  SHASTA AND INVASIVE SPECIES TO SPECIFIC HABITAT FEATURES AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, ESPECIALLY TEMPERATURE  THIS WILL INFORM RISKS TO FISHERIES UNDER FUTURE WARMING SCENARIOS  LASTLY, THEY WILL  3  IDENTIFY AREAS  UNDER CURRENT AND FUTURE CONDITIONS  WHERE C  SHASTA RESTRICTS THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE TROUT, THEREBY REDUCING PRESSURE ON NATIVE SALMONIDS  PROVIDED THE PARASITE LOAD ON NATIVE FISH IS LOW ENOUGH   THIS WILL ENABLE COLLABORATORS TO IDENTIFY PORTIONS OF THE UKB THAT ARE MOST LIKELY TO SUPPORT SUBSISTENCE FISHERIES IN A CHANGING CLIMATE, THEREBY GUIDING RESTORATION AND INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT DECISIONS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  PROJECT OUTPUTS OF SPECIFIC SCIENCE PRODUCTS INCLUDE 1  BASIN WIDE MAPS OF C  SHASTA, INVASIVE TROUT, AND REDBAND TROUT  DNA EXTRACTED FROM WATER SAMPLES  FOR C  SHASTA MAPPING  WILL ALSO BE RETAINED SO THAT FUTURE WORK COULD CHARACTERIZE THE DISTRIBUTION OF OTHER PATHOGENS AND TEST ALTERNATIVE HYPOTHESES 2  A HIERARCHICAL STATISTICAL MODEL ANALYZING HOW INVASIVE TROUT, C  SHASTA, TEMPERATURE, AND OTHER VARIABLES INTERACT TO SHAPE THE ABUNDANCE AND OR OCCUPANCY OF REDBAND TROUT  THIS MODEL WILL TEST FOR A 3 FACTOR INTERACTION AND DETERMINE THE TEMPERATURE THRESHOLDS AT WHICH C  SHASTA KILLS INVASIVE TROUT BUT NOT NATIVE TROUT 3  BASIN WIDE MAPS IDENTIFYING WHERE TEMPERATURES ARE BELOW, WITHIN, OR ABOVE THE THRESHOLDS REGULATING DISEASE INVASIVE SPECIES INTERACTIONS  WE WILL MAKE THESE MAPS FOR PRESENT DAY CONDITIONS AND FOR SCENARIOS OF WARMING INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT PARTNERING ORGANIZATIONS, THE KLAMATH TRIBES, THE OREGON DEPT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL SUBAWARD TO THE OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT

PROJECT TITLE  UNITING WESTERN RESTORATION STRATEGIES AND INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGES TO BUILD CAPACITY AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE ON THE NAVAJO NATIONPROJECT DATES  11 1 2022 THROUGH 10 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE  ACROSS THE NAVAJO NATION, SOIL AND VEGETATION MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE INTERACTING WITH CLIMATE CHANGE TO THE DETRIMENT OF ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION, HUMAN HEALTH, CULTURAL RESILIENCY, AND ECONOMIC WELL BEING  CONDUCTING ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION AND SHIFTING LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL ELEMENTS TO CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND DUST MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR THE NAVAJO NATION, HOWEVER, BARRIERS TO RESTORATION EXIST  RESTORATION IN DRYLANDS IS INCREDIBLY DIFFICULT AND NUANCED, REQUIRING THE USE OF APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGIES, THE INTEGRATION OF MULTIPLE TYPES OF KNOWLEDGE, THE PROJECT TITLE: THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE VULNERABILITY OF AT-RISK AMPHIBIANS TO DISEASE AND INVASIVE SPECIESPROJECT DATES: 8/15/2022 - 8/14/2025AWARD PURPOSE: THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST (PNW) IS A HOTSPOT FOR TEMPERATE AMPHIBIAN BIODIVERSITY. CLIMATE CHANGE THREATENS MANY OF THESE SPECIES AND CLIMATE-ADAPTATION STRATEGIES ARE BEGINNING TO BE INCORPORATED INTO MANAGEMENT PLANS. HOWEVER, CHANGING CLIMATIC CONDITIONS MAY ALSO INCREASE SUSCEPTIBILITY TO DISEASE AND INVASIVE SPECIES, BOTH OF WHICH THREATEN AT-RISK AMPHIBIANS IN THE PNW. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION ABOUT WHICH AMPHIBIAN SPECIES ARE MOST AT RISK FROM CLIMATE CHANGE, DISEASE, AND INVASIVE BULLFROGS, AND WHICH AREAS MAY REPRESENT REFUGES FROM THESE THREATS. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP STATE AND FEDERAL WILDLIFE AGENCIES DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR SPECIES CONSERVATION THAT ARE UNIQUELY SUITED TO THE MOST PROMINENT THREATS TO EACH SPECIES. THUS, THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE CLIMATE RESILIENCE FOR THESE THREATENED AND UNIQUE SPECIES, SO THAT THEY CAN MAINTAIN THEIR IMPORTANT ROLE IN PACIFIC NORTHWEST ECOSYSTEMS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FOR 14 AT-RISK AMPHIBIAN SPECIES FROM THROUGHOUT THE PNW THIS PROJECT WILL: 1) PREDICT CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED ALTERATIONS IN HABITAT SUITABILITY, 2) EVALUATE CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED SHIFTS IN DISEASE RISK ASSOCIATED WITH AMPHIBIAN CHYTRID PATHOGENS AND RANAVIRUS, 3) EVALUATE CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED SHIFTS IN RISKS OF INVASIVE AMERICAN BULLFROG, 4) CREATE MAPS IDENTIFYING HABITATS AND POPULATIONS AT HIGH RISK OF CLIMATE-DRIVEN CHANGES IN HABITAT SUITABILITY, DISEASE, AND BULLFROG INVASION, AS WELL AS POTENTIAL REFUGIA FROM THESE THREATS, AND 5) DEVELOP A SET OF SPECIES AND HABITAT-SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS THAT MAY REDUCE CLIMATE-DRIVEN RISK.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS, TECHNICAL AND PUBLIC FACT SHEETS, REPORTS, AND DATA PRODUCTS SUCH AS MAPS OF RISK AND UPDATED PATHOGEN OCCURRENCE DATA. THESE WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH USGS'S SCIENCEBASE AND OTHER PLATFORMS. FINDINGS WILL ALSO BE SHARED THROUGH WEBINARS AND A WORKSHOP, WITH THE GOAL OF PROVIDING CRITICAL INFORMATION ON RISK FOR SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND THOSE BEING CONSIDERED FOR LISTING, AND TO FACILITATE REVISIONS TO STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS (WHICH ARE SUPPOSED TO BE COMPLETE IN 2025).INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GOVERNMENT AND STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES, TRIBAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL SUBAWARD TO THE WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY TO EXECUTE THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSING VULNERABILITY OF VEGETATION AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES TO POST-FIRE TRANSFORMATIONS TO GUIDE MANAGEMENT OF SOUTHWESTERN FORESTS AND WOODLANDSPROJECT DATES: 10/1/2022 - 9/30/2024AWARD PURPOSE, ACTIVITIES, DELIVERABLES:WILDFIRES ARE AN ESSENTIAL AND FUNDAMENTAL PROCESS IN FORESTED ECOSYSTEMS ACROSS THE WESTERN U.S. BECAUSE MANY PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES HAVE EVOLVED WITH WILDFIRE OVER MILLENNIA AND DEVELOPED SPECIFIC ADAPTATIONS TO FIRE, THESE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS DEPEND ON NATURAL FIRE REGIMES. SOUTHWESTERN FORESTS ARE VITAL FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH, RECREATION, CLEAN WATER, AND MANY OTHER ECOSYSTEM SERVICES BUT HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY MEGA-FIRES IN RECENT DECADES. IN SOME PLACES, INTERACTIONS BETWEEN CLIMATE CHANGE AND HUMAN ACTIVITIES SUCH AS GRAZING, TIMBER PRODUCTION, AND FIRE SUPPRESSION HAS RESULTED IN EITHER A LACK OF FIRE OR FIRES THAT ARE UNCHARACTERISTICALLY FREQUENT OR SEVERE. THESE CHANGES HAVE MARKED CONSEQUENCES FOR ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION, ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, LOCAL HUMAN ECONOMIES, AND THE STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION OF WILDLIFE AND VEGETATION COMMUNITIES. FIRES CAN REDUCE DENSE WOODY BIOMASS AND CREATE LIGHT AND NUTRIENT CONDITIONS NEEDED TO SUPPORT COMPLEX FOOD WEBS THAT WILDLIFE DEPEND ON. TO BETTER MANAGE OUR FORESTS, THE MAIN GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW RECENT FIRES HAVE AFFECTED VEGETATION AND WILDLIFE BY ASSESSING FIRE IMPACTS IN A HISTORICAL AND ECOLOGICAL CONTEXT. DOING SO WILL REQUIRE MODELS BASED ON REMOTE SENSING AND FIELD DATA, WHICH THE PROJECT TEAM WILL GATHER AT DIFFERENT SPATIAL SCALES ACROSS THE SKY ISLANDS REGION AND MOGOLLON PLATEAU. THIS WILL INCLUDE INFORMATION ON CLIMATE, TOPOGRAPHY, VEGETATION STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION, AND WILDLIFE. A GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF WHERE, AND UNDER WHAT CONDITIONS WILDFIRE INCREASES HABITAT AVAILABILITY FOR VARIOUS BIRD SPECIES THAT EACH DEPEND ON DIFFERENT SETS OF RESOURCES AND CONDITIONS. BIRDS ARE EXCELLENT ECOLOGICAL INDICTORS DUE TO THEIR LINKAGES TO SPECIFIC RESOURCES AND CONDITIONS THAT PROVIDE FORAGING AND NESTING REQUIREMENTS. IN FIRE-ADAPTED ECOSYSTEMS OF THE SOUTHWESTER U.S., THESE REQUIREMENTS ARE RELATED TO FIRE HISTORIES THAT RESPOND TO CHANGES IN CLIMATE.EXPECTED OUTCOMES, INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):BY INTEGRATING COLLECTED DATA USING SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL MODELS THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP NEW KNOWLEDGE AND TRANSFER THIS INFORMATION TO RESOURCE MANAGERS IN BOTH THE U.S. AND MEXICO, INCLUDING THOSE FROM FIRST NATIONS. THEY WILL COLLABORATIVELY DEVELOP SETS OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WITH A BROAD RANGE OF MANAGERS AND STAKEHOLDERS SO THAT INFORMATION CAN BE APPLIED TO BETTER MANAGE AND CONSERVE OUR SOUTHWESTERN FORESTS AND WOODLANDS. AN IMPORTANT PRODUCT FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN INTERACTIVE ATLAS TO VISUALIZE VARIABILITY AND CHARACTERIZE RESPONSES OF VEGETATION AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES TO FIRE, HIGHLIGHT DEGREES OF VULNERABILITY OF VEGETATION AND ASSOCIATED WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES ACROSS BROAD AREAS, AND IDENTIFY LOCAL REFUGIA AND FACTORS THAT CREATE THEM SO AS TO FOCUS CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE COLLECTIVE BENEFIT IN THE REGION TOWARDS THE GOAL OF LIVING WITH FIRE IN OUR FORESTS AND THE METHODS THAT CAN BE EMPLOYED TO DO SO.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A
