PROJECT TITLE: UNDERSTANDING THE INTERSECTION OF CLIMATE VULNERABILITY AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN RURAL COMMUNITIES: A STUDY OF SOCIAL-ECOLOGICAL CONNECTIONSPROJECT DATES: 9/1/2022 THROUGH 8/31/2024AWARD PURPOSE, ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED, DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES, INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):THIS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE THE WAYS IN WHICH NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IS INTERSECTING WITH (THAT IS, EXACERBATING OR AMELIORATING) CLIMATE VULNERABILITY IN DISADVANTAGED RURAL COMMUNITIES IN THE NORTH CENTRAL GREAT PLAINS.THE PROPOSED TWO-YEAR PROJECT WILL USE ETHNOGRAPHIC METHODS TO INDUCTIVELY IDENTIFY COMMUNITIES THAT ARE DISADVANTAGED AND MOST VULNERABLE TO THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, AND THE WAY IN WHICH NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AFFECTS OR MAY AFFECT THOSE COMMUNITIES IN THE FUTURE. THE PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IN KANSAS. YEAR 1 WILL BE EXPLORATORY; THE PI WILL 1) REVIEW AND SYNTHESIZE EXISTING MEASURES OF SOCIAL AND CLIMATE VULNERABILITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL INJUSTICE, AND 2) CONDUCT INFORMAL AND SEMI-STRUCTURED INTERVIEWS WITH FEDERAL AND STATE RESOURCE MANAGERS, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, RURAL COMMUNITIES, AND TRIBAL MEMBERS. BASED ON THE FINDINGS DURING YEAR 1, YEAR 2 WILL FOCUS ON TWO SPECIFIC DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES AND USE MIXED METHODS TO FURTHER EXPLORE, IDENTIFY, AND UNDERSTAND THE WAY IN WHICH RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AFFECTS OR MAY AFFECT THESE COMMUNITIES.THESE EFFORTS WILL LAY A FOUNDATION FOR A LONG-TERM SOCIAL SCIENCE PROGRAM TO PROMOTE CONSIDERATION OF CLIMATE JUSTICE IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT BY 1) IDENTIFYING DISADVANTAGED GROUPS FOR STUDY AND ENGAGEMENT ON THIS TOPIC, 2) INCREASING UNDERSTANDING OF HOW RESOURCE MANAGERS CURRENTLY CONSIDER THE INTERSECTION BETWEEN THEIR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES, 3) IDENTIFYING OPPORTUNITIES FOR GREATER INCORPORATION OF CLIMATE JUSTICE CONSIDERATION IN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND 4) INCREASING CONNECTIONS BETWEEN DECISION MAKERS AND RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES. FINDINGS WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER-REVIEWED PAPERS AND SHARED THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AT CONFERENCES AND OTHER VENUES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

PROJECT TITLE: ON-DEMAND QUANTITATIVE CLIMATE SCENARIO SUMMARIES TOOL FOR SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS AND SCENARIO PLANNINGPROJECT DATES: 9/1/2022 THROUGH 8/31/2024PROJECT PURPOSE AND BENEFICIARIES: A RAPIDLY CHANGING CLIMATE DURING THIS CENTURY POSES A HIGH RISK FOR IMPACTS TO ECOSYSTEMS, BIODIVERSITY, AND TRADITIONAL LIVELIHOODS. A COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE DIFFERENT WAYS AND DEGREES TO WHICH VARIOUS ASPECTS OF CLIMATE (I.E., DIFFERENT CLIMATE METRICS SUCH AS TEMPERATURE, PRECIPITATION, HEAT STRESS AND OTHER EXTREME WEATHER METRICS) COULD CHANGE IS CRITICAL FOR A ROBUST ASSESSMENT OF RISKS AND EVALUATION OF ACTIONS TO MITIGATE THOSE RISKS. QUANTITATIVE CLIMATE INFORMATION OF SUCH NATURE IS HIGHLY DESIRED BY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS IN THE NORTH CENTRAL REGION, AND IN PARTICULAR THERE IS AN EVER-GROWING DEMAND FROM THE US FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE TO EFFECTIVELY CONDUCT THEIR SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS (SSAS), AS WELL AS OTHER SCENARIO PLANNING ACTIVITIES FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND CONSERVATION, PARTICULARLY THOSE CONDUCTED BY TRIBES AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. CURRENTLY, SUCH INFORMATION IS DEVELOPED MANUALLY BY SCIENTISTS EXTRACTING AND ANALYZING DIFFERENT DATASETS TO PRODUCE A COMPREHENSIVE QUANTITATIVE SUMMARY FOR DIFFERENT CLIMATE SCENARIOS. HOWEVER, THIS MODEL OF SERVICE IS NOT EFFICIENT IN MEETING THE GROWING DEMAND IN A TIMELY MANNER AND IS CHALLENGING THE CAPACITY OF THE HUMAN RESOURCES TO SERVE EFFECTIVELY.PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND DELIVERABLES: THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A HIGHLY-ACCESSIBLE AND WIDELY-APPLICABLE TOOL TO GENERATE ON-DEMAND QUANTITATIVE SUMMARIES FOR NUMEROUS ECOLOGICALLY-RELEVANT CLIMATE METRICS UNDER DIFFERENT FUTURE CLIMATE SCENARIOS TO MEET THE IMMEDIATE AND GROWING NEED FOR SUCH INFORMATION FOR REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS, AS WELL AS OTHER SCENARIO PLANNING ACTIVITIES FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND CONSERVATION. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP THIS TOOL USING THE EXISTING COMPUTATIONAL AND DATA-INTENSIVE PLATFORM PROVIDED BY THE CLIMATE TOOLBOX, WHICH IS A VERY HIGHLY RECOGNIZED DATA DELIVERY AND CLIMATE ANALYTIC TOOL. THE PROCESS OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS TOOL, INCLUDING DEVELOPING NEW DATASETS AND FUNCTIONALITIES FOR THE TOOL, AND ASSESSING ITS USABILITY WILL BE STRONGLY INFORMED BY REGULAR ENGAGEMENT WITH COOPERATORS (FROM USFWS, USNPS AND TRIBES) AT DIFFERENT STAGES OF THE PROJECT. THE TOOL WILL BE HOSTED ON THE HIGH-PROFILE CLIMATE TOOLBOX PLATFORM AND UTILIZE ITS EXISTING COMPUTATIONAL AND DATA-SUPPORT STRUCTURE WHICH WILL MAKE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS TOOL VERY EFFICIENT AND COST EFFECTIVE AND GUARANTEE ITS LONG-TERM MAINTENANCE. THE TOOL WILL ALSO ALLOW USERS TO DOWNLOAD SPATIAL DATA FOR USE IN SSA SPATIAL ANALYSES AND ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS MODELING FOR SELECTED REGIONS AND SCENARIOS. THE RESULTING OPEN-SOURCE TOOL WILL HAVE WIDE APPLICABILITY TO A VARIETY OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER-STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE CONTIGUOUS UNITED STATES THAT ARE INTERESTED IN (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) APPLYING SCENARIO-PLANNING APPROACHES TO CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND CONSERVATION.SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO WILL SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, MERCED, WHICH CREATE THE NEW TOOL AS WELL AS NEW WEB SERVICES AND DATASETS TO SUPPORT THE TOOL.

PROJECT TITLE: IMPACT OF CLIMATE DRIVEN WATER-LEVEL FLUCTUATIONS ON RECREATIONAL FISHERIES IN THE NORTHERN GLACIATED PLAINSPROJECT DATES: 10/1/2022 THROUGH 9/30/2024PROJECT PURPOSE AND BENEFICIARIES: THE NORTHERN GLACIATED PLAINS (NGP) OF THE UPPER MIDWEST, USA IS AN AREA WHERE FISHING GENERATES MILLIONS OF DOLLARS A YEAR FOR LOCAL AND STATE ECONOMIES. MAINTAINING THESE RESOURCES REQUIRES ANGLER-DESIRED FISH POPULATIONS AND ANGLER ACCESS TO FISHING SITES (BOAT RAMPS, PUBLIC LAND ACCESS). FISHERIES THROUGHOUT THE WORLD ARE CURRENTLY UNDERGOING UNPRECEDENTED CHANGES DUE TO WATER LEVEL FLUCTUATIONS AND ALTERED WATER QUALITY RESULTING FROM CLIMATE CHANGE. THE CONSEQUENCES OF CLIMATE CHANGE TO NGP FISHERIES ARE UNKNOWN BUT POSE AN IMMEDIATE CHALLENGE FOR RESOURCE MANAGERS AS ANGLER ACCESS AND OPPORTUNITIES CAN BE JEOPARDIZED WHEN BOAT RAMPS BECOME INACCESSIBLE DUE TO CHANGING WATER LEVELS AND ALTERED WATER QUALITY COULD NEGATIVELY AFFECT DESIRED FISH SPECIES. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE FISHERIES MANAGERS WITH INFORMATION ABOUT HOW CLIMATE CHANGE WILL ALTER THE HYDROLOGY OF NGP LAKES AND SUBSEQUENT CHANGES IN FISH COMMUNITIES, ANGLER ACCESS, ANGLER BEHAVIOR, AND ANGLER EXPENDITURES. A HYDROLOGIC MODEL WILL BE USED TO PREDICT CHANGES IN LAKE SIZE AND WATER QUALITY BASED ON WEATHER CONDITIONS UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS INFORMATION WILL THEN BE USED TO PREDICT CHANGES IN FISH COMMUNITIES, IDENTIFY CURRENT ANGLER ACCESS LOCATIONS THAT ARE AT RISK OF BECOMING INACCESSIBLE, DETERMINE WHETHER ANGLERS WILL CHANGE THE AMOUNT OF TIME THEY SPEND FISHING, AND HOW THESE CHANGES ULTIMATELY AFFECT THE AMOUNT OF MONEY ANGLERS SPEND. BY UNDERSTANDING WHICH LAKES WILL UNDERGO THESE CHANGES, FISHERIES MANAGERS WILL BE ABLE TO MAKE PROACTIVE DECISIONS AT STATE OR REGIONAL LEVELS ABOUT INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT (NUMBER AND LOCATION OF NEW BOAT RAMPS) AND ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT (SPECIES AND LOCATIONS OF FISH STOCKING) THAT WILL MAINTAIN ANGLER SATISFACTION AND THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF RECREATIONAL FISHERIES.PROJECT ACTIVITIES, DELIVERABLES, AND SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT WILL THEREFORE PROVIDE INFORMATION ON HOW CLIMATE CHANGE WILL AFFECT WATER LEVELS AND WATER QUALITY, FISH COMMUNITIES, AND ANGLER -OPPORTUNITY, -BEHAVIOR, AND -EXPENDITURES ON 240+ NGP LAKES. A NOVEL COLD REGION HYDROLOGIC MODEL DEVELOPED FROM HISTORICAL NGP DATA WILL PREDICT LANDSCAPE-LEVEL CHANGES IN HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS (LED BY UNIVERSITY OF NORTH DAKOTA - SUBAWARD; UND); THIS INFORMATION WILL SUPPORT MODELING THE SUBSEQUENT IMPACTS ON FISH COMMUNITIES (LED BY SOUTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY) AND ANGLERS (LED BY UND). THE PROJECT TEAM WILL MEET WITH PARTNERS BI-ANNUALLY SO THEY CAN DEVELOP MENTAL MODELS ON CLIMATE IMPACTS TO RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND CO-PRODUCE RESEARCH RESULTS, PRESENTATIONS, PUBLICATIONS, AND CONTRIBUTE TO STUDENT RESEARCH. DATA AND RESULTS CREATED FROM THIS WORK, INCLUDING MODEL OUTPUT DATASETS AND MAPS, WILL BE SHARED WITH PARTNERS VIA CLOUD-STORAGE SOFTWARE. THE PROJECT'S CROSS-DISCIPLINARY APPROACH WILL ENABLE FISHERY MANAGERS THE ABILITY TO DEVELOP MANAGEMENT PLANS THAT CAN PRIORITIZE WHERE TO CONSTRUCT AND MAINTAIN BOAT RAMPS, LAKES TO ACQUIRE, AND FISH STOCKING DECISIONS ACCORDING TO PREDICTED CHANGES IN LAKE HYDROLOGY, FISH COMMUNITIES, AND ANGLER BEHAVIOR.

PROJECT TITLE: CLIMATE ADAPTATION RESEARCH AND SERVICES FOR NEW MEXICOPROJECT DATES: 8/1/2022 - 7/31/2025AWARD PURPOSE: THE SOUTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (CASC) HAS WORKED DILIGENTLY TO BUILD NEW PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN SCIENTISTS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS TO HELP ADDRESS THE RESEARCH NEEDS AND QUESTIONS OF STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH ACTIONABLE SCIENCE. HOWEVER, THE GROWTH OF THE STAKEHOLDER BASE AND THE LOSS OF THE LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION COOPERATIVES HAS LED TO HAVING UNMET DEMAND FOR IMPLEMENTING DATA AND RESEARCH RESULTS FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, A RESEARCH SCIENTIST WILL INVESTIGATE CLIMATE ADAPTATION RESEARCH, DATA, AND SERVICES NEEDS OF STAKEHOLDERS AND PARTNERS TO HELP GENERATE SCIENCE-BASED DELIVERABLES THAT ALSO WILL BRIDGE THE RESEARCHER AND PRACTITIONER COMMUNITIES IN NEW MEXICO.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED, DELIVERABLES, AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE NEW MEXICO CLIMATE ADAPTATION SPECIALIST WILL COLLABORATE WITH GOVERNMENT, UNIVERSITY, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL RESEARCHERS IN NEW MEXICO AND ACROSS THE REGION TO CONDUCT RESEARCH, DATA MONITORING AND COLLECTION, DATA MANAGEMENT, VISUALIZATION, AND PRODUCT CREATION RELATED TO CLIMATE, CLIMATE IMPACTS, AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION. THEY WILL PROVIDE SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION TO STAKEHOLDERS AS THEY ADAPT TO, RESPOND TO, AND PLAN FOR CLIMATE CHANGE IN THEIR LOCAL JURISDICTIONS. THE SPECIALIST WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS FROM NEW MEXICO TO IDENTIFY INFORMATION GAPS, NEEDS FOR SCIENCE INFORMATION, PRODUCTS, DATASETS, DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS, ETC. TO ENSURE SCIENCE BECOMES ACTIONABLE AT THE LOCAL LEVEL. THEY WILL CONDUCT NOVEL RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIZE CURRENT RESEARCH ON IMPACTS AND ADAPTATION FOR ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THEY ALSO WILL CONVEY RESEARCH RESULTS ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE AND CLIMATE-RELATED TOPICS TO DIVERSE AUDIENCES, INCLUDING SCIENTISTS AND CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, IN READILY UNDERSTOOD AND USEABLE FORMS. PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS THAT SYNTHESIZE THE CURRENT KNOWLEDGE AND IDENTIFY RESEARCH GAPS RELATED TO CLIMATE IMPACTS ON DIFFERENT ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS WILL BE PRODUCED. IN ADDITION, CONCEPTUAL DIAGRAMS THAT ORGANIZE AND STRUCTURE THE EXISTING KNOWLEDGE WILL HELP THE BROADER CASC RESEARCH TEAM TO CONNECT THEIR WORK TO NEW MEXICO MANAGEMENT NEEDS WHERE APPLICABLE, FIND FUTURE COLLABORATORS, AND TRACK PROJECTS AND THEIR DELIVERABLES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT SEVERAL STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING FEDERAL/STATE/TRIBAL AGENCIES, NGOS, AND THE PUBLIC IN NEW MEXICO. THE NEW MEXICO CLIMATE ADAPTATION SPECIALIST WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO ENABLE THEIR USE OF MONITORING, ASSESSMENT, AND ADAPTATION TOOLS, RESOURCES, AND DATASETS, AS WELL AS GENERATE SCIENCE-BASED DISCUSSIONS AMONG THE USGS SOUTH CENTRAL CASC, USDA CLIMATE HUBS, NOAA RISAS, STATE CLIMATE OFFICES, AND OTHER REGIONAL CLIMATE PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THE INFORMATION NEEDS PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THIS PROJECT DOES NOT CONTAIN ANY SUB-AWARDS.

PROJECT TITLE: USING ORAL HISTORIES OF MARSHALLESE AND YAPESE VOYAGING TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT FOR SUSTAINABLE SEA TRANSPORTPROJECT DATES: 8/1/2022 - 1/31/2024PROJECT ACTIVITIES, DELIVERABLES, OUTCOMES: THERE IS A GROWING MOVEMENT IN THE PACIFIC TO DECARBONIZE SEA TRANSPORTATION. THE TRANSITION TO SUSTAINABLE SEA TRANSPORT IS PROJECTED TO REDUCE SOCIOECONOMIC VULNERABILITY TO EXTERNAL RISES IN OIL PRICES WHILE LOWERING CARBON EMISSIONS IN A PERIOD OF INTENSIFYING CLIMATE CHANGE. WITH POTENTIAL PERIODIC GLOBAL BREAKDOWNS IN TRANSPORT OF FUEL DUE TO POTENTIAL HAZARD DRIVERS SUCH AS GLOBAL PANDEMICS OR POLITICAL INSTABILITY, THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUSTAINABLE SHIPPING IS INCREASINGLY RELEVANT. CANOE ORGANIZATIONS IN THE REPUBLIC OF THE MARSHALL ISLANDS (RMI) AND THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA (FSM) ARE WORKING WITH THE MICRONESIAN CENTER FOR SUSTAINABLE TRANSPORT (MCST) TO RESTORE TRADITIONAL SYSTEMS OF VOYAGING AS INDIGENOUS MEANS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION. WHILE THERE IS DOCUMENTATION ON CANOES AND NAVIGATION, THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT THAT ONCE SUSTAINED VOYAGING NETWORKS REMAIN UNSTUDIED, ESPECIALLY CULTURAL SYSTEMS OF RESPECTED SOCIAL HIERARCHIES AND WOMEN'S CRITICAL ROLES IN SAIL MAKING, FOOD PREPARATION, AND OTHER SUPPORTIVE ACTIVITIES. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO UNDERSTAND HOW THE SOCIAL INSTITUTIONS AND NETWORKS EMBODIED IN PACIFIC VOYAGING SYSTEMS ONCE FACILITATED INFORMATION EXCHANGE SUCH AS THE SHARING OF MODELS OF CUSTOMARY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND MOBILIZING COLLECTIVE RESPONSES IN TIMES OF UNCERTAINTY. THE PROJECT COLLECTS ORAL HISTORIES TO DOCUMENT THE STORIES, MEMORIES, AND EXPERIENCES OF MARSHALLESE AND YAPESE PRACTITIONERS OF NAVIGATION, AND FACILITATES CONVERSATIONS AMONG THE STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP A TRANSFERRABLE CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT THAT WOULD CONTRIBUTE TO THE REESTABLISHMENT OF TRADITIONAL TRANSPORT AND SUPPORT THE DESIGN OF NEXT GENERATION SUSTAINABLE SEA TRANSPORT (SST).PROJECT BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT WITH THE REGIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICES AND CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS ON HAWAI'I ISLAND TO DOCUMENT INDIGENOUS TRANSPORTATION KNOWLEDGE AND STRENGTHEN CULTURAL IDENTITY WITHIN THE DIASPORIC POPULATIONS IN THE FACE OF ANTICIPATED CLIMATE CHANGE MIGRATIONS. TWO GRADUATE STUDENTS OF MARSHALLESE AND YAPESE HERITAGE WORKING TOWARDS THEIR MA DEGREES IN HERITAGE MANAGEMENT AT THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI'I AT HILO WILL PRODUCE MA RESEARCH THESES, PRESENTATIONS, PUBLICATIONS, ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS, AND THE TRANSFERRABLE CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO AND ADVANCE THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF ALL STAKEHOLDERS IN THE PACIFIC REGION FOR, AND WHO RELY ON, SUSTAINABLE SEA TRANSPORT.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

PROJECT TITLE: DROUGHT EARLY WARNING PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AND TESTINGPROJECT DATES: 7/18/2022 THROUGH 7/17/2024AWARD PURPOSE: DROUGHT IS A COMMON CONSEQUENCE OF CLIMATE VARIABILITY IN THE SOUTH-CENTRAL UNITED STATES. IN COMBINATION WITH INCREASING TEMPERATURES AND MORE VARIABLE PRECIPITATION IN THE FUTURE, DROUGHT WILL CONTINUE TO STRESS WATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY IN THIS REGION. A PILOT STUDY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT THE PALMER DROUGHT SEVERITY INDEX, A MEASURE OF LONG-TERM DROUGHT CONDITIONS, CAN BE FORECAST AT A CLIMATE DIVISION-LEVEL IN SOUTH-CENTRAL OKLAHOMA USING LARGER-SCALE CLIMATE DRIVERS, COMMONLY REFERRED TO AS "TELECONNECTIONS" IN THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY. TELECONNECTIONS SUCH AS THE EL NINO-SOUTHERN OSCILLATION, PACIFIC DECADAL OSCILLATION, AND ATLANTIC MULTIDECADAL OSCILLATION INFLUENCE PRECIPITATION PATTERNS HUNDREDS OR THOUSANDS OF MILES AWAY, INCLUDING IN THE SOUTH-CENTRAL U.S. THIS PROJECT TAKES ADVANTAGE OF THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN TELECONNECTIONS ACROSS THE EARTH AND PRECIPITATION IN THE FOUR STATES SERVED BY THE SOUTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (LOUISIANA, NEW MEXICO, OKLAHOMA, AND TEXAS) TO DEVELOP AN EXPERIMENTAL DROUGHT EARLY-WARNING PRODUCT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL ENGAGE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, INCLUDING FISH, WILDLIFE, AND WATER MANAGERS, ACROSS THE FOUR-STATE REGION TO GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT WHAT TYPE OF CLIMATE FORECASTS (IF ANY) HAVE BEEN USEFUL TO THEM IN THE PAST, WHAT LEAD TIMES THEY NEED AND WANT FOR PREPARING FOR DROUGHT, WHAT MONTHS OR SEASONS EARLY WARNING OF DROUGHT WOULD BE MOST USEFUL, AND WHETHER CLIMATE DIVISION-LEVEL INFORMATION IS HIGH ENOUGH RESOLUTION FOR THEM TO USE. USING A LARGE SET OF POSSIBLE TELECONNECTION INDICES, THE TEAM WILL THEN DEVELOP A SET OF STATISTICAL MODELS AND DETERMINE WHETHER THE FORECAST SKILL IS HIGH ENOUGH TO MEET THE MANAGERS' NEEDS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE (1) SPECIFIC DROUGHT FORECAST MODELS FOR EACH CLIMATE DIVISION, AS APPROPRIATE, IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL REGION; (2) GUIDANCE ON HOW THESE FORECASTS CAN BE USED BY MANAGERS THROUGH DISCUSSIONS ABOUT DROUGHT PREPAREDNESS WITH REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INTERACT DIRECTLY WITH NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AT THE BEGINNING AND END OF THE PROJECT TO ENSURE THAT ANY SUCCESSFUL DROUGHT FORECAST MODELS MEET THE NEEDS OF THE STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO ENGAGE WITH EXISTING PARTNERS WORKING IN NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES, COMMUNITIES, AND TRIBES WHO ARE CONCERNED ABOUT DROUGHT IMPACTS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS ON THIS PROJECT.

PROJECT TITLE: UNLOCKING RESILIENCE DRIVERS TO INFORM REEF MANAGEMENTPROJECT DATES: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 7/31/2024PROJECT ACTIVITIES, DELIVERABLES, OUTCOMES: THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO LEARN FROM PALMYRA ATOLL'S RESILIENT CORAL REEF ECOSYSTEM TO INFORM ACTIONS THAT IMPROVE CORAL RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE IMPACTS ELSEWHERE. PREVIOUS RESEARCH FROM PALMYRA ATOLL INDICATES THAT CORAL HETEROTROPHY MAY HAVE SUPPORTED HIGH CORAL SURVIVAL THROUGH PAST THERMAL STRESS EVENTS. ABUNDANT SEABIRDS SUPPLY PALMYRA'S REEFS WITH NUTRIENTS VIA THEIR GUANO, WHICH BOOSTS COASTAL PRODUCTIVITY - A HETEROTROPHIC FOOD RESOURCE FOR CORALS. THE BENEFIT OF SEABIRD-DERIVED NUTRIENTS TO CORALS WAS SURPRISING BECAUSE ANTHROPOGENIC NUTRIENT ENRICHMENT IN COASTAL WATERS IS TYPICALLY ASSOCIATED WITH NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO REEFS. FURTHER RESEARCH HAS INDICATED THAT CORAL REEFS NEAR DENSE SEABIRD POPULATIONS HAVE HIGHER GROWTH RATES AND ARE MORE RESILIENT TO THERMAL STRESS THAN SIMILAR REEFS WITH NO SEABIRD NUTRIENT INPUT. THEREFORE, CORAL REEFS APPEAR TO BE RESPONDING DIFFERENTLY TO NATURAL VS. ANTHROPOGENIC NUTRIENT SOURCES; THIS COULD INDICATE A DIFFERENCE IN THE, TYPICALLY, NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF NUTRIENTS ON CORALS OR A DIFFERENCE IN THE EFFECTS OF ZOOPLANKTON AVAILABILITY, AND FURTHER EXPLORATION IS NEEDED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW NATURAL NUTRIENT SUBSIDIES SUPPORT REEF RESILIENCE.THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THE RESPONSE OF CORALS TO DIFFERENT NUTRIENT SOURCES WITH AND WITHOUT HETEROTROPHIC FEEDING. WHILE THERE HAS BEEN SIGNIFICANT RESEARCH CONDUCTED ON THE EFFECTS OF NUTRIENT ENRICHMENT TO CORALS, THERE IS A GAP IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW DIFFERENT NUTRIENT SOURCES (NATURAL VS. ANTHROPOGENIC) AFFECT CORAL HEALTH AND RESILIENCE. A SECONDARY CONSERVATION GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO TEST IF THIS NATURAL NUTRIENT PATHWAY CAN BE SIMULATED USING OTHER, AVAILABLE RESOURCES, SUCH AS DISCARDED FISH WASTE FROM COMMERCIAL FISHING ACTIVITIES. THE FISH WASTE WILL BE RENDERED INTO A SOLUTION AND TESTED AS A NATURAL NUTRIENT REPLACEMENT FOR GUANO, AS SEABIRD POPULATIONS ARE IN DECLINE, AND GUANO IS NOT AVAILABLE EVERYWHERE.THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ACCLIMATE REPLICATE CORAL FRAGMENTS FROM MULTIPLE COLONIES (TO CONTROL FOR GENOTYPE) TO AMBIENT OR THREE NUTRIENT ADDITION TREATMENTS (+SEABIRD GUANO, +FISH SOLUTION, CONTROLLING FOR TOTAL N) FOR 4 WEEKS, EACH WITH AND WITHOUT THE ADDITION OF ARTEMIA AS A HETEROTROPHIC FOOD SOURCE. THE CORALS WILL THEN BE EXPOSED TO A 4-WEEK THERMAL STRESS EVENT, FOLLOWED BY A 4-WEEK RECOVERY PERIOD TO CHARACTERIZE RESILIENCE TO BLEACHING, AND CORAL FRAGMENTS OF EACH GENOTYPE X TREATMENT WILL BE COLLECTED AT THE END OF THE ACCLIMATION PERIOD, AT THE END OF THE BLEACHING PERIOD, AND AT THE END OF THE RECOVERY PERIOD. WE WILL MEASURE CORAL SURVIVAL, GROWTH, TISSUE CONDITION, AND ENDOSYMBIONT DENSITY AS METRICS FOR CORAL RESILIENCE. CORALS HAVE THE ABILITY TO INCORPORATE NUTRIENTS BY DIRECT UPTAKE FROM THE WATER AND FROM THE FOOD THEY EAT. STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSIS OF THE CORALS, THEIR ENDOSYMBIONTS, AND THE ARTEMIA WILL INDICATE IF THE CORALS ARE SWITCHING FROM AUTOTROPHIC TO HETEROTROPHIC FEEDING DURING THE EXPERIMENT.PROJECT BENEFICIARIES: PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BENEFIT AGENCIES AND REEF MANAGERS THAT ARE ACTIVELY MANAGING PACIFIC CORAL REEF ECOSYSTEMS, AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

PROJECT TITLE: CLIMATE MICROAPPS - ASSESSMENT AND INNOVATION IN CLIMATE DECISION SUPPORT TOOLSPROJECT DATES: 9/1/2022 - 8/31/2023AWARD DESCRIPTION AND INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):: THE QUANTITY AND AVAILABILITY OF WEATHER- AND CLIMATE-RELATED DATA HAS GROWN DRAMATICALLY OVER THE PAST DECADE DUE IN PART TO IMPROVEMENTS IN COMPUTING SPEED, INTERNET BANDWIDTH AND DATA VISUALIZATION TOOLS. THIS HAS MADE IT CHALLENGING FOR DECISION MAKERS LIKE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TO FIND AND ACCESS RELEVANT DATA AND FOR CLIMATE SERVICE PROVIDERS TO DEVELOP USEFUL DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS (DSTS) THAT PROVIDE ACCESS TO THESE RELEVANT DATA. IN THIS PROJECT, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL EXAMINE OPEN SOURCE, DATA ACCESS TOOLS AND PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES (E.G. R AND PYTHON) THAT PROMOTE USE OF INCREASINGLY DIVERSE WEATHER AND CLIMATE DATASETS, AND TO LEVERAGE THESE TOOLS IN THE CREATION OF NEW RAPIDLY PROTOTYPED CUSTOM DSTS AND CLIMATE SERVICES. TO DEVELOP AND TEST THESE IDEAS, THE TEAM WILL WORK WITH RANGE MANAGERS IN THE SOUTHWESTERN U.S. WHO ARE SOPHISTICATED CONSUMERS OF WEATHER AND CLIMATE INFORMATION. BASED ON AN ASSESSMENT OF TOOLS AND INFORMATION THEY ALREADY USE, ALTERNATE MODES OF PROVIDING WEATHER AND CLIMATE DATA WILL BE EXPLORED BY USING THESE SIMPLE DATA QUERY AND VISUALIZATION TOOLS. LESSONS LEARNED FROM THIS RAPID ASSESSMENT AND CLIMATE SERVICES DEVELOPMENT WILL BE DETAILED IN A BEST-PRACTICES REPORT AND PUBLISHED MANUSCRIPT FOR PUBLIC AND STAKEHOLDER BENEFIT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED, DELIVERABLES, AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE HOW WEATHER AND CLIMATE DATA ACCESS SYSTEMS LIKE THE REGIONAL CLIMATE CENTER-APPLIED CLIMATE INFORMATION SYSTEM (RCC-ACIS) AND OPEN SOURCE DEVELOPMENT TOOLS LIKE R-SHINY CAN BE BROUGHT TOGETHER TO QUICKLY PROTOTYPE CUSTOM DATA ACCESS AND VISUALIZATION TOOLS FOR SPECIFIC PURPOSES BASED ON THE NEEDS EXPRESSED BY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS IN MIX OF FORMAL INTERVIEWS, INFORMAL CONVERSATIONS, AND SURVEY RESPONSES. THIS MODE OF CLIMATE SERVICES DEVELOPMENT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO QUICKLY AND FLEXIBLY CONNECT AN EVER-INCREASING ARRAY OF CLIMATE DATA AND INFORMATION TO MANAGERS WHO HAVE LITTLE TIME TO LEARN COMPLEX DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS, BUT WHO DECIDEDLY WANT TO INCORPORATE THIS INFORMATION INTO THEIR DECISION MAKING AND PLANNING. PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE LESSONS LEARNED FROM THE ASSESSMENTS AND WILL BE DETAILED IN A REPORT AND PUBLISHED MANUSCRIPT AND ALL OF TOOLS AND CODE WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE IN AN OPEN SOURCE REPOSITORY.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD: N/A

PROJECT TITLE: ANTICIPATING CLIMATE-DRIVEN SPREAD AND IMPACT OF MULTIPLE INTERACTING INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER BASINPROJECT DATES: 8/15/2022 THROUGH 8/14/2024PROJECT SUMMARY:A PERSISTENT MANAGEMENT QUESTION IS WHETHER CURRENT CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING WILL REMAIN ROBUST WHEN FACING A GROWING NUMBER OF INVASIVE SPECIES. THE CONCERN IS THAT CURRENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT FOCUS EXCLUSIVELY ON SINGLE INVASIVE SPECIES AND OVERLOOK CLIMATE DRIVEN BIOLOGICAL INTERACTIONS, MAY LEAD TO POOR DECISIONS. BY DELIVERING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE, THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY INFORMS SPECIFIC PLANNING, MANAGEMENT, AND DECISION NEEDS OF TRIBAL AND GOVERNMENTAL PARTNERS WORKING IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN. FIRST, RESEARCHERS WILL ASSESS THE INFORMATION NEEDS FOR, AND BARRIERS TO, EFFECTIVE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN. THIS HELPS SYNTHESIZE KNOWLEDGE AND BUILD COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG STAKEHOLDERS FACING SIMILAR INVASIVE SPECIES CHALLENGES. SECOND, RESEARCHERS WILL DEVELOP EARLY WARNING INDICATORS THAT COMBINE SPATIAL MODELS WITH CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECTIONS TO HELP INFORM MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO REDUCE THE SPREAD AND IMPACT OF MULTIPLE INVASIVE SPECIES - SMALLMOUTH BASS AND RUSTY CRAYFISH - ON JUVENILE CHINOOK SALMON IN THE JOHN DAY RIVER, OREGON. CLIMATE CHANGE IS POSED TO BOTH DIRECTLY AFFECT JUVENILE CHINOOK SALMON AND POTENTIALLY AMPLIFY THE IMPACT OF THESE INTERACTING INVASIVE SPECIES, WHO THEMSELVES MAY PROMOTE EACH OTHER'S CONTINUED SPREAD. MODEL-DERIVED EARLY WARNING INDICATORS ALLOW MANAGERS TO BETTER ANTICIPATE INVADER OUTBREAKS AND SUBSTANTIAL ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS. WORKING WITH PARTNERS IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER INTER-TRIBAL FISH COMMISSION, CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE WARM SPRINGS RESERVATION OF OREGON, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, RESEARCHERS WILL DEVELOP AND TEST REALISTIC CLIMATE-ENLIGHTENED MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS THAT DRAW ON THESE METHODS TO MINIMIZE THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND IMPACTS ON SALMON. IN SUMMARY, THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO INCREASE OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT THE ECOLOGICAL OUTCOMES OF INTERACTING INVASIVE SPECIES, AND DEVELOP CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES THAT CAN ACCOMMODATE UNCERTAINTY, AND BUILD RESISTANCE AND ENHANCE THE RESILIENCE OF FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS PROJECT SEEKS A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE DYNAMICS OF TWO EXPANDING INVADERS - SMALLMOUTH BASS AND RUSTY CRAYFISH- AND THEIR COMBINED IMPACTS ON JUVENILE CHINOOK SALMON, TO HELP INFORM CLIMATE-ENLIGHTENED MANAGEMENT. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: A SURVEY OF INVASIVE SPECIES PRACTITIONERS IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN; PARAMETERIZATION OF MULTI-SPECIES, INDIVIDUAL-BASED POPULATION MODELS, HORIZON SCANNING EXERCISES, MANAGEMENT SCENARIO DEVELOPMENT, AND MONITORING TRAINING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DELIVERABLES INCLUDE GEOSPATIAL LAYERS AND ANIMATED MAPS OF PROJECTED SPREAD OF INVADER AND SALMON POPULATIONS UNDER DIFFERENT CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS, KNOWLEDGE TRANSFER VIA WEBINARS, PRESENTATIONS, PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND COMMUNICATION USING DEDICATED OUTREACH MATERIALS AND SOCIAL MEDIA.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE MANAGEMENT NEEDS OF SEVERAL TRIBAL AND GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS BY PROVIDING ACTIONAL SCIENCE THAT ALLOWS THE INTEGRATION OF THE ANTICIPATED EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE INTO INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. IT INVOLVES CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH THE COLUMBIA RIVER INTER-TRIBAL FISH COMMISSION, CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE WARM SPRINGS RESERVATION OF OREGON, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE.

PROJECT TITLE: EVALUATION OF NETWORK TOOLS TO ADVANCE CLIMATE ADAPTATION IN THE SOUTHWESTPROJECT DATES: 9/1/2022 - 8/31/2023PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION AWARD PURPOSE: THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF ONLINE DECISION INFORMATION TOOLS DESIGNED TO AID NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ADAPTATIONS TO CLIMATE CHANGE, THAT ARE SUPPORTED BY THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NETWORK OF PRACTICE TO GENERATE COLLABORATIVE SOLUTIONS TO COMPLEX CLIMATE CHALLENGES. NETWORKS CAN AID ADAPTATION BY MOBILIZING LEADERSHIP, ENHANCING THE FLOW OF INFORMATION AND GENERATING MORE ACTIONS THAT LEAD TO ADAPTATION BREAKTHROUGHS. THIS PROJECT'S RESEARCH WILL EVALUATE FIVE NETWORK TOOLS IN THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES, WITH THE GOAL OF PROVIDING GUIDANCE TO INCREASE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF NETWORK TOOLS TO ACHIEVE ADAPTATION OUTCOMES. NETWORK TOOLS WILL BE EVALUATED THROUGH INTERVIEWS AND SURVEYS WITH NETWORK COORDINATORS AND NETWORK TOOL USERS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ANALYZE INTERVIEW AND SURVEY DATA FOR EVIDENCE OF: THE BENEFITS OF AND BARRIERS TO TOOL USE, THE CREDIBILITY OF INFORMATION AND OUTPUT FROM THE TOOLS, CAPACITY FOR LEARNING THROUGH USE OF THE TOOLS, AND SKILLS OR EXPERTISE GAINED THROUGH THE USE OF THE TOOLS. USING SOCIAL NETWORK ANALYSIS METHODS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO VISUALIZE CONNECTIVITY AMONG THE NETWORK PARTICIPANTS AND ANALYZE THE IMPACT OF CONNECTIVITY ON LEARNING, COLLABORATION, AND PARTNERSHIPS. IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT NETWORK TOOLS HAVE ENHANCED INFORMATION FLOWS AND MAINTAINED OR ENHANCED CONNECTIVITY AMONG PARTICIPANTS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROJECT'S EVALUATION REPORT AND SUMMARY WEBINAR WILL BENEFIT NETWORK COORDINATORS AND STAKEHOLDERS BY PROVIDING INSIGHTS ON THE USES, CHALLENGES, AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVING AND ENHANCING NETWORK TOOLS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: DATA COLLECTION AND RESEARCH INCLUDES SIX ACTIVITIES: (1) GATHER AND REVIEW EXISTING LITERATURE AND INFORMATION ON NETWORK TOOLS AND DEVELOP A DATABASE; (2) COLLECT IN-DEPTH NETWORK COORDINATOR AND ACTIVE NETWORK MEMBER INTERVIEW DATA (N=25), TO GAIN INSIGHTS INTO THE NETWORKS AND TOOLS; (3) COLLECT SURVEY DATA, WITH 40% OF NETWORK PARTICIPANTS, TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE TOOLS; (4) EVALUATE INTERACTIONS AMONG NETWORK MEMBERS, USING SOCIAL NETWORK ANALYSIS; (5) EVALUATE QUALITATIVE AND NETWORK DATA AGAINST NETWORK EFFECTIVENESS METRICS; (6) SYNTHESIZE RESULTS IN REPORTS AND WEBINAR PRESENTATIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE EXPECTED RESULTS AND PRODUCTS FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE A PUBLIC REPORT THAT SUMMARIZES AND SYNTHESIZES PROJECT FINDINGS (INCLUDING SOCIAL NETWORK MAPS, FIGURES, AND DATA TABLES); PUBLIC WEBINARS; A PUBLICLY AVAILABLE REVISED NETWORK AND TOOL DATABASE; INFORMATION SHARED WITH NETWORK COORDINATORS TO IMPROVE TOOL AND NETWORK SERVICES; AND INCREASED STAKEHOLDER AWARENESS ABOUT THE CAPACITIES, USES, AND EFFECTIVENESS OF NETWORK TOOLS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): STAKEHOLDERS WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE COORDINATORS OF THE FIVE NETWORKS EVALUATED THROUGH THE RESEARCH, AS WELL AS MEMBERS AND PARTNERS OF THE SELECTED NETWORKS. OTHER BENEFICIARIES ARE REGIONAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, RESEARCHERS, PRACTITIONERS WHO USE OR REFERENCE NETWORK TOOLS, CLIMATE ADAPTATION STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE PUBLIC.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD: N/A

PROJECT TITLE: MANAGING THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND LAND LOSS ON NATIVE AMERICAN ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES IN COASTAL LOUISIANAPROJECT DATES: 8/1/2022 - 9/31/2024AWARD PURPOSE: NATIVE AMERICAN ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES ON LOUISIANA'S GULF COAST ARE ENDANGERED AND BEING DESTROYED BY SEA-LEVEL RISE, COASTAL EROSION, AND CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE CULTURAL RESOURCES ARE CRUCIAL SOURCES OF INFORMATION AND REPRESENT THE UNIQUE HERITAGE OF COASTAL LOUISIANA. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CHITIMACHA TRIBE OF LOUISIANA AND WORKING WITH TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, A TEAM OF ARCHAEOLOGISTS, CLIMATE SCIENTISTS, GEOLOGISTS, AND ENGINEERS FROM LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY (LSU), TULANE UNIVERSITY, UNIVERSITY OF LOUISIANA AT LAFAYETTE (ULL), IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, WILL ASSESS CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITIES FOR THE IMPENDING LOSS OF THESE IRREPLACEABLE CULTURAL RESOURCES. SINCE SITE DESTRUCTION IS ONGOING AND INCREASING DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, THIS PROJECT IS EXTREMELY URGENT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS COLLABORATIVE, INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH WILL GENERATE AN UP-TO-DATE, CLIMATE-INFORMED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT AND ACTIONABLE MEASURES FOR RESOURCE MANAGERS AND STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH: (1) AN OVERVIEW OF THE EXISTING ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL LITERATURE ON LOUISIANA'S GULF COAST, (2) IDENTIFICATION OF GAPS IN PRESENT KNOWLEDGE, (3) ASSESSMENT OF THE FUTURE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, SLR, AND COASTAL LAND LOSS ON CULTURAL RESOURCES, AND (4) DEVELOPMENT OF PROGRAMMATIC, REGION-WIDE CRM PLAN FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, WITH ALTERNATIVE MITIGATION STRATEGIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ADDRESSING PREDICTED IMPACTS. A GIS-BASED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT WILL INVOLVE THE ENGAGEMENT OF STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH CONSULTATIONS, WORKSHOPS, VIRTUAL MEETINGS, AND WEBINARS. IDENTIFICATION OF AT-RISK SITES WILL BE INFORMED BY RECONNAISSANCE AND SITE MONITORING IN RAPIDLY CHANGING COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS RESEARCH WILL GENERATE (1) A GIS-BASED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT AND RISK MATRIX OF SITES IN THE MRD AND LOUISIANA CZ, AND (2) A PROGRAMMATIC, REGION-WIDE CRM PLAN THAT INCLUDES (A) AN OVERVIEW OF EXISTING ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, (B) IDENTIFICATION OF GAPS IN PRESENT KNOWLEDGE, (C) PREDICTIVE MODELING OF THE EFFECTS OF RELATIVE SLR AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON CULTURAL RESOURCES, (D) A CLIMATE INFORMED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT, AND (E) ALTERNATIVE MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, WITH RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ADDRESSING PREDICTED IMPACTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, RESOURCE MANAGERS, COASTAL COMMUNITIES, REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION ON ENDANGERED CULTURAL RESOURCES AND CLIMATE-INFORMED MANAGEMENT. THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND APPRECIATION OF THE DEEP HISTORY, CULTURAL HERITAGE, AND ECOLOGY OF LOUISIANA'S GULF COAST, WHICH ALSO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF THE CULTURAL ECONOMY. THE INTERDISCIPLINARY PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH TRIBAL AND COASTAL COMMUNITIES IN CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANNING AND ADVISE RESOURCE MANAGERS AND STAKEHOLDERS ON WHERE AND HOW TO DIRECT LIMITED RESOURCES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: LSU TEAM WILL DIRECT DATA COLLECTION, MODEL DEVELOPMENT, AND ORGANIZE WORKSHOPS AND WEBINARS. ULL WILL CONTRIBUTE TO CRM PLANNING THROUGH AN OVERVIEW OF EXISTING KNOWLEDGE AND COLLABORATION. TULANE WILL PRODUCE A GIS-BASED RISK MATRIX AND CLIMATE-INFORMED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT.

PROJECT TITLE: ENHANCING A SPATIAL PLANNING TOOL TO SUPPORT RESERVOIR FISHERIES, INSTREAM FLOWS, AND SOCIETAL WATER NEEDS IN THE RED RIVER.PROJECT DATES: 8/15/2022 - 8/14/2024AWARD PURPOSE: ENSURING THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF WATER RESOURCES REQUIRES CAREFUL STEWARDSHIP OF WATER FOR HUMAN USES (I.E., MUNICIPAL, AGRICULTURAL, AND INDUSTRIAL SECTORS) AND ALSO FOR THE BENEFITS THAT HUMANS DERIVE FROM AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS. IN PARTICULAR, RESERVOIR FISHERIES AND RIVERINE ECOSYSTEMS PROVIDE A RANGE OF ECONOMIC, CULTURAL, AND RECREATIONAL BENEFITS TO HUMANS. MAXIMIZING THE BENEFITS THAT WE RECEIVE FROM WATER WILL THEREFORE ENTAIL BALANCING SOCIETAL USES, RESERVOIR STORAGE, AND RIVER FLOWS. CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO COMPLICATE THE CHALLENGE OF FINDING A BALANCE AMONG THESE THREE DIMENSIONS OF WATER SUSTAINABILITY. TO NAVIGATE THESE CHALLENGES, STAKEHOLDERS NEED FRAMEWORKS FOR SIMULTANEOUSLY PREDICTING THE EFFECTS OF CHANGING WATER AVAILABILITY ON BIODIVERSITY AND ON SOCIETAL WATER NEEDS. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A SPATIAL PLANNING TOOL THAT WILL ALLOW STAKEHOLDERS TO EXPLORE HOW CLIMATE AND WATER USE SCENARIOS IMPACT SOCIETAL WATER SATISFACTION, RESERVOIR FISHERIES AND STREAM FLOWS IN THE RED RIVER BASIN.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: OVER THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS, THE PROJECT TEAM HAS LEVERAGED PREVIOUS SOUTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER MODELS AND DATA TO BUILD A SPATIAL PLANNING TOOL FOR BALANCING SOCIETAL WATER NEEDS AND STREAM FLOWS. IN THIS PROJECT, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL EXTEND THAT WORK TO EXPLICITLY MODEL THE IMPACTS OF WATER USE AND CLIMATE ON FISHES IN RESERVOIRS AND STREAMS. TO DO THAT, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL 1) ENHANCE THE HYDROLOGIC COMPONENTS OF THE MODEL TO EXPLICITLY REPRESENT WATER ELEVATION, TEMPERATURE AND OXYGEN IN RESERVOIRS, AND 2) USE A TRAIT-BASED APPROACH TO PREDICT THE IMPACTS OF THOSE RESERVOIRS CONDITIONS ON FISHES, AND ON STREAM FISHES. THE INTEGRATED MODELING FRAMEWORK WILL ALLOW STAKEHOLDERS TO IDENTIFY WATER SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGIES THAT ARE RESILIENT TO FUTURE CLIMATE UNCERTAINTY AND MAXIMIZE THE POTENTIAL FOR BALANCING SOCIETAL WATER NEEDS, RESERVOIRS, AND STREAM FLOWS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PRIMARY OUTPUT OF THE PROJECT WILL BE A SPATIAL PLANNING TOOL THAT WILL ENABLE STAKEHOLDERS TO EXPLORE HOW WATER MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS IMPACT SOCIETAL WATER NEEDS AND RESERVOIR AND STREAM FISHES. IN WORKSHOPS, STAKEHOLDER INPUT WILL BE SOLICITED ON HOW BEST TO MAKE THE PLANNING TOOL AND SCENARIOS ANALYSES AVAILABLE; OPTIONS RANGE FROM STATIC WEB PAGES TO INTERACTIVE WEB TOOLS DEVELOPED USING R SHINY. FINAL DATA SETS WILL BE ARCHIVED IN USGS SCIENCEBASE. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE 4-6 PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS AND A FINAL WRITTEN REPORT.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM A WIDE RANGE OF DECISIONS RELATED TO WATER SUSTAINABILITY IN THE RED RIVER, INCLUDING SOCIETAL WATER USE AND THE MANAGEMENT OF FISHES IN RESERVOIRS AND STREAMS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS EL-PASO WILL LEAD THE HYDROLOGIC MODELING OF RESERVOIRS. FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY WILL COLLABORATE ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MATHEMATICAL OPTIMIZATION MODEL FOR EXPLORING WATER USE SCENARIOS.

PROJECT TITLE: TECHNICAL ASSESSMENT OF CLIMATE SCIENCE NEEDS IN THE MIDWESTPROJECT DATES: 5/23/2022 - 5/22/2023AWARD PURPOSE: THE STRATEGIC SCIENCE AGENDA THAT WILL GUIDE THE MIDWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER'S (CASC) WORK FOR 2021-2026 IS AT AN INTERIM STAGE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS FROM THE MIDWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER CONSORTIUM TO CONDUCT A TECHNICAL ASSESSMENT (EVALUATION AND REVIEW) OF THE INTERIM SCIENCE PRIORITIES. THIS INCLUDES AN ASSESSMENT OF HOW MUCH IS KNOWN ABOUT THESE PRIORITIES, ADDITIONAL SCIENCE GAPS THAT MIGHT EXIST OR EMERGE IN THE COMING YEARS, AND THE PRIORITIES MOST RELEVANT FOR REDUCING UNCERTAINTY FOR MIDWEST CLIMATE RELATED ISSUES. USING SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS, DATA ON EXPERTS' ASSESSMENT OF THE CURRENT PRIORITIES WILL BE SOLICITED, INCLUDING ABOUT THE QUALITY AND EXTENT OF EXISTING KNOWLEDGE, AND THE FEASIBILITY AND IMPORTANCE OF POTENTIAL RESEARCH. THE PROJECT TEAM ALSO WILL EXAMINE PUBLISHED LITERATURE TO ILLUMINATE FINDINGS ON ADAPTING TO CLIMATE IN THE MIDWEST. THE DATA WILL BE USED TO HELP ENSURE THAT THE MIDWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER'S RESEARCH PRIORITIES ARE INFORMED BY CURRENT SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING, TECHNICAL COMPLEXITY, AND OPPORTUNITY FOR IMPACT - AND THAT THEY CAPTURE THE FULL RANGE OF RELEVANT ISSUES AND ARE ATTENTIVE TO EMERGING CONCERNS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:A THREE-STAGE PROCESS FOR THE TECHNICAL ASSESSMENT WILL BE UTILIZED:I. SURVEY UNIVERSITY, STATE, TRIBAL AND FEDERAL/USGS RESEARCHERS AND OTHER EXPERTS TO IDENTIFY IMPORTANT SCIENCE QUESTIONS FOR THE MIDWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (CASC).II. GROUP SIMILAR RESPONSES FROM STAGE I, AND CROSSWALK THEM WITH THE CASC'S INTERIM SCIENCE PRIORITIES. THIS UPDATED LIST WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE USGS. THE USGS WILL DETERMINE IF THE INTERIM LIST SHOULD BE REVISED OR IF ANY NEW ITEMS SHOULD BE ADDED, WHICH WILL INFORM STAGE III.III. INVITE THE EXPERTS FROM STAGE I TO GROUP MEETINGS TO CHARACTERIZE THE NEW, COMBINED LIST OF SCIENCE PRIORITIES ALONG THREE AXES: (1) STATE OF KNOWLEDGE, (2) TECHNICAL COMPLEXITY AND FEASIBILITY OF ANSWERING THE QUESTION, AND (3) OPPORTUNITY FOR IMPACT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A REPORT OF THE SCIENCE AGENDA TECHNICAL ASSESSMENT. THIS REPORT WILL INCLUDE THE METHODS AND OUTCOMES OF THE TECHNICAL ASSESSMENT PROCESS, INCLUDING MAJOR RESEARCH QUESTIONS, THEMATIC GAPS AND SCIENCE OPPORTUNITIES. EACH SCIENCE PRIORITY WILL BE CHARACTERIZED USING SOLICITED DATA ON SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING, TECHNICAL COMPLEXITY, AND OPPORTUNITY FOR IMPACT. THIS REPORT ALSO WILL INCLUDE AN ASSESSMENT OF HOW THE RESEARCH PRIORITIES ALIGN WITH THE STAGES OF THE ADAPTATION CYCLE.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE MAIN BENEFICIARY OF THIS PROJECT IS THE MIDWEST CASC, ITS STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE PUBLIC. THIS ASSESSMENT WILL HELP FOCUS AND PRIORITIZE CASC FUNDING AND OUTREACH IN ORDER TO STRATEGICALLY IMPACT CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE IN THE REGION. RESULTS WILL ALSO BE SHARED AT CASC MEETINGS, TO OTHER REGIONS IN THE NATIONAL CASC NETWORK, AND AT A NATIONAL OR REGIONAL MEETING.

PROJECT TITLE: EXAMINING DIVERSE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AND BROADENING STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANNING OF HISTORIC STRUCTURES WITHIN THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEMPROJECT PERIOD: 9/1/2022 - 8/31/2024PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: THIS PROJECT INCLUDES AN ARRAY OF RESEARCH ACTIVITIES TO EXPAND UPON A CLIMATE ADAPTATION DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORK, THE OPTIMAL PRESERVATION (OPTIPRES) MODEL. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DEFINING A RANGE OF MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AND SET OF ADAPTATION ACTIONS TO TEST USING A CO-PRODUCTION OF SCIENCE PROCESS DURING A COLLABORATIVE WORKSHOP WITH NATIONAL PARK SERVICE STAFF, NORTH CAROLINA STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE STAFF, AND REPRESENTATIVES FROM TWO FORMAL PARTNERS WITH SPECIFIC TIES TO THE HISTORIC DISTRICTS AT CAPE LOOKOUT NATIONAL SEASHORE; (2) ASSESSING THE ACCEPTABILITY OF THE ADAPTATION ACTIONS USING ONLINE SERVICE RESEARCH METHODOLOGY WITH MEMBERS OF THE TWO PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS; (3) OBTAINING ESTIMATED COSTS FOR THE ADAPTATION ACTIONS AFFILIATED WITH THE FULL COMPLEMENT OF STRUCTURES LOCATED IN THE TWO HISTORIC DISTRICTS TO ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMPLEX TRADEOFFS THAT NEED TO BE MADE WHEN FUNDING FOR ADAPTATION IS LIMITED; (4) CREATING A RANGE OF STORMINESS SCENARIOS FOR THE NEXT 30 YEARS (SUBRECIPIENT); (5) UPDATING VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT DATA AND DETERMINING STORM-RELATED IMPACTS TO THE STRUCTURES AND ASSOCIATED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS (SUBRECIPIENT); (6) UPDATING MODEL DYNAMICS, MODELING BUDGET SCENARIOS, AND CREATING VISUALIZATIONS OF TRADEOFFS (SUBRECIPIENT); (7) EVALUATING BROADER STAKEHOLDER REACTIONS TO TRADEOFF VISUALIZATIONS DURING AN OUTREACH WORKSHOP; (8) COMPARING TRADEOFFS AMONG AND BETWEEN THE SCENARIOS TO GENERATE GENERALIZATIONS TO APPLY TO THE BROADER NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE A FINAL PROJECT REPORT, A MINIMUM OF TWO (2) MANUSCRIPTS PREPARED FOR SUBMISSION TO A REFEREED JOURNAL, PROJECT BRIEFING MATERIALS (E.G. POWERPOINT SLIDE DECK), A PUBLIC WEBINAR, AND A TRANSFERABILITY FACTSHEET. THESE PRODUCTS WILL PROVIDE AN ARRAY OF VISUALIZATIONS OF OPTIPRES MODEL OUTPUTS TO ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMPLEXITY OF MANAGEMENT TRADEOFFS AND THE OPTIMAL SEQUENCING OF ADAPTATION UNDER DIFFERENT BUDGET CONSTRAINTS. THE BROADER STAKEHOLDER OUTREACH WORKSHOP WILL DISSEMINATE PROJECT RELATED INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC ON THE VULNERABILITY OF HISTORIC STRUCTURES IN COASTAL ZONES AND SHOULD ENABLE INSIGHTS INTO THE PUBLIC PERCEPTIONS OF THIS DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORK FOR FUTURE ADAPTATION PLANNING AND DECISION MAKING EFFORTS. BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE: THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, OTHER CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS, PARK PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS INTERESTED IN THE PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT OF HISTORIC STRUCTURES, AND THE BROADER PUBLIC.

PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSING PATTERNS OF SUBTERRANEAN BIODIVERSITY AND MICROCLIMATES TO INFORM CAVE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATIONPROJECT DATES: 8/1/2022 - 7/31/2024PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES HAS VAST UNDERGROUND ECOSYSTEMS WHERE TEMPERATURES VARY LITTLE THROUGHOUT THE YEAR AND HUMIDITY IS ALWAYS NEAR 100%. THESE CAVE AND KARST ECOSYSTEMS PROVIDE MANY SERVICES TO PEOPLE, SUCH AS RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, REVENUE FROM TOURISM, AND GROUNDWATER STORAGE. CAVES ALSO PROVIDE HABITATS FOR IMPORTANT AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, LIKE BATS THAT EAT MOSQUITOES AND CROP PESTS.CAVE-DWELLING SPECIES HAVE EVOLVED TO LIVE IN RELATIVELY STABLE CLIMATES, SO THEY MAY BE ESPECIALLY SENSITIVE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. HOWEVER, IT IS UNCLEAR HOW SURFACE CLIMATE CHANGE WILL AFFECT CAVE CLIMATES AND THE SPECIES THAT RELY ON THEM, BECAUSE CAVES ARE REMOTE ENVIRONMENTS THAT HAVE LONG BEEN DIFFICULT TO STUDY. THIS PROJECT WILL FILL THESE IMPORTANT DATA GAPS SO THAT CAVE MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS ARE NO LONGER LEFT IN THE DARK WHEN PREDICTING HOW MANAGEMENT DECISIONS WILL AFFECT FUTURE CAVE ECOSYSTEMS IN A WARMING WORLD WITH ALTERED PRECIPITATION PATTERNS.THE PROJECT WILL BRING TOGETHER SCIENTISTS FROM NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA IN HUNTSVILLE (SUBAWARD) AND MANAGERS FROM FEDERAL, STATE, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS NINE SOUTHEASTERN STATES TO PERFORM UNDERGROUND SURVEYS OF CAVE CLIMATES AND CAVE-DWELLING SPECIES. BASED ON THESE SURVEYS, THEY WILL IDENTIFY ANY CAVES THAT CONTAIN RARE SPECIES AND ANY CAVES THAT ARE ESPECIALLY COOL AND WET. FORESTS COULD HELP KEEP CAVES COOL AND WET AS GLOBAL SURFACE CLIMATES CHANGE, CREATING IMPORTANT REFUGES FOR SPECIES STRESSED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO MEASURE HOW MUCH CAVE CLIMATES VARY BETWEEN CAVES UNDER DENSE FORESTS AND CAVES UNDER LANDS WHERE FORESTS HAVE BEEN REMOVED. USING INSIGHTS FROM NEW SURVEYS AND PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED STUDIES, THE TEAM WILL CREATE A TOOLBOX OF POSSIBLE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FOR CONSERVING CAVE ECOSYSTEMS OR CAVE-DWELLING SPECIES THREATENED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. THE TOOLBOX CAN BE USED BY MANAGERS THROUGH THE SOUTHEAST AND THE WORLD WHEN MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT HOW TO CONSERVE CAVES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

INDIGENOUS-LED CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES: INTEGRATING LANDSCAPE CONDITION, MONITORING, AND CULTURAL FIRE WITH THE NORTH FORK MONO TRIBEINDIGENOUS PEOPLES AND NATIONS ARE ON THE FRONT LINES OF CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS, YET THEY ARE ALSO LEADING THE WAY IN INNOVATIVE ADAPTATION ACTION, SUCH AS IN THE USE OF TRADITIONAL BURNING FOR ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND BUILDING CULTURAL RESILIENCE. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND AND CONTRIBUTE TO TARGETED DECISION-MAKING THAT FACILITATES THE APPLICATION OF INDIGENOUS CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO CULTURAL BURNING. INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL BURNING MAY BE APPLIED SINGULARLY, OR AS A COMPLEMENTARY APPROACH WITH OTHER ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PRACTICES, SUCH AS THINNING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING. FOCUSING ON COLLABORATION WITH THE NORTH FORK MONO TRIBE, THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES: (1) COLLABORATIVE, MULTI-PARTNER EFFORTS APPLYING INDIGENOUS CLIMATE ADAPTATION TECHNIQUES ACROSS JURISDICTIONS, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO CULTURAL BURNING; (2) VEGETATION MONITORING PRE- AND POST-CULTURAL BURNS; (3) A CLIMATE VULNERABILITY AND RISK ASSESSMENT OF INDIGENOUS PUBLIC DOMAIN ALLOTMENT LANDS; AND (4) A MULTI-STAGE EFFORT TO IDENTIFY AND SUPPORT INDIGENOUS LAND MANAGERS OF LANDS IN DIVERSE JURISDICTIONS TO INTEGRATE INDIGENOUS CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO CULTURAL BURNING. THIS PROJECT ADVANCES PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN THE SOUTHWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (SW CASC) AND TRIBAL NATIONS AND COMMUNITIES, PARTICULARLY THE NORTH FORK MONO TRIBE, IN ADDITION TO STRENGTHENING RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN TRIBAL MEMBERS, COMMUNITIES, AND NATIONS THAT APPLY INDIGENOUS CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES. THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE USGS, THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA (SW CASC), TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN CALIFORNIA, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS, WHO WILL LEAD PROJECT RESEARCH EFFORTS.
